story:
Short Summary

What are your favorite memories of PE in high school?  Do they include biking on the Golden Gate bridge, or hiking through national parks?  Our students experience these memories, thanks to our Post-session program!  

Post-Session is a milestone of the ARISE High School experience. Students take three-week intensive courses related to arts, creativity, or physical education. As a teacher, it allows me to teach the passions I have beyond the discipline I teach everyday. For students, it allows them to explore beyond the traditional academic disciplines, to get out of the classroom, build community across grade levels, and cultivate new passions. Students who haven't always done well in Math or English find new confidence and competence when they can explore other strengths like drawing, painting, dancing, biking, or mountaineering. Post-Session culminates in an exhibition night in which each course presents what they did and learned to the community at large. You are welcome to join us to see the impact of your contributions.

Our course offerings this year are as follows:

WARRIOR INTELLECTUAL LEADERS IN TRAINING

(Art Credit) Using interactive art mediums, students who have been elected by their peers to represent them in the Student Leadership / Step To College course, will become oriented to the basic structures of the course, better understand their responsibilities for the year, and create a leadership community ready to continue cultivating a stronger ARISE community.

OH, THE PLACES WE’LL GO

In Oh, the Places We’ll Go! we will explore attractions throughout the Bay Area, such as Coit Tower, the Golden Gate Bridge, the Exploratorium, and other hidden nature spots right in Oakland. All these exploring skills will be tested on a 3-day backpacking trip to one of the Bay Area’s most scenic spots.

OH! THE PLACES WE'LL DRAW!

Leisurely explore  the bay area and sketch things, people and animals. We will practice lots of drawing techniques using a variety of media. Botanical gardens, cityscapes, the zoo, the coastline and our own back yard will be the setting of this adventure. Your sketchbook will be your daily companion as well as your final product. 

I WANT TO RIDE MY BICYCLE!

We will bike the Bay Trail, the Headlands of Marin, Tennessee Valley, China Camp, and all over the East Bay. Students will learn bicycle safety, maintenance, and repair in addition to biking themselves into great shape. The course will culminate in a three-day overnight stay in the Marin Headlands. Trips for Kids will take us out mountain biking on trails in the surrounding area. Bikes!

EXPLORING THE OUTDOORS VERSION 2.0

This year we will continue to build on our skills navigating the outdoors by spending a week camping on the Klamath River in Humboldt County. We will develop strength and fitness through running, hiking and other exercises. We will also learn about native California ecological concepts. While in Humboldt, we will work with the Yurok tribe learning about different issues they face with sovereignty, land and fishing rights. 

ACTIVE RESISTANCE

Journey with us as we will find our Zen, strengthen our core, and learn healing strategies that speak truth to power. Active Resistance will provide you with the tools to endure struggle on all fronts of your life, be it physical, mental, emotional and spiritual.  Participants will increase their physical strength through traditional martial arts and yoga, find their center by practicing daily meditation and participating in a Native American sweat lodge ceremony, spend time amidst California's serene coastline and explore what Hip Hop, health, and higher education have to do with resistance. 

MI CUERPO RECUERDA: A Youth Wellness and Self Care Class

“Mi Cuerpo Recuerda” will be a 3-week journey that will help young women learn how to take care of their bodies. You will learn about different topics related to health and make your own medicine like massage oils, bath salts, tea blends, and more. To keep things fun, you will also be going on a field trip, have guest speakers come and share their knowledge about different topics, and watch cool films. 

HIP-HOP'S GOT ME FEELING SOME TYPE OF WAY

We will be exploring hip-hop culture through spoken word, emceeing, and dance. Students will also have the opportunity to study the history of hip hop along with the path it has taken from the Bronx in the 70’s to mainstream society in 2014. Hip Hop 4 change, along with other special guests, will lead workshops. 

SPORTS!  SPORTS!!  SPORTS!!!

Do you eat, live breathe, and sleep sports? Do you live for the highlight reels and Top 10 plays on ESPN? Or, do you just long to have some constructive outdoor fun? Well if so, come join Ms. J and Ms. Tanya as we travel around the world (ok, maybe not the world, but certainly the immediate Bay Area!) and play as many sports and anything else active as humanly possible!!! Some of the activities will include, but are not limited to: Basketball, Football, Baseball/Softball, Soccer, Tennis, Ice Skating, Skateboarding, Tumbling, Cheer, Track, Hiking, Power Walking, Bocce Ball, Dance, Kickball…and the list goes on (we may even get to attend some sporting events!!!). Learn to build healthy, positive competitive skills, teamwork & leadership skills, and healthy living skills, all while having fun and enjoying the beautiful bay!


What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, statewide budget cuts have gutted our funding for Post-Session and left us to raise the funds ourselves. Each course will receive $600, in addition to Bart tickets which we purchase for the students, which means we need to raise $6000 to support the 9 course offerings. Each course spends the money a little differently, but it is generally used for transportation, supplies, and guest teachers. For instance, the bicycle course uses the money for bicycle parts, snacks, and lodging for the overnight trip. The film course uses the money for camcorders, props and transportation.

As for perks, you will certainly receive kharmic bonus points, a sense of glory and accomplishment, and...most importantly...a thank you card from our students. For a $100 donation, the youth wellness crew will put together a stress-reducing tea blend for you.  If you give $150 or more, we will list you on our program at the exhibition night for all the post-sessions. 


Your Impact on Students

More than 80% of adults do not meet the guidelines for both aerobic and muscle-strengthening activities, and more than 80% of adolescents do not do enough aerobic physical activity to meet the guidelines for youth. (Reference 1)

Studies show that there is a correlation between physical exercise and academic success.  (Reference 2)

Children, on average, spend nearly 7 hours in front of a screen (television, computer, video games) each day.  (Reference 3)

Here's how your donation can help us overcome these statistics: over the past 7 years Post-Session has been offered, we've seen countless students discover their passions. Many students decide what they want to study after high school. And almost all students return to the classroom energized, more confident, and more ready to learn. Students also build relationships across the grade levels, with students who they don't have in their daily classes. This builds the familial, connected feeling of Arise High School.

Your contribution will help 250 students participate in post-session. It will enable students to receive the requisite Art and PE credit they need to graduate, while also exposing them to new topics, experiences, and modes of learning.


Here are some student quotes about the importance of Post-session:

"In Sports Around the Bay we got to go to parks all over the East Bay and play everything from basketball to ultimate frisbee. It allowed me to get out of my head and all the stress of my daily life. When we went camping, we could share with each other and really become friends with students we didn't know that well," Jennie.

"Post-session gives you three weeks where you don't have to stress about academics, but can focus on new experiences and making new friends. I loved spending three days in the Marin Headlands with the other students. We got to bond over some challenging bike rides and at night at the hostel. You just can't bond like this in the classroom," Eric.

"I think post-session is great because I can connect with my teachers outside of the classroom. It helps us humanize one another," Maria.

"At first, I thought Mr. Damon was crazy for making us drink that green sludge (energy shakes). Then I tried one and it wasn't as disgusting as it looked at it made me feel great. After the class, it was funny to see kids walking down the hallway with those green shakes," Marco.

"After bicycling, we were able to go the Bikery and earn free bikes. I started biking to school everyday. I think about half the class did too," -Chris. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, we get that. We're broke teachers, after all. You can still help, however, even if you don't have any funds. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word. Help us connect with folks who might have money. Also, if you have any of the following to contribute it would be of great help:

  • Bart tickets and AC transit tokens.  We need to get around the bay, and these are the easiest ways.  
  • Snacks for our groups on the go: granola bars, trail mix, beef jerky, water are all necessities as we're traveling around the bay area.
  • Any type of sports equipment!  Balls, bats, gloves, ropes, flags, etc.
  • Bicycles and Bike parts: if you or someone you know has a bike that's just collecting dust, you can donate it. If you happen to have spare parts or tools lying around, we'll take those too.
  • Art supplies. Of all sorts.  In particular, if you have sketch books, fine tip markers, drawing pencils and any other drawing tools (erasers, sharpeners) we would love to get some of those.
  • Digital Recording equipment: if you have camcorders, digital cameras, microphones, digital audio recorders, etc. We'd love them.


REFERENCES:

1. U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Healthy People 2020. Available at: http://www.healthypeople.gov/2020/default.aspx.

2. American Journal of Public Health. 2008 April; 98(4): 721–727.

3. Rideout, Victoria J., Foehr, Ulla G., and Roberts, Donald F. Generation M2: Media in the Lives of 8- to 18-Year-Olds.Rep. Menlo Park: Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, 2010.

story:
What is Film Camp for Teens?


Twice a year a group of Toronto filmmakers come together to run a five-day intensive training program where teenagers gain firsthand experience in professional filmmaking. The kids produce, write, direct, light, shoot, act in, and edit their own films! Renowned industry guest professionals are brought in to lead a variety of workshops. The teens work together in a caring, respectful environment where they are treated as equals and are encouraged to speak their minds. They are in a constant state of learning, filming a ton of training exercises - barely stopping to breathe! By Thursday they’re ready to shoot their final short films. Counselors work overnight on Thursday to edit these films so our teens can put the finishing touches on them on Friday morning - in time for a (grand!) Friday afternoon celebration and screening for family and friends.

These kids meet on Monday, some of them have never held a camera before, and look at what they accomplish only days later – it’s extraordinary:

http://www.centreforthearts.com/film-camp-for-teens/short-films/

Our March Break camp is only weeks away!

Dates: March 10-14, 2014
Time: 10am - 5:30pm
Location: 918 Bathurst: Culture, Arts, Media and Education Centre

Why do we need your support now?

For the first time in the 12-year history of Film Camp for Teens, we, the Producers and Counselors, are reaching out to our community for help as we prepare to produce our 23rd camp.

We have always had a high demand for Pay-What-You-Can and Full Sponsorship positions, but in recent years the request has come from nearly all of our teens. Faced with the escalating costs of producing Film Camp for Teens, the money we are able to bring in from registration simply doesn’t cover it.

It is a mandate of Film Camp for Teens to offer a spot at camp to any teen that would like to attend regardless of their financial resources.

We have worked with, and continue to work with organizations like Covenant House, St. Christopher House, Soulpepper Theatre Company’s Youth Outreach Program, Sick Kids Hospital, Trinity Bellwood’s Community Programs, 4Unity Productions, Theatre Revolve and many others.

We put our heart and soul into this camp. We'd love to be able to continue to offer this type of opportunity to our youth! 

Who are we?

For 12 years Film Camp for Teens has been run by dedicated and passionate Toronto-based filmmakers. Camp producers Sarain Boylan, Troy Miller and Ashleigh Rains have welcomed a multitude of professional filmmakers to camp over the years including longtime volunteers Daniel Abboud and Jill Harper.

To read Producer & Counselor bios please visit our website and scroll down the camp's sub-menu:
http://www.centreforthearts.com/film-camp-for-teens/


Where does your donation go?

-  space rental

-  equipment rental

-  insurance

-  gas & transportation costs

-  projector rental

-  DVDs and DVD cases

-  printing

-  office and craft supplies

-  free healthy snacks

-  props, costumes and make-up

-  a catered lunch for our Thursday full-day film shoot (which we have had to eliminate in recent years)

In addition, all of our talented and dedicated staff work tirelessly to make camp possible and are only offered a very small honorarium. We would like to be able to offer them a larger honorarium for the many long hours of work they put in year after year.

The Producers of Film Camp for Teens are exploring funding options, sponsorships, grants, etc for future camps. But, if you can, help the teens continue their wonderful creative work now!



If you would like to donate food and/or beverages, TTC Student tickets, equipment to camp, please email us:


info@centreforthearts.com
story_txt:
What is Film Camp
for Teens?Twice a year a group of Toronto
filmmakers come together to run a five-day intensive training program where teenagers gain
firsthand experience in professional filmmaking. The kids produce, write,
direct, light, shoot, act in, and edit their own films! Renowned industry guest professionals are brought in to lead a variety of workshops. The teens work together in a caring, respectful environment where they are treated as equals and are encouraged to speak their minds. They are in a constant state of learning, filming a ton of
training exercises - barely stopping to breathe! By Thursday they’re ready to shoot
their final short films. Counselors work overnight on Thursday to edit these
films so our teens can put the finishing touches on them on Friday morning - in
time for a (grand!) Friday afternoon celebration and screening for family and friends. These kids meet on Monday, some of them
have never held a camera before, and look at what they accomplish only days
later – it’s extraordinary:
http://www.centreforthearts.com/film-camp-for-teens/short-films/Our March Break camp is only weeks
away! 
Dates: March 10-14, 2014Time: 10am - 5:30pmLocation: 918 Bathurst: Culture, Arts, Media and Education CentreWhy do we need
your support now?For the first time in the 12-year history of Film Camp for
Teens, we, the Producers and Counselors, are reaching out to our community for
help as we prepare to produce our 23rd camp. 

We have always had a high demand for
 Pay-What-You-Can and Full Sponsorship positions, but in recent years 
the request has come from
nearly all of our teens. Faced with the escalating costs of producing 
Film Camp
for Teens, the money we are able to bring in from registration simply 
doesn’t
cover it. It is a mandate of Film Camp for Teens to offer a spot at camp
 to any
teen that would like to attend regardless of their financial resources. 

We have worked with, and continue to work with
organizations like Covenant House, St. Christopher House, Soulpepper Theatre Company’s Youth
Outreach Program, Sick Kids Hospital, Trinity Bellwood’s Community Programs, 4Unity Productions,
Theatre Revolve and many others. 

We
put our heart and soul into this camp. We'd love to be able to continue to offer this type of opportunity to our youth! Who are we?
For
12 years Film Camp for Teens has been run by dedicated and passionate
Toronto-based filmmakers. Camp producers Sarain Boylan, Troy Miller and
Ashleigh Rains have welcomed a multitude of professional filmmakers to camp
over the years including longtime volunteers Daniel Abboud and Jill Harper.
To read
Producer & Counselor bios please visit our website and scroll down the camp's sub-menu:http://www.centreforthearts.com/film-camp-for-teens/Where does your donation go?
-  space rental
-  equipment rental
-  insurance
-  gas &
transportation costs
-  projector rental
-  DVDs and DVD cases
-  printing
-  office and craft supplies
-  free healthy snacks
-  props, costumes and
make-up
-  a catered lunch for
our Thursday full-day film shoot (which we have had to eliminate in recent
years)In addition, all of our talented and dedicated staff work
tirelessly to make camp possible and are only offered a very small 
honorarium. We would like to be able to offer them a larger honorarium 
for the many long hours
of work they put in year after year. The
Producers of Film Camp for Teens are exploring funding options, sponsorships, grants, etc
for future camps. But, if you can, help the teens continue their wonderful creative work now!
If you would like to donate food and/or beverages, TTC
Student tickets, equipment to camp, please email us:info@centreforthearts.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Mack Worley. I am a disabled veteran of the United States Air Force. I honorably served my country for over 5 years before I was medically retired. I am a card carrying member of the NRA and a 2nd amendment activist through my youtube media channel youtube.com/onthemoveshow.

I was recently arrested while lawfully and peacefully open carrying a firearm in Vancouver, Washington. I have been charged with trespassing (even though I was on a public sidewalk) and displaying a weapon (which I wasn't touching and open carrying is authorized in the state of Washington and the city of Vancouver).

I am trying to get help paying for the costly legal fees that I am about to start racking up. I am dedicated to our personal freedoms and will not be intimidated. I will fight for all of us. I will not give up. If they can do this to me, they can do this to anyone. Anything you can donate would be greatly appreciated and will go to defending the 2nd amendment.

What We Need & What You Get

I literally have no idea how much we will need, but $4,000 would be a great start. I am sure my future legal fees will far exceed that amount. All donations will go to help protect our 2nd amendment freedoms.

I am not out to make a million dollars. If we somehow make more money than what is needed for my legal fees, I will donate all of what is left to the NRA (minus what has to come out for taxes).

I can offer as a reward for your donation a phone call from me (Mack Worley) thanking you. As well as recognition on my facebook (facebook.com/onthemoveshow).

The Impact

Every penny counts! I know you've heard that a million times, but it is true. I cannot afford a lawyer. Without your help I will be fighting this battle with a public defender. Don't let this be the battle they win and start using this court case as a precedence for future gun laws.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Send others to our page as well. Everyone needs to know about this. You can watch and share my interview with opencarryvancouver.com on YouTube (http://www.youtube.com/watch?annotation_id=annotation_468719&feature=iv&src_vid=vj88LhnLnx4&v=eN3ehYJ3NMA).

Please also subscribe to my YouTube channel (www.youtube.com/onthemoveshow), find me on facebook (www.facebook.comonthemoveshow) and follow me on twitter (@OnTheMoveShow).

Anyone and everyone who cares about their gun rights needs to know about this. Please help get the word out. I appreciate your support!

story:
What is ExamLab

ExamLab is a non-profit project which provides many services for Java programmers and SCJP/OCPJP exam candidates. The core of the ExamLab project is its exam simulator that has attracted over 150,000 people.  ExamLab is available on http://www.examlab.org

Who we are

The ExamLab project was started in 2008 with a free desktop software that runs on Windows platform. As the earliest step it supported only the Sun Certified Java Programmers (SCJP) 5.0 exam. One of the main objectives of ExamLab was it simulates the real exam interface assuming it gives the candidates more comfort in the real exam. After having over 60,000 downloads, it released another free version to support SCJP 6.0 exam in 2009, yet as another desktop application runs on Windows.

Due to some unavoidable reasons related to limited resources, the project was temporarily discontinued at the end of the year 2012, and re-initiated as web-based exam simulator in the mid of 2013, giving users more comfort to simulate the exam without having to download anything to their computers. With that migration, more useful features like "Get an Online Tutor" and "Do an Assignment" are introduced in parallel to the running of ExamLab test simulator.

I, Devaka Cooray, am a computer programmer, web developer, and software architect. I founded the ExamLab project in 2008 with 360 questions I wrote and an exam engine software I made.

Why we need your support

The mission of the ExamLab project is to reach Java education to more people.

I founded the ExamLab project for the prime and only interest of helping people to learn Java and gain their certifications. I started it with a desktop application and I, personally, was impressed as it has reached over 100,000 users in a relatively short time.

As it was growing on, my inbox started filling up with thousands of emails from people who wanted to buy the project or have their ads placed on the exam, and my response was a repetitive no. I like to see people coming here and getting some help thanking the project from their inside. I don't want to see people getting distracted or 'purchasing' ExamLab at their expense. And yes, I think I am right and I fulfilled my mission.

Seeing from the other end, we still need funds. As we are now running wholly on the web, we have much more expenses than ever since. I am heading up to pay through the nose as the server costs getting higher everyday. With all the expenses incurred, I need to keep ExamLab running forever, and yes, with seamless tinkering, new features, and improvements done all the way costing more and more. I need your help in that part, to sustain the seamless running of ExamLab.

Whatever you can donate, is going to be a 'saving' for someone in the future as it is only your donations can keep ExamLab running.

Previous fundraising

Our last fundraising campaign at Indiegogo helped us to pay off the expenses incurred in setting up and launching ExamLab successfully.

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/support-examlab-project-to-keep-it-running-forever-phase-3

Where your donations go

All your donations will be used to keep ExamLab running with more and better features introduced over the time. 

We have to spend the costs incurred in struggling to get the discontinued ExamLab project up as a web-based project. 

Our hosting costs us more and more as we are getting increasing number of user accounts created everyday, and lots of people doing web based exams at the same time.

It costs us to hire experienced and really talented people to provide tutoring services.

It costs us to hire experienced and really really talented people to review assignments.

There will be more features in future, and we need more funds to make them happened and provided for free.

What else you can do to help

Spreading the word of this cause will indeed be a real help. Please share this via emails, Facebook, and Twitter. I thank you all for all sort of helps you do to keep ExamLab running forever.

story:
What Happened?

On the night of Feb 10, Jayson's kids happened to be at their mom's house and he was able to escape a devastating fire that completely destroyed his home.  His cat did not make it out alive.


Why We Need Your Help

Jayson had only months before begun the process of purchasing the property and home.  After the fire, he found out that the current owner had no fire insurance, will not offer any help, and that even without the home, the property will still be the same price.  So, Jayson needs to start from scratch and it takes money to do that.  A place to live, new clothes, furniture, toys, etc as well as other expenses that are bound to come up as he sorts out the next phase of his life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.

First, your thoughts, prayers and wishes are always appreciated.  2nd, Jayson and his family are going to need a lot of non-financial help to get back on their feet.  Here is info on a Utah drop off location and an Nevada drop off location.  Also, Jayson lost all his clothes, so if you happen to have xl shirts, 34x36 pants or size 11 shoes or boots, that would help immediately.  And socks, etc.

UTAH drop off: Please message us if you plan on dropping something off. If you need something picked up, message us and we'll see what we can arrange. 1869 West Bowling Ave, Taylorsville, UT, 84129. If no one is home please leave in driveway or on the porch. Thank you.
NEVADA drop off or pickup: Please call Sid at 775-835-2346 for pickup or if you plan on dropping something off the address is 85 Laine Way, Fernley, NV 89408. If no one is home please leave in drive or on the porch. Thank you.

More info on specific needs will be posted on the official page, here, too.

story:
"YES" Rising Caledonia Music, Cultural Arts & Munro Baggers Festival

In the months leading up to September 18th Referendum vote these Events take on even more significance and are sorely needed now to HIGHLIGHT and MASSIVELY boost the YES Campaign.

These events are non-profit events being stage to raise fund for the "YES" Campaign.

To advertise and promote our events to interested sponsors in the hope of raising much needed funds or donations.

Now a little bit more about these event that we think should go on and would be a massive boost to “YES” as well as being a fantastic event and opportunity for you all to contribute to our Independence cause.

Rising Caledonia (Gathering of the Clans) Music and Arts Festival.
Saturday 28th- 29th June in conjunction with "YES" 2014 Munro Baggers

Venue: The Three Villages Community Halls, Arrochar Loch Lomondside, Argyll and Bute.


http://www.threevillages.org.uk/

The Three Villages Community | Arrochar, Tarbet, Succoth

www.threevillages.org.uk


Nestled beneath the Arrochar Alps, overlooking Lochs Long and Lomond, the Three Villages community of Arrochar, Tarbet and Succoth is situated within the Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, at the gateway to the Argyll Forest Park and the Cowal P


Tradional Scottish music and other genre along with:

Let's bring Rising Appalachia to Loch

Lomond.

Join the Demand at Eventful - http://evrd.us/39EWC

We also hope to attract some Castellers(Human Towers)from Catalonia.

Just Brilliant! We hope here in Scotland your towers of strength push your country towards Independence in 2014 and "Yes" now is the time! Together you shall do it!

Rising Caledonia (Gathering of the Clans) Music and Arts Festival.

(Event link below:)

https://www.facebook.com/events/450829458349091

"YES" 2014 Munro Baggers

(Event link below:)

https://www.facebook.com/events/243132002530390

"Yes" 2014 Munro Baggers ...They may take our City's by Unionist stealth but not our music and mountains.

I have an idea to highlight the "Yes" campaign but it needs to wait for better weather to start ... Sir Hugh Munro completed his list of Scottish peaks in 1891, and since then, people have been 'bagging' the 282
munros...

We plan to make a weekend of it possibly camping in a field with music and rallies/protests and Munro bagging Saturday 28th – Sunday 29th June

If you can't make Loch Lomondside don’t worry you can still bag a Munro near you and we all can bag a Munro at the same time with a Saltire and a "YES" sign.

Volunteer Here: (link Below)

Munro Baggers Group link below:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/596566387063365/

Enrollment form for the Munro Bagging:

("Click" on link to open form below)

https://adobeformscentral.co/?f=EgQ7cGZpnGKNer7nvvaMtw


The way Indiegogo works is that if we raise the full £3000 required, then we only get a 4% fee - if we don't reach the target, then the fee Indiegogo takes is 9%. If we raise the full £3000 then the festival and Munro Baggers for Independence can be set up and the anything leftover will be donated to the Yes Campaign.


We expect the deposit and damage cover insurance for the community halls to come to around £400-450 then the booking fees for the halls to take that figure to nearer the £1000 mark. ( Indiegogo requires a minimum of £500 to be raised for us to be charged 4% we will shoot for £2000 and any excess will be donated to the Yes Campaign rather than lining Indiegogos pockets ).

Can you help? With your teamwork, The “YES” @Army# can get this “YES” Gig back on the road again and raise those Independence Saltires and “YES” banners on all 282 of Scotland’s Beautiful Munros.

In achieving these Munro climbs and having this wonderful festival we send out across this beautiful country, a proud message to all that wish to see our country free once more.


Thank you so much to everyone who donates to save this Music,
Cultural Art Festival and Mass Munro climbs.

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Hi everyone!  Thanks for taking the time to check out our campaign.

This summer Statement Arts is returning to Washington Heights and the esteemed United Palace of Cultural Arts to provide a free College Prep Program for 12 underserved New York City kids!


What We Want To Do

Last year we ran a College Prep Program for 10 New York City kids. The program was a HUGE success and every one of our kids is going onto higher learning institutions. Most of them got substantial scholarships. We are running it again this summer and will be drawing kids from all over the city. We have received tremendous support, not only from the community, but in past years, State Senator, Adriano Espaillat, and City Councilman, Ydanis Rodriguez came to our Final Performance!


What We Need & What You Get

We have gotten several grants for this program but need to raise an additional $9000.  All money raised will go towards paying for the classroom and performance space, insurance, teacher's stipends, some supplies, transportation and refreshments for our final performance. We'd like to offer every student an equal chance to participate at no cost to them.

Any additional money raised, will go towards our other programs. Whatever you are able to give: $10, $50, or $200, we promise it will make an impact.

As a 501(c)(3), all money donated to Statement Arts is tax-deductible!


The Impact

Every single kid from our program is going to college. At Statement Arts, we believe that education is the great equalizer and we want to continue our work and commitment to arts education and mentorship. With your generous support, our organization can make a difference in the lives of urban youth here in New York City.


Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign with your friends can really make a difference. Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  Like us on facebook, tweet about us, forward our campaign on to all of your friends.

We'd like to thank everyone who helps us with this program and we look forward to empowering many more kids in the future.


About Us

Statement Arts is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization whose mission is to build self confidence and enrich underserved youth with creative experiences through arts education: Music, acting, dance, photography, visual art, filmmaking and writing. We believe that these arts education channels enhance young people's intellectual performance and self esteem, enabling them to become ambassadors in their communities.

www.statementarts.org 


A HUGE Thank you to Ari Espay for his amazing photos! Check out more of his work at www.ariespayphotography.com
story_txt:
Hi everyone!  Thanks for taking the time to check out our campaign.
This summer Statement Arts is returning
to Washington Heights and the esteemed United Palace of Cultural Arts to
provide a free College Prep Program for 12 underserved New York City kids!
What We Want To Do
Last year we ran a College Prep
Program for 10 New York City kids. The program was a HUGE success and every one of our kids is going onto higher
learning institutions. Most of them got substantial scholarships. We are
running it again this summer and will be drawing kids from all over the city. We have
received tremendous support, not only from the community, but in past years,
State Senator, Adriano Espaillat, and City Councilman, Ydanis Rodriguez came to
our Final Performance! 
What We Need & What You Get
We have gotten several grants for
this program but need to raise an additional $9000.  All money raised will
go towards paying for the classroom and performance space, insurance, teacher's
stipends, some supplies, transportation and refreshments for our final
performance. We'd like to offer every
student an equal chance to participate at no cost to them.
Any additional money raised, will go
towards our other programs. Whatever you are able to give: $10, $50, or $200,
we promise it will make an impact.
As
a 501(c)(3), all money donated to Statement Arts is tax-deductible!
The Impact
Every single kid from our program is
going to college. At Statement Arts,
we believe that education is the great equalizer and we want to continue our
work and commitment to arts education and mentorship. With your generous
support, our organization can make a difference in the lives of urban youth
here in New York City.Other Ways You Can Help
Sharing this campaign with your friends
can really make a difference. Please help us get the word out and make some
noise about our campaign.  Like us on facebook, tweet about us, forward
our campaign on to all of your friends.
We'd like to thank everyone who helps
us with this program and we look forward to empowering many more kids in the
future.

story:
Give Kids in Egypt a Chance. A Better Future Starts with Education! 

Nile Union Academy (NUA) in Egypt is a Christian secondary school dedicated to offering a high level education to rural students from across Egypt. We have been doing this for 60 years. Now we need your help.

NUA is a Christian English language secondary school in greater Cairo, Egypt. The students primarily come from Egypt and Sudan. Many of them come from poor villages in Upper Egypt. They have big dreams of becoming professionals in different areas and helping their families and communities. They are seeking a better future. Our diploma offers them the ability to seek a bachelors education almost anywhere in the world.

You Can Make a Difference

We are excited to be celebrating our 60th birthday this year! But with the joy comes danger. NUA is dedicated to offering the most affordable education possible. In a desire to help as many as possible, we have kept our tuition intentionally low. Now, before June, we need to raise $30,000 to stay in operation. 

  • We need $18,000 to pay salaries for our 25 dedicated teachers and staff. 
  • We need $12,000 to pay for general school expenses such as books, electricity, maintenance and dormitory expenses.
  • A donation of $250 will keep tuition at current levels for 1 student this year.
  • 100% of donations (minus Indiegogo's bit) will go directly to the continued education of students. 

NUA exists because at different times many people like you have stepped up to help these kids. Help keep the dream of education alive for all NUA students!

A VALENTINES DAY SURPRISE!

Update February 14, 2014. We have HUGE news to share! A surprise donor has stepped forward and offered NUA matching funds. For every dollar you give, the donor will give 2. We could hardly believe the news when we heard it! Our $30,000 goal could turn into $90,000 if reached! You can read the whole story by clicking on the update here.


Meet George

George is one student who has benefited from NUA. George, the son of a carpenter, grew up in Alexandria, Egypt. He admits that he was not a good student as a child. He got into a lot of trouble wreaking havoc on the streets of Alexandria where he liked to smoke and fight. In 2009 he heard about NUA and was fortunate enough to be accepted as a student. Slowly his life began to change. In fact, over the years George has changed from brigand to studious leader at NUA--he even quit smoking. He attributes his success to the faith in a brighter future NUA instilled in him.

"NUA was a turning point in my life. Here I studied for real for the first time. Here I started to have a personal relationship with God. Now I know that I'm able to succeed. If I aim something, by God's will I can do that. Without NUA I could not do much. This school planted a dream in my heart. The dream? After my graduation here, I want to study Political Science and work in the United Nations one day." (George Megdy Khier Essaa, 20, is a senior student and the Students Association President at NUA in 2014)


1st Class Education, 3rd Class Price

NUA is a boarding school. Most of the students and staff live on campus. Beyond quality education we provide students with regular meals, dorm accommodation, work education and social and religious activities. The dream is to keep the tuition as low as possible in order to help students obtain a 1st class education at a 3rd class price. 

60 Years Helping Kids

NUA began as a little rural school with no more than a couple students. Now we serve almost 130 dreamers—boys and girls eager for a brighter future. We must not be allowed to stop making some difference in Egypt through education. Please, help us to have one more reason to celebrate the 60th NUA birthday this year.

story:
BHDragons Bosnia Youth Football Campaign


Short Summary

Bosnia-Herzegovina is a country in South-Eastern Europe that saw untold violence and destruction in the 1990s.  Much of the country lay in ruins, and even nowadays, the economy is very bad, making it one of the poorest countries in Europe.  One of the uniting forces in the country is football, which brings joy to the population, in particular children.  Bosnia has just qualified for its first ever World Cup, and the sport is more popular than ever.  Sadly many children cannot afford to play the beautiful game, nor train in proper conditions because of a lack of equipment and money.  That is where you come in!

What We Need & What You Get

BHDragons is collecting monetary donation that will be pooled into a PayPal account. All of the money, 100% will be distributed to youth football programs such as Valter Skola in Sarajevo, and others.  The money will be used to purchase cleats, footballs, goals, jerseys, and shorts for the children that cannot afford them.

  • Donating at least $25 will put your name (if you choose) on our Wall of Honor, a permanent page on our website.
  • Donating at least $50 will enter you into a prize drawing which includes an Edin Dzeko Manchester City jersey, a signed Edin Dzeko photograph, and your name on our Wall of Honor.

The Impact

The impact of this campaign will be tremendous.  Football is the most popular sport in the country.  Children benefit from extracurricular activities such as sports to help grow in mind, body and spirit.  Help Bosnia's youth today by doing a beautiful thing for the beatiful sport!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you cant help!

Help us get the word out by tweeting out this campaign, sharing the video and the news! Tell your friends, family, anybody that will listen!

www.bhdragons.com

story:
Extraordinary Child- where every child belongs... and their families always have a place that welcomes them.

                                                                      

Our Extraordinary Mission

We unite and strengthen special needs families and individuals representing all types of disabilities, by providing positive social experiences and family bonding in our unique therapeutic play facility.

We Need Your Support to continue helping the many special needs children and families that depend on us. 


Extraordinary Child is a volunteer based organization with no paid employees.  We depend on the generosity of people, like you, who care... to continue helping the special needs community.


Why giving to us is important

Your donation will also help us to not only keep our doors open, but it will also improve and expand our facility to accommodate more children, with all types of disabilities. We will be able to provide more needed services and add needed therapeutic equipment.

    

                         

  We have done so much already with very little... 

imagine what we can do with more...

Who We Are

My name is Jennifer and I am the founder and Director of a new and unique non-profit called Extraordinary Child.  We are a therapeutic play facility designed specifically with the needs of special needs children in mind, but we are beneficial to ALL children. We firmly believe 'inclusion goes both ways'.

At our unique facility we do not require a referral or insurance, we strive to keep access affordable and sometimes free.

What we do:

  • We provide opportunities for individuals with special needs and their families to access: social interaction, sensory-enriched play, emotional support, and family resources.
  • We provide a place for families to play and bond in ways that might not otherwise be available to them.
  • We provide resources, support, and education
  • We provide play that supports childhood development
  • We provide networking for adults and children
  • We provide a safe and supportive environment that gives families positive experiences, rather than negative emotional outcomes
  • We provide opportunities for sibling and family bonding
  • We do so much more!!!

Why we need your help- in detail

                                             

Like most new nonprofit businesses that launch we have had many successes and obstacles. Our successes include each positive impact we have made on our families, volunteers, interns, and our community at large. Be we need donations from extraordinary people like you to continue our mission.

Fundraising Goals & Needs

$5400 will give us time to hear back from grants we have applied to, and to implement other fundraising efforts. Please take a moment and see with your own eyes why this is important.

$8500 will allow us to help more special needs families and offer further programming.

$20,000 will keep our doors open worry free for a year, help even more special needs families and purchase much needed office supplies.

$40,000 will do all of the above and we will be able to purchase needed therapy supplies (like a hammock chair, special needs library, etc) and to build our sensory polar room.  These items will help many more special needs children, who will benefit greatly from the sensory stimuli this will provide.

What else you can do to help

Learn more about us, spread the word, and like our facebook page. Our vision is to have facilities located all over the United States and to help persons' with disabilities of all ages.

To get tickets for our sticks Tavern BBQ please read the following instructions first and then click on purchase link. We are using this service because we are not being charged a fee.


  1. Take a moment and review ticket selection options on the right of the screen under the word "perks".

  2. Choose the package that fits you the best and then hit the red button that says "contribute now"

  3. Be aware that you can only select one perk when you donate to this site, so if you choose only one child ticket but need four, you will have to make 4 separate donations.

  4. Make a donation in the amount that matches your ticket selection. Example; if you would like 1 adult ticket only, please donate 20 dollars.

  5. Once you make the donation it will ask you to select your "perk", choose your ticket package.

Thank you for your donation

story:
This is a project that I am extremely excited about, and I believe this can be replicated in all communities (and should be!) It all started back in 2006 when we purchased a single family home in Amherst, MA.

The Idea is Simple:

  • Transform a traditional single-family home into the premier sustainability house and educational site in Amherst, MA (Or insert your town/city! Learn more about that below)  

Why is this Important?

In 2008, I began learning about the massive amounts of energy that our houses and buildings use. So I set out on a quest to address that issue and two years later received my M.S. degree in Green Building from UMass Amherst. I decided the best thing I could do was focus locally and to create a prototype that demonstrates how anyone can live sustainably.

The Pilot Project:

This particular project focuses on a home located in Amherst, MA and converting it into the premier sustainability house and educational site in Western, Massachusetts. Here’s what we’d like to accomplish over the next 6 months:

  1. Installing a 4.4kW roof-mount solar system that supplies 70% of our household energy needs (happening this month – installed by PV squared!)
  2. Planting a front-yard mini orchard of 10 fruit and nut trees (peaches, pears, paw paws, Asian pears, persimmons, hazelnuts and more!)
  3. Creating a map / planting guide for the front-yard community permaculture garden
  4. Building a patio that we’ll use to host educational and community-building events
  5. Beginning a microbusiness that entails selling surplus edible and medicinal plants from our garden (A Permaculture Plants Nursery!)

THIS PROJECT IS ABOUT EDUCATION!

We understand that this project alone cannot solve all the world’s problems. But it can serve as a model and be an example for others – and that’s incredibly important!

The 6,000 square foot (front yard!) permaculture garden is our main area of focus because it is extremely visible and interactive for engaging our community. The garden is already used to teach others how to live a happy, healthy and high quality of life while having a beneficial impact on the ecology, neighborhood, and the local economy!

What We'll Do With The Funds Raised!

Specifically, we’ll be using the money we raise to purchase edible fruit trees (asian pears, peaches, persimmons, paw-paws, cherries, etc.) nut trees/bushes (walnut, heartnut, hazelnut) berry bushes, as well as other edible perennials (flowers, herbs, insect attractors, soil-building plants, etc.) We’ll concentrate on getting as many from local sources as possible. We’ll also be buying seeds, soil amendments, compost and mulch, educational signage.

If WE REACH OUR GOAL, WE’LL ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING (in YEAR 1!):

  • 100+ community visitors – we will engage at least 100 community volunteers each year and we’ll be promoting free educational events throughout the year, such as tree plantings, harvest days, sheet-mulching workshops, and more!
  • 5-10 free garden/home tours – At least one per month throughout the growing season that anyone can attend and register for (1-hr guided tour of the property.)
  • Develop a website and provide free online content about the project that allows others to see what we did and create a similar home transformation of their own.
  • Continue to develop a how-to manual (e-book) with special thanks to people and organizations who donate! Version 1 is already available on our website.

SO WHAT WILL MY DONATION DO EXACTLY?

  1. It will help us create this model project that can be adapted and replicated anywhere
  2. It will provide hundreds of future volunteers with an educational “living laboratory” that they can interact with and learn from.
  3. It will provide funding to create an online hub that can be used to tell more people about this project, and how we are doing it.
  4. It will help us establish an edible (permaculture) plants nursery. We are concentrating on plants that can be easily propagated and we intend to share the surplus and help other individuals and projects create similar permaculture gardens!
  5. If you donate at a certain level, we’ll even send you a personalized E-book (a how-to manual) so you can begin experimenting and trying this out for yourself!

Summary:

  • This project is all about education and the main focus is to demonstrate how anyone can transform a traditional single family home into a model residence for sustainable living.
  • This particular (pilot) project focuses on a particular home located in Amherst, MA and converting into a premier residence for sustainability education.
  • We are intentionally starting with the garden as it is a space that can quickly and easily and quickly engage a lot of people and simultaneously showcase how we can have a regenerative impact on our ecosystems and communities.
  • In the long-term, we hope that every community will have a house like the one we are trying to create.

Summary:


This project is all about education and the
main focus is to demonstrate how anyone can transform a traditional single
family home into a model residence for sustainable living.


This particular (pilot) project focuses on
a particular home located in Amherst, MA and converting into a premier residence for sustainability
education.


We are intentionally starting with the

In the long-term, we hope
that every community will have a house like the one we are trying to create.

story:
The students of The Triangle Program need us to come together as a community to raise funds to replace the equipment that was stolen on the night of June 20, 2012.

This is Pride month in Toronto - what better time to come together to show the youth of our community that we care? 

Let's raise some money to provide the classroom with new computers this summer, before the youth come back to school in the fall.

 

After the theft, The Triangle Program tweeted:

"We are sad that our school had a break in last night. Hope the people that took our technology needed it more than we did. We forgive you."


We will make a single donation by cheque to The Triangle Program once this campaign closes.  We can't do it without you.


A note from Andy: I believe that the crowdfunding platform provides accountability and transparency to the project.  As a longtime member of Toronto's LGBTQ community, I am putting my personal and professional reputation behind this fundraiser to ensure this campaign is successful and the money goes directly to The Triangle Program.   

 

About The Triangle Program:

The Triangle Program is Canada’s only high school program for LGBTQ youth.  It is a safer space, free from homophobia, transphobia and heterosexism where LGBTQ youth can be themselves, be respected, and valued for who they are.  It is a program where all will be respected and treated equally regardless of gender, race, ethnicity, religion, class, ability, gender identity or sexual orientation.  Racist, sexist, homophobic and other oppressive behaviour, language and/or symbols are not tolerated.  The Triangle Program is a classroom that supports students to develop or rediscover the skills necessary to successfully transition back mainstream secondary school programs, post-secondary education, or to the workplace.  It is a supportive environment where conflicts and differences get dealt with quickly in a mature and responsible manner.

The Triangle Program Values:

  • A safer, social justice, community-focused, and equity-based high school program for students who have left school, or are thinking of leaving school, because of the homophobia, the transphobia, and the heterosexism that exists in the school system.
  • A program designed to assist students in developing both the academic and life skills necessary to move on to another high school program, a post-secondary program, or to the workforce.
  • A student-centred program, with a teaching and support staff that work together to assist students in developing their potential.
  • A program that features curriculum about our LGBTQ – lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans-identified, inter-sexed, two-spirited and questioning/sexual minority  – literature, history, and lives.
  • A process of community and community input.  We modify our Program’s policies and practices through reflective approaches to teaching – communication with staff, students, parents/guardians, and our school council

Who The Triangle Program Serves:

We serve all members of the LGBTQ community, their families, and other students negatively affected by homophobia and heterosexism.

  • Students learn that they have a valued place in the LGBTQ community and the community at large.
  • Students learn that they have a rich LGBTQ history and are able to contribute to the further development of Canadian society.
  • Students experience the joy of celebrating themselves in positive ways that encourage them to pursue their life dreams, those previously shattered by the homophobia and heterosexism they have endured.
  • Students will earn credits towards their Ontario Secondary School Diploma – courses are offered at the  Applied, Academic, College Preparation and University Preparation levels.
story_txt:
The students of The Triangle Program need us to come together as a community to raise funds to replace the equipment that was stolen on the night of June 20, 2012.This is Pride month in Toronto - what better time to come together to show the youth of our community that we care? 
Let's raise some money to provide the classroom with new computers this summer, before the youth come back to school in the fall.
 
After the theft, The Triangle Program tweeted:
"We are sad that our school had a break in last night. Hope the people that took our technology needed it more than we did. We forgive you."

We will make a single donation by cheque to The Triangle Program once this campaign closes.  We can't do it without you.

A note from Andy: I believe that the crowdfunding platform provides accountability and transparency to the project.  As a longtime member of Toronto's LGBTQ community, I am putting my personal and professional reputation behind this fundraiser to ensure this campaign is successful and the money goes directly to The Triangle Program.

story:
Dear Family and Friends,

In 3 weeks I’m going to San Rafael, Honduras to help build a Methodist Church and to run a childrens' program there.

Honduras is located in Central America and is one of the poorest third world countries. I went there two years ago and it was the most amazing and unforgettable experience of my life! I can never fully explain what a life changing moment that was for me. That trip made me realize how fortunate I am, and that I want to spend my life helping make a difference to the less fortunate, especially the children.

I made such amazing relationships there, and I’m so thankful for this opportunity again.

The cost of the trip is $1,300 and despite my best efforts, I’ve only been able to save $500. I'm reaching out to my family and friends and ask that you might consider donating money for this trip. I truly appreciate any donations given, and please know that all donations will make a difference.

If you can't support me financially, I understand. I would also appreciate your prayer support. Please consider praying for our team, prayers for health, and protection as we make this trip.


Love,

Jamie

story:
Hello Aggies!

I am working with the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Initiative, which in short is an initiative developed to increase awareness and representation in the STEM disciplines for members in underrepresented groups. We would like to share some news and make North Carolina A&T Alumni  and supporters of representation in STEM disciplines aware of a couple of pressing items.  Firstly, A&T is the largest producer of minority STEM graduates in the country.  Secondly, A&T is hosting a STEM conference on March 7 -9th  to increase minority awareness in the STEM disciplines.  Finally, the STEM Initiative is launching a fundraiser in conjunction with the STEM conference in order to promote STEM projects which may be ultimately put toward future research and scholarships. A portion of the funds donated are tax deductible and all will be sent to the STEM conference on behalf of the A&T Alumni.  To support this effort please follow the support information below.  Additionally, in order to attend the conference send an email to thestem.donation@gmail.com

Thanks in advance for your support. 

 

AGGIE PRIDE!!!!!!!

  

 
Please forward this site to all of your social networks and spread the word

story:
I have lived in Belize for three years and have been working as the trainer/instructor at the Belize Equestrian Academy for close to two. After over 25 years of being a professional horsewoman in the USA, I was drawn back into the service here in Belize.

We have an amazing group of students at the BEA, from all over the globe, to local kids that are of Belizian, Creole, and Mayan decent. Many of our students are able to pay for their education and that helps keep the school open. But many others, such as local youth, are not able to do so and I try to provide training regardless. I have been fortunate to get some local funding to help me do this, but it gets to a point, with such a small country that is not well funded itself, that there is only so much one can do.

The idea of having the Cayo Institute for the Deaf start to ride at the BEA was two fold. One, it would give us more students and help the struggle to keep the “stall doors opened” so to speak, but more than that, it excited me to that old feeling of WOW, this would be amazing! Enough so that if I could do it financially myself, I would. But, that’s not reality. I have worked with kids of special needs over my vast career and there was never anything more gratifying… Rescuing an animal is close, but to see a child who was told he/she couldn’t/shouldn’t do it, EXCEL is amazing.

Did you know:

Benefits of Therapeutic Horseback Riding for Children with Disabilities

  • Balance, posture, strength
  • Flexibility
  • Teamwork, cooperation
  • Self-confidence, self-esteem
  • Emotional control, self-discipline
  • Sense of normality
  • Hand-eye coordination
  • Visual/spatial perception
  • Remedial math and reading skills
  • Advanced equestrian skills

Watching a person connect with a horse, see that understanding the horse has, watch that bond build and the belief in ones self worth, is truly an inspiration.

I have letters of recommendation from, paraplegic, autism and blind families. I KNOW the horses can make a difference in the Deaf students life as well. If given the chance, Ill prove it. If we reach our goal I hope to be able to take on more local youth for lessons as well.

I can only thank you and believe God will bless you for any contribution that you can make to help us obtain this goal. If you can not hepl with funding, please help us tell folks about our plan and share our quest with others.

As we progress, I will do my best to have updates constantly. If you would like to see a little bit of the BEA now, check out the NBHA Belize Facebook page as the events are hosted there at the Academy and will show you many of our existing students.

“Never sell your saddle, cause lifes a long, long ride"

story:
My Permaculture Path

Lunaya Shekinah is a visionary permaculture designer, consultant and teacher who brings a fresh new perspective to the permaculture paradigm. Part of the Gaiacraft core team, she has collaborated to design an extensive educational platform and learning community dedicated to cultivating sustainable practices and creative solutions for pressing planetary concerns from local to global. Offering design and consulting services, she cultivates her imaginative intelligence to support people in making successful, long term design decisions about their properties, homes and lifeways. She is currently doing a two and a half year All Seasons Advanced Permaculture Diploma Course connecting countless projects and initiatives together into a holistic life design.  Over the years she has collaborated to create a series of permaculture web platforms, learning and teaching tools, books, worksheets and all manner of conscious educational materials. Inspired to create a series of open source permaculture media vehicles, Lunaya has dedicated herself in service to the World Community. 

What I Need & What You Get

Right now, in order to complete my diploma, I need to take advantage of an amazing opportunity to take the Permaculture Teacher Training right here in my back yard of Roberts Creek, with the very teachers who are going to be awarding me my diploma!! 

- I need $1,1100 to finish paying for this awesome training. Every penny donated will go directly to that cause.

- Anyone who makes a donation will have free access to my online Introduction to Permaculture Course! Contributors of larger sums will get to be part of a pilate group for a 6 month permaculture coaching program that I'm developing. I will also be giving out free educational media to everyone and passing it forward in so many ways.

- If I don't reach my goal, I will put the funds towards another teacher training or PDC, both requirements of my Diploma process.

The Impact

I would appreciate your help soooo much from the bottom of my heart. This training will empower me to take my permaculture educational outreach work to the next level. I will not only be teaching a montly Introduction to Permaculture course at a very affordable rate, but also developing an online course and a coaching program. I'll continue moving forward on my path, accepting opportunities to create and rebirth powerful media platforms for the permaculture message to reach the world. This will help inspire countless people to explore and activate in service to the planet, who otherwise would not consider it. It will make a big difference to our gaian culture, helping to educate, inspire, and evolve individuals and communities worldwide.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially to this campaign, I do understand! There are still lots of other ways you can help. Mostly, I would ask if you could share this campaign on your social media pages and email. Tell your friends and think of people who might be in a position to help fund me. I can't begin to tell you how much this would meant ot me.

story:
An Educational Crisis for Native American Youth:

  • High school drop out of rates of 70% for Native American students
  • Only 17% of Native American high school graduates attend any level of college.  The rate is 67% among other students in the U.S.
  • Bullying and racism directed towards Native American students
  • Low self esteem and lack of opportunities
  • Teenage suicide rates at 4 times the national average
  • Large numbers of students mislabeled as special education

"Society has lowered standards to a point that underachievement is more likely than not." Bradbury, Boyd

The Academy is a private charitable institution. We receive no federal or public school funding.  We have a team of dedicated expert teachers and volunteer staff working with disadvantaged youth to ensure that these students are successful in their education and in their lives. www.theacademy.bz, www.sunkawakan.org

Changing Lives:

“Before, I had no confidence in myself, I would hide my smile. Since I have been here I pay attention to my school work, I am welcomed with open arms by other students and I have a future where I can do whatever I dream."

8th grade student at The Academy

 

The Academy is a K-12 educational center, internationally accredited by The University of Cambridge. The Academy is changing the lives of Native American children in a premium academic setting where children are nurtured and all cultures are celebrated. This top-ranked, educational foundation is ensuring future success in higher education and beyond for each of these students.  We need your help to provide this opportunity for more children in need. 

 

Life-Changing for Native American Families at The Academy

"I am an enrolled Oneida Tribe of Indians member but more importantly I am a grandmother raising three grandchildren.  It is my experience and belief that Native American children face unique challenges.  It is shocking, but a truth we live, that prejudice still exists in our community off the reservation.  As a result of this prejudice bullying is prevalent and many children live a life of fear and quiet desperation within the classrooms, in the halls and on the playground of our local schools.  There have been many children in our family that have experienced this.  It has gone on for decades.  My granddaughter was a victim of bullying and the opportunity to attend The Academy came at a time when we were looking for solutions.  What we discovered at The Academy is such a unique educational environment that all three grandchildren have grown in ways we could not have even imagined."

 

"The Academy has granted our children hope for a brighter future.  The incredible opportunity they have at experiencing an excellent education at The Academy, and the hope for continuation for their education at the university level, has opened doorways that have been closed to this specific population for generations."

 

"Being taught that each child is unique and deserving of the best there is to offer has given them so much more than an excellent education."

 

One Student's Story:

"I'm 14 years old.  What The Academy is offering to Native Americans is a bright future, helping us, the students, achieve what we really want to do with our lives.  The Academy has students from around the world.  As soon as you step through the doors all students are equals.  That's what Native Americans need, we want to be like every other kid who wants the best education.  At my last school it was horrible because they made fun of those who were Native.  I was bullied.  I did not want to go to school where people still judge you by your skin color.  The Academy's goal for its students is to be successful at whatever we do.  Before, I had no confidence in myself, I would hide my smile.  This school has really changed me because before I never really learned anything.  I was bullied and did not have a bright future.  Since I have been here I pay attention to my school work.  I am welcomed with open arms by other students and I have a future where I can do whatever I dream." An 8th Grade Academy student

 

"It is with this hope and knowledge that we have the ability to catch these wonderful, incredible spirits.  To be able to nurture, shape and mold the youth is a must.  No longer should we accept the depressing statistics we need to be addressing them and bring forward the wonderful minds, talents and spirits of our children."  Lakota Resident of Pine Ridge Reservation

story:
Short Summary

We are partnering with GOOD SHEPHERD SERVICES and their Red Hook Beacon Center. (More on these Amazing organizations Below).  Three Wednesday afternoons in April, two Barefoot Teaching Artists will collaborate with Good Shepherd's Beacon Center and their students (ages 14-17) to write short plays.  During the week, when not meeting with teaching artists, students meet every day with Beacon Center staff to work on their writing pieces.  They have also received donated laptops that each student will take home to use for their writing.  

The third meeting will consist of students being paired up with writers and artists 1-on-1 to edit their final drafts.

The last day will be for student to come to an off-broadway theatre, meet Barefoot members and learn about the process of creating and producing one's own work.  They will see a short rehearsal, followed by their pieces read on stage and then a more established playwright's work read on stage.  It's going to be awesome!

In the past, Barefoot Theatre Company has collaborated with Stella Adler Studio Of Acting's Outreach Program as well as South Side High School in Long Island, New York by holding ensemble workshops, holding invited dress rehearsals for students, talk-backs with artists as well producing new plays by students in our bareNaked Reading Series...

What We Need & What You Get

  • All funds will go towards:
  • Teaching Artsits Stipends
  • Artists Stipends
  • Supplies: Copies, Binders, Water, Coffee.

By supporting our Education Department's OUTREACH PROGRAM, you'll be the first to get a special invitation to the student's presentation at an Off-Broadway venue featuring first rate directors, actors and award winning playwrights taking part in the post show talk-back.  Additionally, you'll get a special thank you along with tax-deductible letter stating how much we've appreciated your support and further gifts such as: company pin, posters, special invite to upcoming events and productions.  

The Impact

Good Shepherd: "Good Shepherd Services is a leading youth development, education and family service agency that serves over 20,000 program participants a year. Focusing on high-need communities in Brooklyn and the Bronx, we provide a broad array of individual, family and school-based services to prevent youth from becoming disconnected from family, school and society. We also help those who come to us already disengaged find hope and motivation to reconnect with their community. When young people cannot stay in their families, we continue to provide a safety net of superior quality foster care and residential programs, as we have since 1857."
 
Beacon Center: "Good Shepherd Service's Red Hook Beacon provides year‐round, day, evening, and weekend activities for more than 2,000 young people and their families annually. Activities designed to promote individual, family and community development include an afterschool program for six to twelve year olds; four youth leadership development groups that engage youth from the ages of 9‐21; a summer camp program and events such as the annual Community Thanksgiving Dinner."   

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word by sharing the link to this campaign on any and all social media outlets and extend our search for help to friends and family.

(More on these Amazing organizations Below).  Three Wednesday afternoons in April, two Barefoot Teaching Artists will collaborate with Good Shepherd's Beacon Center and their students (ages 14-17) to write short plays.  During the week, when not meeting with teaching artists, students meet every day with Beacon Center staff to work on their writing pieces.  They have also received donated laptops that each student will take home to use for their writing.  
The third meeting will consist of students being paired up with writers and artists 1-on-1 to edit their final drafts.
The last day will be for student to come to an off-broadway theatre, meet Barefoot members and learn about the process of creating and producing one's own work.  They will see a short rehearsal, followed by their pieces read on stage and then a more established playwright's work read on stage.  It's going to be awesome!
In the past, Barefoot Theatre Company has collaborated with Stella Adler Studio Of Acting's Outreach Program as well as South Side High School in Long Island, New York by holding ensemble workshops, holding invited dress rehearsals for students, talk-backs with artists as well producing new plays by students in our bareNaked Reading Series...


What We Need & What You Get

All funds will go towards:
Teaching Artsits Stipends
Artists Stipends
Supplies: Copies, Binders, Water, Coffee.

By supporting our Education Department's OUTREACH PROGRAM, you'll be the first to get a special invitation to the student's presentation at an Off-Broadway venue featuring first rate directors, actors and award winning playwrights taking part in the post show talk-back.  Additionally, you'll get a special thank you along with tax-deductible letter stating how much we've appreciated your support and further gifts such as: company pin, posters, special invite to upcoming events and productions.  


The Impact

Good Shepherd: "Good Shepherd Services is a leading youth development, education and family service agency that serves over 20,000 program participants a year. Focusing on high-need communities in Brooklyn and the Bronx, we provide a broad array of individual, family and school-based services to prevent youth from becoming disconnected from family, school and society. We also help those who come to us already disengaged find hope and motivation to reconnect with their community. When young people cannot stay in their families, we continue to provide a safety net of superior quality foster care and residential programs, as we have since 1857."
 

Beacon Center: "Good Shepherd Service's Red Hook Beacon provides year‐round, day, evening, and weekend activities for more than 2,000 young people and their families annually. Activities designed to promote individual, family and community development include an afterschool program for six to twelve year olds; four youth leadership development groups that engage youth from the ages of 9‐21; a summer camp program and events such as the annual Community Thanksgiving Dinner."   


Other Ways You Can Help
Help us spread the word by sharing the link to this campaign on any and all social media outlets and extend our search for help to friends and family.

story:
Why Japan Day @ Central Park Needs YOU

Japan Day @ Central Park was started in 2007 and has grown into an event eagerly anticipated by New Yorkers from all walks of life. This year, Japan Day @ Central Park will be May 12th, 2013.  But just as Japan Day has become more and more popular, the event is facing critical challenges in this difficult economic environment -- and we need your support if we are to keep proudly presenting the best of Japan in Central Park.  (Take a look at the video above for last year's thrilling celebrations!)

Japan Day is a day-long cultural celebration that kicks off with the rousing Japan Run, a 4-mile mini marathon, and kids' races hosted by New York Road Runners. The 4-mile race is a qualifying race for ING New York City Marathon. The event continues with Japan Day Festival featuring food (udon, gyoza, tea and more!), activities (origami, calligraphy, yo-yo and more!), and stage performances  (pop & traditional music, dance, karate, and more!). Last year's festival attracted 45,000 who enjoyed all these offerings completely free of charge.

The event, however, is not free to produce! So, you will have our heartfelt thanks -- and the rewards listed below -- if you will kindly contribute!

 

  • For a contribution of $15 or more, you will receive Japan Day 2013 original button!  (The actual design may differ from the image shown below.)

  • For a contribution of $30 or more, you will receive a pair of Japan Day 2013 original foam can coolers!  (The actual design may differ from the image shown below.)

  • For a contribution of $50 or more, you will receive Japan Day 2013 original "Arigato / Thank You" T-shirt!  Plus all of the above.  (The actual design may differ from the image shown below.)

  • For a contribution of $100 or more, your name will be listed on Japan Day official website!  Plus all of the above.

 

Japan Day Inc. was registered in 2008 as a non-profit organization (NPO 501(c)(3)), and your contribution will be tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.

Please visit our website at http://www.japandaynyc.org/ for much more information, and details on the Japan Day Art Contest.

 

Contact Us

For any questions and comments, please contact our Project Liaison Office:

Japan Day @ Central Park Project Liaison Office
Address: 226 West 47th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10036
Tel: 212-398-7145
Email: risa@gorgeousentertainment.com

Please also visit our website, facebook page, and Twitter, and spread the word!

Official Website: http://www.japandaynyc.org/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Japan-Day-Central-Park/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/Japan_Day

story:
Hello,

My name is Gavie West and I'm excited to let you know that I am raising funds to go to Italy and Greece this summer. This should be the trip of a lifetime and will broaden my horizons in many different ways.
At the end of June, 2012 I will be joining two teachers and approximately fifteen students on a journey that will allow us to learn not only more about the cultures, but also learn more about myself, as well as how to manage my own money by myself. While this is an amazing opportunity, it is also very costly. This trip will cost over four thousand dollars.
I am doing various sorts of fundraising, but I am currently asking for private donations. That is you! If there is any way that you, your friends, or your company would be willing to donate, it would be greatly appreciated. 
I am aware that times are financially tough; however, if there is any amount that you can donate that will help me arrive closer to my goal, it will be treasured. Every little bit helps. 
Please, tell people you know.If I'm not able to reach my goal the funds will go into a savings account for college.
Thank you,
Gavie West
