story:
Short Summary

The Indian Pueblo Cultural Center (IPCC) is a tax exempt 501(c)(3) organization with a mission to preserve and perpetuate Pueblo culture and to advance understanding by presenting with dignity and respect, the accomplishments and evolving history of the 19 Pueblos of New Mexico. We are owned and operated by the 19 Pueblo Indian tribes of New Mexico. 

This Popé (pronounced Po-Pay) sculpture, by Clifford Fragua of Jemez Pueblo, is currently on loan to us by the artist. We are raising funds to acquire Popé as part of our permanent collection. Popé was a community and religious leader of the 1680 Pueblo revolt against the Spanish. This was the first successful uprising by a Native American group against a foreign oppressor in North America.

By keeping the Popé sculpture "home" at the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center, we will contribute to the education of thousands of visitors annually and more importantly, we will be sharing this important historical event and individual with a younger generation of Pueblo youth. The Popé sculpture stands as a reminder of the important role he and others played in preserving Pueblo culture, religion, traditional lands, language and a way of life. It is our intent to share this story and connect the path that has paved the road for our Pueblo people today as we strive to maintain our way of life and strengthen our deeply rooted traditions. 

This is the second rendering of Popé by Clifford Fragua. In 1995, Mr. Fragua was commissioned by the State of New Mexico to complete a statue to be dedicated and housed in statuary hall in Washington, D.C. Popé II is carved from the same pink Tennessee marble as the first Popé sculpture . 

What We Need & What You Get

This Popé sculpture is valued at $125,000.and artist Clifford Fragua is committed to the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center and our mission, so he has reduced purchase price to $70,000. Our goal is to ensure that Popé never leaves the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center and is here for future generations.

Indian Pueblos Marketing, Inc. (IPMI), our sister corporation is supporting this campaign too. For each dollar committed, IPMI will contribute $0.50 cents toward our $70,000 goal. Thanks to individual donors we have raised $33,000 toward our goal. We are a little less than half way toward our goal of $70,000. 

We strive to reach our goal by August 10, 2013, which is the 333rd anniversary of the 1680 Pueblo revolt. We hope a final fundraising push will get us there.

The Impact

For many students learning New Mexico history, the Pueblo Revolt of 1680 is but a small paragraph in their textbooks. For New Mexico’s Pueblo people, this event is a vital part our history and presents a monumental example of resilience and sacrifice by our ancestors. Just as American History teaches students about influential individuals like Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and President Abraham Lincoln, we would like to teach about Popé and other significant Pueblo people who have personally contributed to the continuance of Pueblo life. We would like to share the stories of those who have risen to the challenges in their own right and advocated to preserve and protect such things as their traditional lands, language, sovereignty, suffrage, natural resources, sacred places and the right to practice Native religion. 

This sculpture was loaned to IPCC in January 2012 to be a part of a special exhibition entitled 100 Years of State and Federal Policy: The Impact on Pueblo Nations. This exhibition is currently on display at the center. The 7-foot tall Popé is the first thing our visitors see when entering the center, with good reason.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't Contribute? Here's how you can help:

Share this Campaign with all of your friends on Facebook and other sites so we can reach a wider population. Spreading awareness is just as important as donating. 

Use the tools here on Indiegogo to share this impactful Campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Aoi Taiyo is a Non Profit Organization which hosts academic competitions and events for students. Our mission is to shape young minds to be positive leaders. 

This year, Aoi Taiyo is participating in the Kansai Walk-A-Thon by hosting the 2013 Scavenger Hunt Games for students ages 5-16.

The Walk-A-Thon is an annual charity event held by the American Chamber of Commerce (ACCJ). The charity's theme is supporting women in the workplace by improving the working environment for women in Japan as well as to contribute to the growth of Kansai, its society and business. 

The Kansai Walk-A-Thon will be held at the New Grand Front Osaka, North District.  October 19th 2013

2000+ people attend ACCJ Kansai Walk-A-Thon every year. This year we are aiming to bring more students to the event and estimate that 500+ students will participate in the 2013 Scavenger Hunt Games.

 

 

What We Need

In order for the 2013 Scavenger Hunt Games to be a success we need your help! As an NPO we rely on sponsors and volunteers to make each organized event an epic success.

We aim to raise money to support the 2013 Scavenger Hunt Games which will support the Walk-A-Thon's goal to raise money for the overall charity.  

Funds raised will be used to purchase the scavenger hunt supplies for the Aoi Taiyo booth and winning give-a-ways for the participating students. Surplus funds will be donated to the ACCJ Kansai Walk-A-Thon directly. 

 

 

The Impact

The working environment for women is most often a challenge in Japan. Japanese women constitute nearly half (48%) of university graduates. Yet this tranche of talent is woefully underutilized: Only 67% of college-educated women are currently employed, and many of them either languish in low-paid, part-time jobs or are shunted into dead-end “office-lady” roles.

But, with the Help of the ACCJ and other government parties throughout Japan, japanese  women's socio-economic positions are changing, as well as the discursive politics surrounding mothers in contemporary Japan.

And although Aoi Taiyo is an NPO for students, we know with our help we can support the ACCJ's efforts as well as still give students at attendance a chance to learn and participate in an educational event themed to support working women in japan. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in the Kansai area and would like to volunteer to be an Aoi Taiyo volunteer please don't hesitate to contact us!

We also encourage everyone to come and participate in the Walk-A-Thon! 

For more information about the Kansai Walk-A-Thon visit:

http://www.accjwalk.com/about/index.html

story:
What we do

Csoma's Room Foundation is a group of architects, social workers and education professionals who have set out to support a wonderful community in its transition to 21st century, while learning tremendously about traditional Tibetan culture - about nature, silence and ourselves.

Sight to Sky is a Singapore based non-profit, which started in 2012 with the vision of bringing eye care to under-served communities in the Himalayas. Through their mobile eye clinics, they have served a total of 11563 patients whom have either received screening, treatment and all whom have received primary eye care education.

These two organisations joined efforts to complete a new Solar School in the Zanskar Valley in 2017. 

We invite you to join and support us, so that we can provide more effective, more elaborate tools to this community.

We have been working in beautiful Zangla village (in Ladakh, India, at about 3700 meters elevation) since 2008 with both locals and Western volunteers on projects related to construction and architecture, as well as education and community.

Photo: Seregély Eszter

 

Our projects in 2017:

  1. Tanpo Solar School:  we aim at building a new solar school, ideal for winter schooling, when no other local facility can accommodate children) in Tanpo village in the Indian Himalayas. This would secure the winter schooling of another 30 children in the area, when students are otherwise forced to stay away from school, due to extremely low temperatures. We use local building methods and materials, along with large, sun-facing windows, that capture the heat of the Sun and do not require any of those external energy sources, that are scarce in this region.
  2. Winter Accommodation Project & Solar School Project: we have been working on the Zangla Solar School project and its adjacent Winter Accommodation (for teachers) for several years and we are proud to say, they have been already in use in the winter of 2016-17 by pupils and teachers from several villages. Although we have years of experience with local materials and construction, buildings often suffer damages due to extreme weather conditions. We need volunteers and material to correct these damages and maintain the school buildings for maximum comfort.
  3. English tuition: English is a fundamental asset for Ladakhi people to articulate their position and interests. Our volunteers assist the Governmental School of Zangla with professional English teaching. In addition, in 2016, thanks to a successful cooperation with the Changchub Choling Monastery and the Jamyang Foundation, our volunteers held English teaching sessions to the little nun students of the Zangla nunnery. We would like to keep up this good work that we all enjoyed.
  4. Community development through creativity: in 2017, we would like to launch a community program. Given our good relationship to local children, we start by creative developmental sessions in the Zangla Solar School, using alternative educational methods but building on kids’ interests. In addition, we would like to start a beginner adult session, to develop basic English skills within the adult population of Zangla as well.

Photo: Seregély Eszter

How can you contribute?

Help Csoma’s Room Foundation with your donation to support a unique community in transition.

 

Donate to support:

- Continuous access to schooling in remote, extremely cold winters

- Access to professional English tuition where English is key asset

- Community programs for better cohesion and language skills, as a first step to empowering villagers to act on their own interests

Your donation will actually shape the future of a region, where small scale projects still have a measurable impact!

Photo: Irimiás Balázs

Why we do it

From preservation to resilience

 

10 years ago, we arrived on bicycles to Zanskar, a remote, secluded area in Ladakh, the Indian Himalayas, following the epic trail once undertaken by Alexander Csoma de Kőrös, author of the first Tibetan-English dictionary. At around 3700 meters elevation, we did reach Zangla village, known for its 16th century Palace (where Csoma de Kőrös has also spent 13 months) surrounded by numerous stupas, still magical in its crumbling state.

 

One of us being an architect, amazed by the simple, natural beauty of Ladakhi buildings, we decided to come back and bring some help. We launched our first program to perform emergency interventions and basic conservation work on Zangla Palace.

 

As we got to know Zangla and the people of Ladakh more and more, we soon discovered, there is much more to help: modernisation is arriving with full power, to villages that used to live in complete isolation until about 30 years ago - and are still extremely remote.

Photo: Seregély Eszter

A community in steep transition

 

The Zanskar Valley is a unique place in the Indian Himalayas, rich with traditional Tibetan Buddhist culture, secluded by mountains reaching 7000 meters. The region remained unaffected by globalisation for centuries, however, in recent years it started to open up rapidly: attracted by the unique landscape and Zanskari culture more and more visitors are flocking to the region. Tourism development is expected to accelerate further, as a new road construction is cutting through valleys and high passes, opening a free way all year round, in and out of Zanskar.

These developments  will have a significant impact on the traditional lifestyle, to which they will need to adjust. In order to maintain their unique identity and culture, while benefitting from the opportunities of modernisation locals will need suitable skills and tools. We believe in the unique, creative combination of the innovations of the 21st century.

Due to the remoteness of the area, locals face several barriers when meeting this challenge.

  1. Language barrier: Access to information requires an English-speaking generation, who are also capable of protecting their own cultural heritage.
  2. Cultural barrier: a sustainable community has to value its own culture, self-sustaining structures and ways of production.
  3. Skills and know-how barrier: Modernisation will demand new skills to manage in the rapidly changing environment. Necessary know-how needs to be developed to help locals work out a model for local, community-specific development.

  4. Resolution & Progress: Ever since Csoma’s Room Foundation started working in Zangla, we have managed to complete and maintain several projects mostly focused on the development of the local education and the preservation of the local cultural heritage.

 

The Zangla Solar School Project

 

Photo: Fehér Anna Ditta 

After completing the conservation of Zangla Palace and several historical Stupas, our focus shifted towards Education and Sustainable Development. Our first Solar School in Zangla was completed, with a Teachers' Accommodation in 2016, with the help of a successful Indiegogo Campaign. This year we would launch our second Solar School project in the neighbouring Tanpo Village, as a joint Project with Sight to Sky, a non-profit based in Singapore.

In addition, Sight to Sky saw the potential to use the school as a future base for their clinic operations in the high need area of Zanskar.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

About The Csoma's Room Foundation

Inspired by Alexander Csoma de Kőrös - the Hungarian author of the first Tibetan-English dictionary - who was studying in Zangla for one and a half year - The Csoma’s Room Foundation carry out all their activity in the region with the help of volunteers and local craftsmen, with an approach that complies to international heritage protection requirements.

 

Their helping hand in education focuses mainly on the local school, where they help students with textbooks that are customised for the region, volunteer teachers and most importantly by building sustainable solar schools suitable for winter times.

 

www.csomasroom.org

 

We appreciate any kind of help you can provide!

Please share our project with friends who would be interested in it, and follow us on social media:

Facebook

Youtube

Instagram

Tumblr

English tuition: English is a fundamental asset for Ladakhi people to articulate their position and interests. Our volunteers assist the Governmental School of Zangla with professional English teaching. In addition, in 2016, thanks to a successful cooperation with the Changchub Choling Monastery and the Jamyang Foundation, our volunteers held English teaching sessions to the little nun students of the Zangla nunnery. We would like to keep up this good work that we all enjoyed.

Community development through creativity: in 2017, we would like to launch a community program. Given our good relationship to local children, we start by creative developmental sessions in the Zangla Solar School, using alternative educational methods but building on kids’ interests. In addition, we would like to start a beginner adult session, to develop basic English skills within the adult population of Zangla as well.
Photo: Seregély EszterHow can you contribute?Help Csoma’s Room Foundation with your donation to support a unique community in transition. Donate to support:- Continuous access to schooling in remote, extremely cold winters- Access to professional English tuition where English is key asset- Community programs for better cohesion and language skills, as a first step to empowering villagers to act on their own interestsYour donation will actually shape the future of a region, where small scale projects still have a measurable impact!Photo: Irimiás BalázsWhy we do itFrom preservation to resilience 10 years ago, we arrived on bicycles to Zanskar, a remote, secluded area in Ladakh, the Indian Himalayas, following the epic trail once undertaken by Alexander Csoma de Kőrös, author of the first Tibetan-English dictionary. At around 3700 meters elevation, we did reach Zangla village, known for its 16th century Palace (where Csoma de Kőrös has also spent 13 months) surrounded by numerous stupas, still magical in its crumbling state. One of us being an architect, amazed by the simple, natural beauty of Ladakhi buildings, we decided to come back and bring some help. We launched our first program to perform emergency interventions and basic conservation work on Zangla Palace. As we got to know Zangla and the people of Ladakh more and more, we soon discovered, there is much more to help: modernisation is arriving with full power, to villages that used to live in complete isolation until about 30 years ago - and are still extremely remote.Photo: Seregély EszterA community in steep transition The Zanskar Valley is a unique place in the Indian Himalayas, rich with traditional Tibetan Buddhist culture, secluded by mountains reaching 7000 meters. The region remained unaffected by globalisation for centuries, however, in recent years it started to open up rapidly: attracted by the unique landscape and Zanskari culture more and more visitors are flocking to the region. Tourism development is expected to accelerate further, as a new road construction is cutting through valleys and high passes, opening a free way all year round, in and out of Zanskar.These developments  will have a significant impact on the traditional lifestyle, to which they will need to adjust. In order to maintain their unique identity and culture, while benefitting from the opportunities of modernisation locals will need suitable skills and tools. We believe in the unique, creative combination of the innovations of the 21st century.Due to the remoteness of the area, locals face several barriers when meeting this challenge.

Language barrier: Access to information requires an English-speaking generation, who are also capable of protecting their own cultural heritage.

Cultural barrier: a sustainable community has to value its own culture, self-sustaining structures and ways of production.

Skills and know-how barrier: Modernisation will demand new skills to manage in the rapidly changing environment. Necessary know-how needs to be developed to help locals work out a model for local, community-specific development.
Resolution & Progress: Ever since Csoma’s Room Foundation started working in Zangla, we have managed to complete and maintain several projects mostly focused on the development of the local education and the preservation of the local cultural heritage.
 The Zangla Solar School Project Photo: Fehér Anna Ditta After completing the conservation of Zangla Palace and several historical Stupas, our focus shifted towards Education and Sustainable Development. Our first Solar School in Zangla was completed, with a Teachers' Accommodation in 2016, with the help of a successful Indiegogo Campaign. This year we would launch our second Solar School project in the neighbouring Tanpo Village, as a joint Project with Sight to Sky, a non-profit based in Singapore.In addition, Sight to Sky saw the potential to use the school as a future base for their clinic operations in the high need area of Zanskar. Other Ways You Can Help About The Csoma's Room FoundationInspired by Alexander Csoma de Kőrös - the Hungarian author of the first Tibetan-English dictionary - who was studying in Zangla for one and a half year - The Csoma’s Room Foundation carry out all their activity in the region with the help of volunteers and local craftsmen, with an approach that complies to international heritage protection requirements. Their helping hand in education focuses mainly on the local school, where they help students with textbooks that are customised for the region, volunteer teachers and most importantly by building sustainable solar schools suitable for winter times. www.csomasroom.org We appreciate any kind of help you can provide!Please share our project with friends who would be interested in it, and follow us on social media:FacebookYoutubeInstagramTumblr

story:
Mission: Give students participating in local community-based organizations access to a program that will prepare them to make educated decisions regarding a college or career choice after high school. Our goal is giving teens thorough assessment, education and evaluation prior to making important decisions for their futures.

This program includes:
• Career assessment
• SAT/ACT instruction
• How to write a powerful college essay
• College admissions timetable
• Develop a successful college application
• Getting the most out of a college visit
• Using the Internet for college search
• Searching for scholarships
• Financial aid understanding
• How to search for colleges
…and much more!

Goal: We’d like to raise $100,000.  This would give us the momentum to expand the program outside of Rochester, NY and reach inner-city kids nationwide.  

Coursework provided to the student:This seminar helps teens participating in a community-based organizations master the essential steps in developing effective plans for career and college readiness.

Step 1 – Assessing their interests, skills, academics, and personal preferences and relating them to appropriately matched majors, career paths and college environments.

Step 2 – Learning how to research and explore your options for all aspects of post-secondary educational opportunities. How to include the practical use of print, electronic and in-person resources.

Step 3 – Developing informed and effective decision-making skills regarding all aspects of college planning including majors, financial aid, testing, and a strategic understanding of admissions dynamics.

Step 4 – Getting organized for the application process so you are empowered to possess both confidence and effective time-management skills.

During the sessions, students will document their work using a unique NextStepU workbook. Students will be encouraged to share the seminar experience and content with their parents. Each session will result in follow-up activities and Seminar Workbook completion exercises. Students may consult with their school counselors and parents as they work on this material. At the end of this process, each participant will have a written action plan to guide them through his or her "Next Steps" in college planning.

Who will take the seminar: Students in grades 9, 10 and 11 currently participating in community-based organizations such as Boys & Girls Club.

About the creator of the program: James F. Malone, Ph.D., NCC, NextStepU College and Career Readiness Counseling. For more than 40 years, Malone has helped thousands of students, parents and institutional clients on every level within the educational community. His counseling services and consulting work address the needs of individuals who are seeking assistance with college selection and career planning.

Professional credentials include National Counselor Certification, New York State Mental Health Counselor Licensure, New York State Permanent School Counselor Certification, Distance Credentialed Counseling, Approved Clinical Supervision and Fellowship Status Membership in the National Career Development Association. Malone has served as a high school counselor, a graduate school counselor educator-trainer, a director of distance career counseling services for a national company and finally, as a private practitioner and consultant for a variety of individuals and institutions. For many years, he published and presented widely in the fields of career counseling and college planning.

Why we are crowd funding: Our goal is to expand this to as many teens as possible! This program is happening locally in Rochester, N.Y. We have local colleges, businesses and instructors taking part in and witnessing the success happening for the teens that are participating. We can’t keep this to ourselves! The author and main instructor for the program is ready to train instructors nationwide.

story:
Prepping to go live on Proyecto U, Noticias Univision 41 San Antonio with co-anchor Zulema Garcia.

AliBee who?

With blue bonnets and la chancla, from Texas with love. A first generation Texan gal with Mexican roots on a journey to become a voice in the Spanish media. Self-confessed running addict, Alicia Barrera is a lover of traveling, cultura, and the media.

Honors student at Our Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX.

Why #ReporterAliBee needs YOUR help!

Dedicated to enhance the quality of journalism in the land of the free, the National Association of Hispanic Journalists (NAHJ) is an organization I have always strived to become part of as a young professional. In less than 30 days hundreds of Hispanic journalists will be gathered in San Antonio as NAHJ celebrates their 30th anniversary convention, and I hope to be there too!

During my years as an undergrad at Our Lady of the Lake University I have received valuable experience with Univision 41 San Antonio as an intern and most recently as a freelancer. My work with Univision 41 includes experience in community affairs, production, as well as on-camera work in both news and entertainment. My mission is to continue learning and networking as this passion for broadcast journalism runs in my veins. Below is my reel! 


Covering the 2013 Taco Truck Throwdown in San Antonio, TX for Univision 41's "Tu Estilo".

The NAHJ 2014 Convention will take place August 7-9 and will include workshops, panels such as "Getting Your First Job" and "Video Journalism for All Platforms", a media and career expo, and of course some time to let loose on the dance floor. To view the schedule click here.

Here is where I need your help. The registration fee for NAHJ student members is $275.00.

The money I raise will go directly towards the registration fee for this 3-day convention. 

Your donation is so valuable to me as I know it will have a great impact in my career. This 3-day event serves as a chance for me to network with other Hispanic journalists, improve my storytelling, and become a stronger leader in my community.

Anchoring for Univision 41's "Proyecto U" back in 2013.

This convention is an opportunity for me to become a better journalist so that I may better communicate with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

I ask that you please support me by donating, sharing with friends and family on social media, and following me on this journey! You can find me on both Instagram and Twitter under @CallMeAliBee & hashtags #ReporterAliBee #AliBeeNAHJ14SA #NAHJ14SA

Co-Anchoring "Proyecto U" live with Zulema Garcia, 2013.

Producing Our Lady of the Lake University's LakeFrontLive Newscast, 2014.

Networking with Mr. John Quiñones at Our Lady of the Lake University, 2014.

Networking with Mr. Jorge Ramos in Univision Newsport, Miami, FL, 2014.

A strong female role model in the industry, Ilia Calderon.

In the words of Chicana theorist Gloria Anzaldúa, "I change myself, I change the world." That is my goal.

We have 19 days to reach my goal of $275.00. 

Ready? Set. GO!

Muchas gracias. Thank you.

story:
Aldo Leopold Charter School

We need a new stove...and updated kitchen equipment.

After 103,247 lunches in 10 years, it isTime to retire Capri...!!!

The Lunch Bunch is a group of committed parent volunteers who strive to serve healthy, affordable and hot lunches each and every school day. Each year they serve over 10,235 meals. We supplement the lunches with greens and vegetables grown in our School Garden. Local merchants provide healthy and nutritious lunches in their commercial kitchens and we serve them hot and ready for Middle School and High School students. Beloved as she is, we want to retire "Capri" our old and inefficient stove and replace her with an energy efficient model. We also need updated shelving, storage and serving equipment.

Please help us raise the funds to purchase a new stove and other kitchen equipment so the Aldo Leopold Lunch Bunch can continue to serve hot lunches.

Thank you so much for your support.


Aldo Leopold Charter School is a New Mexico Public Charter School

Mission:

Aldo Leopold Charter School provides an engaging and challenging educational program emphasizing direct experience, inquiry learning, stimulation of the creative process, and stewardship of our community and natural environment.

story:
The Event

The University of North Texas (UNT) Graduate Student Art Education Association (GSAEA) is a professional organization that exists to promote academic and professional development for students in the department of Art Education and Art History.  Additionally, the organization seeks to promote cutting edge research and scholarship in the field of Art Education.  As such, GSAEA is launching a new annual symposium. The theme for the 2015 symposium is Method/ologies, and will focus on the vast theories and methods used to access research data as it relates to both art and education.  Art Education, because of its interdisciplinary and creative foundation, lends itself to a breadth of methodological approaches.  Thus, the 2015 symposium will not only benefit students and scholars in the field of art education, but also others who are interested in the arts, education, philosophy, and the social sciences. 

The Need

The symposium will be a free event for any graduate or undergraduate student who would like to attend.  However, the following expenses will need to be met:

Honorarium for Speakers: $500 ($100 per speaker)

Refreshments: $200.00

Marketing Designs: $50.00

Printing of Marketing Materials: $50.00

Our speakers for this year have agreed to join us at no cost, and so if we do not meet our campaign goal, the money earned will go towards refreshments and marketing for the event. 

The Impact

It is our hope that emerging scholars in the field of Art Education and beyond will walk away from this symposium with a sense of renew confidence in their own ability to engage dynamic research methodologies and methods.  Not only that, but we hope that attendees will gain a global understanding of the limitless research possibilities that can be forged through the arts. 

Your Help

Please consider donating to our campaign, and remember that helping is a simple as promoting our efforts among your contacts via social media!  Thank you in advance for your support!

story:
Who?

Aimee is this amazing woman who is a core part of our lives. 

Her goal before her next birthday: To become a certified yoga instructor. 

Aimee gives so much to everyone around her on a daily basis that we want to give back to her. Aimee gives to her preschool students and coworkers, she gives to the foster pets she takes care of, she gives to friends and family constantly even if it's just moment to listen. She has said that finding yoga has opened her to love in so many ways. She wants to take her practice deeper and we want to make sure that dream happens. 

What?

Aimee needs $1500 to cover the rest of her tuition. 100% of that will go towards tuition for her. This cost is calculated after receiving a partial scholarship from Asheville Community Yoga. 

If the goal isn't reached a portion of it goes to Indiegogo and the remaining balance will go towards the program. If we reach the goal Aimee keeps 5% more of the money! 

We want to make sure everything is covered and that Aimee gets to keep it all!

See what exciting perks are offered...let us know if you want to provide a perk. 

Where...will you see it in action?

Aimee will be overwhelmed with love if we can band together and make this happen. That's not all of it though.

Aimee dreams of offering a weekly opportunity for the staff of the childcare center, where she already offers so much of herself, to practice together under her guidance. Her vision is to boost morale and camaraderie amongst other team values. She wants to incorporate yoga into the curriculum of her classroom for two-year-olds. She knows it will broaden the development of their motor skills and give the class a fun, but focused activity to send the energy of the room in a positive direction. Also, she imagines encouraging pregnant women to yoga practice during and following their pregnancy. She is a gentle and humorous instructor who would hope to help the expectant mothers with their body awareness before labor and continued self care once the baby is born. Most recently, the idea of offering a morning practice for parents/guardians and their toddlers every other weekend has been mentioned with a twinkle in her eyes. She would also continue to considerately suggest poses and practices to family and friends who share their lives’ ups and downs with her.

We've already found a Yoga Alliance certified program. 

We've already had her registered AND gotten her a partial scholarship. 

Aid us in making sure Aimee gets to pass on everything she intends to learn on this journey.

When?

Deadline is January 1st. New Years Day.


The Game of Risk

Our risks and challenges with this campaign are one and the same. Not raising all the money. If we don't raise all the money we risk turning some more of it over to our wonderful host site. We risk not getting Aimee into the program due to not being able to fund it. We have the challenge to make sure we support Aimee to our fullest and show her the amazing gratitude and joy we have from having her in our lives. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share. Share. Share. Send this via email. Facebook it. Instagram it. Tweet it. Whatever other social media with take us, throw us out there!

Give us a perk. There's some perks for giving to Aimee's campaign. You can get a Facebook shout out. You can get yourself a jar of homemade organic chai. You can get a homemade thank you from the Caitlins. Why not add a perk for someone else to look forward to?

story:
This past summer, we witnessed a dark time in the Israel and Palestine. Over 2,000 people killed, mostly Palestinians, and more than 4,000 rockets were shot into Israel. The lack of leadership showing an alternative only deepened the hopelessness.

Against all odds, during this time, hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians broke through social, political, and physical barriers, to come together around constructive action. They are the young leaders you see above - the students of MEET. If things are ever to change we must continue to strengthen and grow this network of young leaders. 

We need your help to make sure that these young leaders can continue meeting throughout next year - 2015 - and work together to change the status quo and build a better future!

What is MEET?

MEET is an innovative educational program which, for the past 11 years, in partnership with MIT,  is bringing together the next generation of Israeli and Palestinian young leaders through technology and entrepreneurship. MEET empowers its students to take action towards creating positive social and political change in their communities. When you mix youth, technology and entrepreneurship amazing things can happen. 
You can hear more from MIT President Reif and some of our supporters here:

MEET was recently mentioned by President Obama as "an example of how innovation is reshaping the Middle East.”


Learn more from All Things D, WIRED, Fast Company & MIT President Reif.

          


What this campaign will do

Our goal is to raise at least $15,000 through this campaign to enable our students to continue meeting weekly throughout this year. We can only do this with your help. The money raised through this campaign will allow the following:

  • 30 face-to-face meetings in 2015 for 3 hours each, with 140 students 
  • They will participate in activities that promote communication, break down stereotypes, and foster leadership
  • They will learn computer science and entrepreneurship from MEET alumni, based on curriculum developed by our amazing MIT instructors
  • They will create projects that tackle social and political change in the region
Please support this campaign in any way you can - $50, $500, $5,000 - it all gets us closer to making this happen!! MEET students are showing another way is possible, and they need all of our encouragement to continue fighting the status quo. 


Q&A

How will my money be used?
You are helping us fund weekly classes for 140 Israeli and Palestinian youth (15-17 years old, half Israeli/Palestinian, half boys/girls), currently in MEET’s Student Program. Funds go towards teacher stipends, transportation (not a small feat across borders), lab rental costs, and snacks.

What do students learn in these weekly classes?
Classes are led by MEET alumni, based on curriculum created by our MIT instructors, and are 2-4 hours each time. These classes are essential not only because students gain computer science and entrepreneurship skills, but also because they learn to work together, rely on each other as teammates, and create joint projects that address real-world issues. These weekly classes are part of a rigorous 3-year Student Program, composed of three summer intensives (2-4 weeks) and two yearlong programs (~30 weekly classes). 

Where are the students from?
Students are 15-17-year olds from 11 cities in the West Bank, Jerusalem area, and Nazareth area. Most have never met someone from the “other” side prior to MEET. They work hard to get into MEET - only 70 out of about 1,000 youth are accepted each year for the incoming class.

What types of projects do students create?
This past summer, students created projects tackling media bias, emergency first aid, bi-national tourism and more. See more here, including their venture proposals.
story_txt:
This past summer, we witnessed a dark time in the Israel and Palestine. Over 2,000 people killed, mostly Palestinians, and more than 4,000 rockets were shot into Israel. The lack of leadership showing an alternative only deepened the hopelessness. Against all odds, during this time, hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians broke through social, political, and physical barriers, to come together around constructive action. They are the young leaders you see above - the students of MEET. If things are ever to change we must continue to strengthen and grow this network of young leaders. 


We need your help to make sure that these young leaders can continue meeting throughout next year - 2015 - and work together to change the status quo and build a better future!What is MEET?MEET is an innovative educational program which, for the past 11 years, in partnership with MIT,  is bringing together the next generation of Israeli and Palestinian young leaders through technology and entrepreneurship. MEET empowers its students to take action towards creating positive social and political change in their communities. When you mix youth, technology and entrepreneurship amazing things can happen. 
You can hear more from MIT President Reif and some of our supporters here:MEET was recently mentioned by President Obama as "an example of how innovation is reshaping the Middle East.”

Learn more from All Things D, WIRED, Fast Company & MIT President Reif.

             

What this campaign will doOur goal is to raise at least $15,000 through this campaign to enable our students to continue meeting weekly throughout this year. We can only do this with your help. The money raised through this campaign will allow the following:
30 face-to-face meetings in 2015 for 3 hours each, with 140 students 

They will participate in activities that promote communication, break down stereotypes, and foster leadership
They will learn computer science and entrepreneurship from MEET alumni, based on curriculum developed by our amazing MIT instructors
They will create projects that tackle social and political change in the region

Please support this campaign in any way you can - $50, $500, $5,000 - it all gets us closer to making this happen!! MEET students are showing another way is possible, and they need all of our encouragement to continue fighting the status quo.

story:
Helping those affected by the Badulla landslide

As many of you are aware I recently volunteered in Sri Lanka at an orphanage, kindergarten and elderly care centre in Badulla in Central Sri Lanka. Just this week a huge landslide, caused by monsoon rains, struck a major tea planation in Badulla burying as many as 350 people. It is unlikely any survivors will be found. Most of those lost are tea pickers who are paid as little as $3 a day.

As many as 12 children from the kindergarten class I volunteered at have lost parents and the impact will also be felt at the elderly care centre and orphanage as extended families are responsible for the cost of meals and the like in these organisations.

It is my intention to travel to Sri Lanka next month to distribute any funds raised personally so you can be confident any donations will go where they are most needed.

If you have any further questions feel free to email me at: bryn.tustin1@gmail.com

story:
Say Mazal Tov in Sign Language!

What will the money be used for?

To buy gifts for 55 very special Deaf and hearing impaired children young adults who will be celebrating their Bar/Bat Mitzvah in a unique ceremony in Jerusalem.

From Haifa and Tiberias in the North through to Beersheva in the South they are coming together to celebrate their special day.

You can partake in this unique celebration by contributing towards the event and the gifts they will be receiving. We are so close to the finish line in terms of date and funding but we need another $6000 to go all the way. There are 55 reasons you should contribute to this campaign….




Who Are We?

International Young Israel Movement - Israel Region is a non proft organization based in Jerusalem that runs many social welfare projects in Israel. One of these projects is running activities for Deaf & Hearing Impaired Children.



Our Event in the Press in 2013:

Saying Mazal Tov in Sign Language: http://www.jewishpress.com/news/breaking-news/saying-mazal-tov-in-sign-language/2013/12/11/

Bar Mitzvot for the Deaf: http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/anglo-file/1.563430

http://5tjt.com/saying-mazal-tov-in-sign-language/

Sign of the Inclusive Times: http://www.thejewishweek.com/features/lens/sign-inclusive-times

An Unforgettable day: http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Features/An-unforgettable-day-336209?

Putting the Mitzva in Bar Mitzva: http://www.jns.org/latest-articles/2014/1/6/put...

Putting More Mitzva into that Bar Mitzva: http://www.sdjewishworld.com/2014/01/07/putting-mitzvah-bar-mitzvah/

Putting the Mitzva in Bar Mitzva: http://www.algemeiner.com/2014/01/09/putting-th...

story:
Kia ora,

Mon nom est Arnaud Mouna Massin et je suis actuellement en troisième et dernière année de formation au Grandmothers Healing Haka Integral Learning Programme avec Waimaania et Ojasvin Davis qui en sont les fondateurs. C'est dans le cadre de cette formation que je prépare un voyage d'un mois à Aotearoa - Nouvelle-Zélande pour les y rejoindre (de début Janvier à début Février).

Personnellement, depuis que j'ai commencé ma formation, j'ai arrêté de fumer, j'ai retrouvé ma fille, je me suis marié à la femme que j'aime et une amitié que je croyais définitivement compromise est renée de ses cendres! En plus de ces changements majeurs, j'ai trouvé une famille aimante et puissante avec les autres danseurs de Haka (dont j'entraîne deux groupes une fois par mois), dont un certain nombre sont devenus de véritables amis.

Puisque c'est mon projet de vie, je m'efforce moi aussi sincèrement de me former et de me transformer afin d'éveiller le meilleur et le plus digne en moi et en chacun de nous, dans mon quotidien, lors de mes entraînements et par la suite lors de mes séminaires de Haka de Guérison de la Grand'Mère.

Sachez que j'organise aussi deux Introductions au Haka en Décembre (un après-midi près d'Uzès et une soirée près d'Annecy) pour financer ce voyage: http://www.grandmothershealinghaka.com/flyers/ Votre soutien réunirait la somme minimum nécessaire à payer mon billet d'avion (et le trajet jusqu'à l'aéroport de Paris) et quelques frais sur place. Je travaillerai là-bas une semaine sur un chantier pour payer le tour organisé par mes professeurs et rencontrer le peuple Maori: http://www.grandmothershealinghaka.com/tour-2016/arotahi-tour-details-fr-2016/

Puissé-je, grâce à votre soutien, arriver jusqu'à Aotearoa, le "pays de la lumière éternellement radiante", pour y goûter à la source, recevoir la bénédiction des Anciens et complèter ma formation!

Arohanui (plein d'amour),

Arnaud Mouna

story:
Important Update: our event has been postponed to May 2015 due to unforeseen conditions. We will launch a 2nd fundraising campaign when we have all details finalized. Thank you for your continued support! 

Purchase a Valentine Videogram and help us feed 1000 kids at the Happyland slum-village community

Here's the skinny:

  • Purchase a Videogram for your Valentine ($20 for a standard video greeting and $50 for a custom one)
  • Funds raised will go to towards our mass feed for 1,000 kids at the Happyland slum-village community on February 14th, 2015 (yup, Valentine's day!)
  • Funds raised in excess of $1,000 will be used for (a) employing a local member from the same slum community, and (b) helping us establish an "Operation Inspiration" computer workstation in the slum community.


About Happyland

Happyland is a slum-village community in Metro Manila which is home to more than 7,000 people.  The majority make a living by doing various work in the nearby port, scavenging and doing odd jobs.  As you can see from our photo-gallery:  health, sanitation and lack of stable jobs are big issues in the community. Tuberculosis and undernourishment are widespread problems in the area, as most can't afford basic meals and medication.

story:
On location

What you see in the picture above is the site of Santiago Christian School's new building. Construction started in April of this year and once finished, the building will consist of several classrooms and offices, as well as a brand new and modern Science Lab!

Please consider making a donation in part as a token of gratitude to all the years of service (26!) Mr. Boyd has given to the school and also as a thank you to the school itself for shaping the lives of students/alumni, the community and every person that in one way or another has been involved with it throughout the years.


Your donation will go to the actual construction of the lab walls. If the campaign goal is met, additional funds will be used towards the lab's equipment so all donations to this campaign are strictly for Mr. Boyd's lab.


About the campaign

The "Buy a Block" campaign launched at the beginning of this year at Santiago Christian School. It has received tremendous support from families and students and now the campaign is online so that more people can be a part of it!

Every "block" that you donate will be matched and doubled thanks to a very generous donor in the United States who has been donating to the school based on the matching challenge. 


Other ways to donate

If you prefer to donate with a check you may do so by mailing it to:

Santiago Christian School Foundation
1016 Scenic View Dr
Schwenksville, PA 19473


Want to help but can't donate?

Wonderful! You may share our campaign link with friends through social media: http://igg.me/at/scsdevelopment

Spread the word out because wonderful things are happening at SCS and we want to share this with everyone at Santiago and around the world!

If you want to know more about our school, follow the links below and also see pictures and video in the Gallery.

story:
#ProudGeeks, we  did it! With your help we  reached 105% of our campaign goal!! Thank you for mobilizing, sharing, and contributing. 

Our 501c3 mission at Geek Club Books is both autism education and empowerment through storytelling. We tell our own family's stories via our autism story apps and give opportunities for others on the autism spectrum to tell theirs.

Our fans & funders are #ProudGeek for our mission...

A few of our fans and funders are showing their #ProudGeek to encourage others to support our unique autism advocacy, education and empowerment through storytelling and creative self-expression.

Our story starts with a boy...

He looks like any other boy but his brain is wired differently. He is autistic. And the kids at school? They think he's weird so they bully and isolate him.

This was my son's story but it's a universal experience when you are autistic. And when 1 in 68 children are on the autism spectrum, and over 70% say they are bullied in school, we must do a better job of educating all children about autism and making those who are autistic feel included and valued.

The story arc of my son's life is a happy one…He’s thrived when we found welcoming communities who accepted him for him…and when he has meaningful work from using his talents.

So I had this creative brainstorm of an idea...

What if we use technology to engage and tell real stories from his youth to entertain children while educating them about autism. Research shows that narrative has a powerful impact on the brain, so let's use our autism stories to elicit empathy and affect change...

And ta-da! We made our first story app...

The Mighty League, Vol. 1: The Terrible Taunting, an interactive comic book, is the tale of an autistic boy (or girl – because the reader can choose the gender) on his (or her) superhero quest to stop bullying on the playground.  And the story is inspired by my son's real life experiences. 

The kids, parents and reviewers responded...  

Now here's where you enter the story...

We're ready to make the next autism story app, the Mighty League, Vol. 2: The Horrible Hug and we need your help to do it! 

In our apps, the reader gets to choose the gender of the main character.

From superhero in our last app to Starship Captain, JMan (or Jaycee depending upon the reader's choice) embark on a journey to an alien planet...a brand new school...an overwhelming, fear-of-the-unknown experience for any child...amplified when you are on the autism spectrum.

But the captain of the U.S.S. Mighty League soon discovers that these alien's "horrible hugs" are welcoming and a sign of acceptance. And once again, this tale comes straight from my son's past.

Hear him talk about the huge impact the horrible hugs made on his life:

Join us on our mission...

I realized after the positive response from our first app, that our creative approach to autism awareness and education can make a difference. In April 2014, Geek Club Books, autism storytellers of hope became a 501(c)3 nonprofit!

Your support  for this project means that we can produce an autism story app that will:

  • Give children on the autism spectrum characters they can identify with
  • Educate their peers, teachers, siblings and caregivers for greater understanding 
  • Spark discussions about differences and acceptance    

Stories engage. Stories connect. And our autism stories are making a positive impact. Together, we can profoundly change the way the world views autism…one story at a time.

FOR MORE INFO ABOUT US GRAB THIS PDF

And the money goes to...

Our goal is to raise enough money to fund the development of the Horrible Hug story app to continue our autism awareness, acceptance and empowerment programs. Our expenses include:

  • Writing Fees - $250
  • Illustrations & Animations - $3,500
  • Audio (Engineering, Voice Over, Music, Sound Effects) $1,000
  • App development - $2,000
  • Fees and perk fulfillment - $1,250

Once the app is complete we will use it for our autism outreach and education as well as sell it on iTunes, Amazon and Google Play. We are a 501c3 so all proceeds from app sales will go to further fund our autism mission. 

If we exceed our goal there is so much more that we can do right away, including:

  • Companion Common Core curriculum
  • Expansion of our Penfriend Project: A monthly byline for YA autistic writers 
  • Companion printed comic book version of the app with classroom/reader discussion questions
  • Marketing and PR support

If we do not reach our entire funding goal, we will still produce an awesome story app but will remove some of its special features and interactivity. 


    Be an app star is sold out!

    They support our mission...
     

    The Puzzling Piece raises money for autism organizations and gives away iPads for autism families. 

    Risks & Challenges

    As with any app development or creative project, there is the risk of delays in the production but we've already created an autism story app using the same platform and team. There were surprisingly no major issues so we do not anticipate any with this app. 

    Any perks that would be impacted by a production delay will simply be postponed and rescheduled once the app is complete. Our contributers will be kept apprised of our progress and timeline throughout the entire process.

    Become part of our galactic crew!

    As Carl Sagan said, "the universe is a pretty big place" so the only way we can land the U.S.S. Mighty League and make it into a story app is with your support. Help us spread the word about Geek Club Books mission and this INDIEGOGO campaign. 

    Here are a few geekish tweets to get you started:

    Horrible hugs can squeeze out new understanding for autism http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app

    Engage! like a starship captain for an autism story of hope http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app

    Changing how the world views autism, one story at a time http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app

    Mighty League app stories are mighty powerful for autism acceptance http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app 

    If you tag us @geekclubbooks we'll make sure to RT our TYVM!

    Here's a proud funder badge we hope you'll be proud to display...

    Get the code for the badge + more shareable stuff!

The Puzzling Piece raises money for autism organizations and gives away iPads for autism families. 

Risks & Challenges

  
As with any app development or creative project, there is the risk of delays in the production but we've already created an autism story app using the same platform and team. There were surprisingly no major issues so we do not anticipate any with this app. 
Any perks that would be impacted by a production delay will simply be postponed and rescheduled once the app is complete. Our contributers will be kept apprised of our progress and timeline throughout the entire process.
  Become part of our galactic crew! As Carl Sagan said, "the universe is a pretty big place" so the only way we can land the U.S.S. Mighty League and make it into a story app is with your support. Help us spread the word about Geek Club Books mission and this INDIEGOGO campaign. 
Here are a few geekish tweets to get you started:
Horrible hugs can squeeze out new understanding for autism http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app
Engage! like a starship captain for an autism story of hope http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app
Changing how the world views autism, one story at a time http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app
Mighty League app stories are mighty powerful for autism acceptance http://igg.me/at/autism-story-app 
If you tag us @geekclubbooks we'll make sure to RT our TYVM!
Here's a proud funder badge we hope you'll be proud to display...


Get the code for the badge + more shareable stuff!

story:
For the 2014/2015 school year, Perkerson 5th graders are creating 2 music videos, while learning design thinking, coding, animation, storytelling, filming, and editing with the ultimate goal of uniting South Atlanta youth through the arts and technology.

The money raised will pay for our lead videographer, post-production specialist, two facilitators, two used video cameras, and decorations for our final red carpet event from October 2014 until May 2015

story:
College tuition can build up to an insane amount, especially when it comes to private schools, I'm currently attending one in L.A. and am in serious need of money to cover the tuition expenses. However, I'm unable to carry out my own student loans and do not have any eligible co-signers to assist me. Therefore, I'm doing all I can to keep myself and my education in the heart of Hollywood. 

What this means is that instead of being a full-time student embarking on the 2nd semester, I have cut back on classes and am committing the next three months to my new job as a hostess and establishing credit so that I can eventually be approved for my own loans. I am only eighteen years old (I moved out when I was still seventeen) and adjusting to the 'real' world has been quite a journey so far. While I understand that I am not as privileged as others, I would like to recognize that I have been blessed with so many great opportunities before my post-secondary education/career: I've happily performed over 400 hours of community service in the last 4 years, I worked with special needs kids in the area to help further their social skills for 2 years (Forever Friends), I completed my sixth year of volunteering for the MSMS Smart Peas by assisting agricultural/ student garden sales, I was accepted to a summer arts program whose applicants range from at least 5000 around the world and whose selected students were around 370 in total, I was co-editor for my high school's yearbook and a literary magazine, I was accepted to AMDA, whose acceptance rate was less than 30% during the year I applied, I personally feel I've improved in being a responsible role model/sibling for my younger sister with autism and I've been very open with my parent and grandparents to foster a healthier relationship with one another - so much has happened, I felt more than determined and empowered to make the big decision to move where I have the most opportunity to discover and refine my passions to turn them into useful skills for a career. 

The road hasn't been easy, but I am putting my best thoughts forward and all my efforts into staying low in debt - and yes, that's right. Up until now, I have managed to not* exceed $5,000 in debt (due to federal loans) at a $40,000 college. How? My high school GPA, the FAFSA, CalGrant, AMDA First Year Merit/ VIP Scholarship(s), and other online scholarships have made it possible for me to attend my college. Also, the generosity of my former teachers, my grandmothers, my tias, my mother, and a middle school full of bright and promising students allowed me to fundraise money for the means to help with the first tuition payments. However, as I am only a part-time worker away from home, I no longer have the means to locally raise like I used to. My family is hard working, and it wouldn't be fair of me to rely entirely upon them for my education. I need help, and this Indiegogo campaign (and you, even just by reading this) are giving me a chance!!!

Donations of any amount are appreciated. And to make this a bit more interesting and interactive . . . 

With this campaign, each donor can leave a comment on the campaign's page and make a request to 'travel' and 'explore' to any location in the Los Angeles area. I will scout the destination and once there, will take a picture to show you that the mission has been accomplished (virtual travelling, yay!) I will also record a video of myself doing whatever task you request me to do. As long as it's legal, it's doable! 

It means the world to be able to continue learning here and pursue my dreams, and I hope that you are able to help. Anything brings me one step closer, so in advance... thank you so much for your time and consideration!!! :)

story:
Hi there! I'm Bernardo, the EMBO (evil mind behind the operation) of BLUErabbit. With the help of Roberto and Adrian we are looking to transform education environments into places where it's FUN and ENGAGING to learn.
BLUErabbit is a platform that motivates students (players) as they grow better through their education, takes stress away from grades and focuses on learning.

We want to transform education for ONE MILLION students in our first year.

The goal of BLUErabbit is to improve classes and training for everybody. Most of us had a very standard and boring education. With our platform we want to empower teachers into making their classes something students will always remember as fun and the learning happens naturally instead of a competition against the grades.

We want to erradicate the industrialized education from the beginning of the past century (YES! The methodology is over 100 years old!)

Education is the only element of the equation that breaks through political, economical, environmental, religious, non-religious, health or any kind of problem.

We are looking for funding a whole year of operation and development.

  • We are looking for $130,000 USD
  • The funds will be used completely for the operation of BLUErabbit 1 and the development of BLUErabbit 2.
  • The first thing the funds will cover is the operational cost for the next year. This includes servers, maintenance and documentation development.
  • The second thing the funds will cover will be the development costs for taking BLUErabbit into level 2. This includes three salaries, licensing, rent and the cost of the development  like internet costs and electricity. The development will include the creation of an APP and a lot more connectivity. 
  • The third thing the funds will cover is to develop online courses on how to use game mechanics in the classroom and generate community along with all the documentation (it's a LOT of content) so teachers can create better experiences.
  • The fourth thing the funds will cover is the development of expansion packs.
  • If you buy our UNIQUE PERKS, they guarantee the operation of BLUErabbit for 5 years!
  • If we are unable to get all the funds, we will fulfill our promise to all teachers and their scholarshipped. The funds guarantee a whole year of operation for 3000 teachers, but the cost increments as the accounts increment, so each perk has it's annual cost calculated and you will receive the service you pay for!

You will get a full BLUErabbit account at a discount price. All our perks offer from 25% to 75% discount prices.

  • You will also lock down the cost of any additional months at $15 USD for as long as the offered price is higher (if we are able to lower our prices, you will always pay the lowest available fee)
  • Access to our webinars for the first three months. We will be running webinars to help you set everything up and how to create
  • Exclusive passes and discounts to our gamification of education online courses!
  • For every month covered on every perk, ONE BLOO MONTH will be awarded. Some perks offer more BLOO MONTHS than others
  • BLOO MONTHS are used to grant teachers and schools who can't afford BLUErabbit, access to the system for two years.
  • All accounts will be available the following work day after the campaign has ended.

The way education is taught right now is absolutely obsolete. Schools keep following the system because "it works" and "students are happy". However, more and more we are seeing people that quit school because it doesn't fulfill their knowledge needs and they end up developing their skills into massive complexity without an institution that tells them when or how to study.

What we plan to focus on is precisely this traditional way of teaching and transform it into something that completely evolves the classroom. There is no need for walls, chairs or tables, except for specific activities. BLUErabbit wants to break the barriers, empower the teacher and students to destroy this obsolete form of education by connecting teachers and students at a very different level

  • By leveraging on game mechanics, BLUErabbit identifies what motivates each student by their playing preference. This way we motivate the right way and work towards a more intrinsic motivation and take the focus away from the grades
  • We believe that every teacher can turn the tables on education. Not the schools. Schools are organizations that are hard to transform as a whole, but if each teacher changes their system into something more fun, more practical and more engaging, then education itself will evolve.
  • We've already tested our system with 420 students and the engagement went up to 300%. Teachers could identify their students' weakness and were able to help the through their study.
Some of the obstacles we've found is trying to introduce the whole system to a school. The problem is that the school already has a system they don't want to change because it involves too many people making the decision.
BLUErabbit doesn't try to get in the way of any school system. This is a CLASS system. It's not intended to replace the teacher at any point and it doesn't enforce a specific path or set of assignments. The teacher will be able to build the content as he always has, but with the system she will be able to create an environment where students can fail and retry without feeling that they only have one chance. 
We will offer live webinars for teaching skills that will help the teachers learn better techniques to use in the classroom. We will offer scholarships to the ones who demonstrate commitment to education. We will change the way classes are taught by helping the only ones who can make a difference in the planet: the teachers.
128 Million kids don't have access to education but, on the other hand, there is NO statistic on how many students are actually enjoying their school. People take their kids to school so they can keep up working. They aren't as involved in their education as needed.
As a teacher in Mexico city, I overheard two girls last semester bragging that they had 156 absences between all their classes combined. Then her best friend countered by saying she had 172. That made me really angry. They attend the most expensive school in the country and they were proud of having missed so many classes while the people in the cafeteria and myself weren't EVER able to have this level of education.
But then, why weren't they in class? It's not just about their lack of maturity. The classroom wasn't offering them anything interesting enough so they wouldn't want to miss it.
We want to change this by changing the class system. Bleeding through your life because you missed a grade in lower school is NOT FAIR. Education is a privilege. Having boring classes and unengaged students is a waste of this privilege.
Our team is built around different unique skills that complement each other.
Adrian has been working for the education market for the past 7 years. He is our Chief Commercial Officer.
Roberto's skills are built specifically to acquire users. That's what he has been doing for the past 6 years and is AWESOME at his job. He is our Chief of User Acquisition.
Mony is one of the best finance graduates in the history of her university and is working as Mass Marketing Manager in Insurance Business. She is our Chief Financial Officer.
I am a passionate teacher who loves videogames. I have been studying and developing BLUErabbit based on the theories of over 20 authors and have been working as a teacher for the past 8 years. (I also built the whole thing :D)

If you can't contribute with any perk, please help us get the word out! We really want to change the world for anyone who is studying.

Use the indiegogo share tools, that way anyone who sees it will be able to com back to this page.

We believe BLUErabbit is the way for turning education into an amazing experience without asking the teachers to reconstruct everything.

Remember that life is a game. Let's play!

story:
My Story

I am riding at a Flywheel spin class for 45 minutes to help raise funds for Breast Treatment Task Force, a local non-profit that provides free breast cancer screening and treatment to uninsured men and women above the poverty level that would otherwise have to bankrupt themselves to afford care.  You can learn more about BTTF at www.breasttreatment.org.

Ways you Can Help Me Exceed My Goal of Raising $1000

I have already donated $500, and some friends have already signed up to spin with me or made donations. So seriously, I am just a hop skip and a jump away! You can donate to this great cause by:

A. spinning with me and committing to raise at least $150 Or 
B. you can donate any increment to my campaign 

Who is on my team already?

Sharon Mahn, Jen Kim, Courtney Gaylor, Kris Maccini, and Lauren Asch are on my team and spinning for BTTF. 

Thanks everyone!

story:
Hello! My name is Sally and I recently graduated with a Master of International Affairs from The Pennsylvania State University. I also have a BA in Political Science (Honors) from the University of California.

Learning is a never ending process for me. I like to learn about and analyze every topic in varying perspectives, whether I agree with them or not, because this process makes me a better informed citizen. This is greatly important to me, especially because I'm interested in U.S. Public Policy and ways that citizens can make a difference locally in their communities, nationally, and even globally! I'm currently exploring careers in public policy (including foreign policy) and this seminar experience will help me learn about perspectives and issues that affect public policy and that I might not have thought about or considered before.

Attending this week long seminar put together by Institute for Humane Studies at George Mason University, I would meet students from across the U.S. to dig deeper into issues relating to economics, morality, and freedom in U.S. Public Policy discussions. 

Each day of the week long seminar will typically consist of 3 lectures and 4 discussions. The Summer Seminars typically receive over 2000 applications for a total of 700 seats and this year, I was selected through a rigorous process (that included essays!!!) to attend one of the seminars!

The tuition, books, food, & board are all covered by George Mason University. I just need to get there!

Your contribution today, would go towards my transportation costs and make it possible for me to attend the seminar, which will be hosted at Wake Forest University in North Carolina in mid-June.

Please help me attend by donating whatever you can! Any contribution would be much appreciated. 

Thank you!!!

Sincerely,

      Sally 

 

PS: Even if you can't contribute today, please consider sharing this link with a friend.
