I am a college student studying Physics and European Studies. It is my ultimate dream to work at NASA someday. I currently write a science education blog at downhereonearth.wordpress.com. I've been getting some fabulous opportunities through that blog, but sadly I can't afford to take advantage of some of them them.
I've been given an opportunity.
I’m among 15 people who have just gotten selected to go to a NASA event at the Ames Research Center in California this Friday, the 26th. The event is essentially a test for some new rover robotics, along with some other lectures and networking. It’d be a great step for my career and my personal validation. 
However, last-minute flights from Chicago to California are expensive - the event was announced last week, I was selected yesterday, I have to confirm my attendance in 2 days, and the event is in 6 days. Everything is very last-minute and so much more expensive. 
Please help me grasp that opportunity.
I just spent all my expendable money going to a NASA event in Houston that I was also selected for (either I have excellent luck or the people at NASA like me – I’m pretty happy with those options). It was amazing - maybe even life-changing, and if you know me you know that I'm not prone to exaggeration. It was a big deal, and doing it again would be another big deal.
The only way I can get to this event in California is with some help paying for transportation - even the Greyhound bus is crazy expensive and takes several days, and the very cheapest flight I could find is $740 roundtrip. If I can raise $500, I can afford to go. If I can raise more than $600, I can afford to go and not stay in a sketchy motel. In the chance that I get any additional money past what the trip will cost, it would go towards other physics events where I can learn and network (like this one - I really want to go to that one). 
You would have my eternal gratitude, and would be helping an aspiring young woman in physics grow a career.
I wouldn’t ask, but I’m desperate. I’m a college student and I simply can’t afford to be spending that kind of money twice in two weeks – but I really really want to go to this event, and I feel it’s the next step towards realizing my dream.
Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
What is FEP?

The Food Education Project’s mission is to improve community health by teaching practices through environmental awareness.

At The Food Education Project, we believe health begins at home and is emphasized at school. We have developed a curriculum that children and families will learn about four basic components: 

  • Health - diabetes I and II with our nurses, heart disease, and much more!  
  • Nutrition  - sugar intake, obesity, metabolism, government standards, dietary needs
  • Food - conventional vs unconventional fruits/veggies, knife skills, tastings, demos
  • Environment - global warming, recycle/compost, growth, soil test and much more!

Altogether, we bring the student a more extensive look at the body and our practices incorporate learning topics such as vitamins, seasonal foods and farming, health practices, and physical and environmental impact. Without knowing how food is grown, we will never understand how it impacts our health and wellness. Our program curriculum leaves its imprint in public and private schools, bringing a comprehensive program to the Bay area. 

Our organization is comprised of clinicians and educators that are currently working in the San Francisco/Bay Area community.  Using integrative methods, we work with students, educating them on the latest health and nutrition information. We encourage individuals to learn more about their local area, introducing them to urban gardening, and teaching an unforgettable experience.

In 2013, our graduate level Internship program from the Master of Public Health department at The University of San Francisco was launched and offers services with students, connecting as a public health community based intervention for graduation requirements. Our team efforts have brought in over five interns to graduate, influencing more than 400 FEP (Food Education Project) students in the classroom! Go Team!


Why should you support FEP?

Childhood obesity is one of the largest public health problems that exist today in the United States.  As the mentality of, ‘faster is better’, increases, the rates of obesity have increased as well.  Obesity leads to all sorts of diseases, such as diabetes, orthopedic difficulties, and cardiac dysfunctions.  However, the more detrimental and depressing part of this major issue is that young children are experiencing these negative, life-threatening effects early on.

According to a study on the relationship between birth weight and rapid weight gain:

  • 15% of preschool children are obese and 16% are overweight.
  • Children are over 9 times more likely to be obese and 31 times more likely to be extremely obese during early childhood if they experienced rapid weight gain between birth and 1 year of age.

Children who are placed in an environment that increases the likelihood of rapid weight gain, are more likely to continue to gain excessive weight and become obese during preschool years when staying in that similar environment.   

Currently nationwide, according to the Centers for Disease Control, an estimated 32% of American children between the ages of 2 to 19 are overweight, and 17% of those children are obese. Children are experiencing adult-onset diet-related medical issues at an early age because of various reasons.Overall, there are many factors that lead to children being overweight and obese, but the two main factors include diet and exercise.  Children are not eating the healthy foods needed to supply their body adequately, and are also eating too much unhealthy food.  In addition, they lack enough physical activity in their daily lives.   

Children are growing up in unhealthy environments that trap them in a world of electronics, fast foods, junk foods, and sedentary lifestyles.  They spend a majority of their time in schools, and currently, the school health education programs are inadequate.  In comparison to the importance placed on academic subjects, there is very little value placed on health education.  Physical education and health class has been significantly reduced or even eliminated in many public schools throughout California.


What will FEP do with the funds?

  1. Implement our health curriculum in more schools in San Francisco.
  2. Complete and create more organic edible gardens at each of the school campuses.
  3. Obtain more gardening tools, machines, and equipment.
  4. Purchase garden sheds schoolyards. 
  5. Purchase organic plants, fruits, and vegetables for food tasting, food demos, and planting in student, peer-driven gardens.


What is the impact of FEP?

FEP was founded 2 years ago and is continuously growing.  At the moment, the organization’s health education program is implemented in three schools located in San Francisco: Daniel Webster, Mckinley Elementary Schools, and Immaculate Conception Academy.  Currently, our health curriculum is integrated both in in-school and after-school programs for grades 1-9.  FEP impacts over 900 students and families and by the end of 2014, FEP plans to bring on 2 additional schools, which will increase this number of impacted individuals to 1,500.  Our program evaluation is on-going and has thus far initiated responses on how students choose what to eat, how it affects their health, and what options they have in order to achieve a healthier lifestyle through the program. We reach out to parents, students, and staff during our 4 year study, supported by The University of San Francisco's Master of Public Health program.


Other ways you can help?

Help spread the word about The Food Education Project!

  • Website: www.foodedproject.com
  • Facebook: The Food Education Project
  • Instagram: thefoodeducationproject

story:
A bit about Supersiblings:

What makes you a Supersibling? Supersiblings are siblings of people with autism who have lots of special characteristics attributed to growing up in a family with someone with autism.
 
You might be a supersibling if you...
  • have a desire to be perfect at everything you do 
  • are very protective of and loyal to others, especially your siblings 
  • go out of your way not to inconvenience others 
  • are more independent and mature than most people your age 
  • have a nurturing personality 
  • are used to hiding your feelings for the sake of others 
  • are very intuitive and are very aware of what others around you are feeling 
  • are extremely empathetic, sometimes to your detriment 
  • tend to be very patient and tolerant of others 
  • can easily step into a leadership position 
Is this starting to sound familiar? :)
 
This is NOT to say that we don't face a lot of challenges that others don't have to face-- we deal with denial of feelings, lack of attention from your family, lack of praise and positive reinforcement, jealousy, embarrassment, feeling alone, being suuuuper frustrated, being extra sensitive to many things, not having a "normal" family life or a "normal" growing up experience, etc, etc, etc!
 
We Supersibs do not have the kind of support, resources, or acknowledgement that
we deserve.

We are overlooked.

We are also awesome, extremely valuable people that have many special gifts and traits that others do not.

I am here to EMPOWER you use those gifts to become as successful as
possible in whatever way that means to you. You deserve to spread your
awesome-ness to the rest of the world!

Siblings of children with autism are seriously underserviced and underrepresented. My goal with Supersiblings is to change that!

 

Going to the Walk for Autism with Autism Speaks:

As of now, Supersiblings is mainly my blog and my Twitter account where I connect with and write about siblings and sibling issues. By attending the Autism Walk and having a booth to represent myself, I can advocate for siblings, spread awareness, and begin a local meet-up group for these siblings, as well as start a mentorship program for adult siblings to mentor younger siblings. To go to the Walk will mean more exposure and more connections to make these projects possible!

The registration fee itself is $375, and the remaining money will go towards creating brochures, take-home information, and an autism-friendly activicty for the booth.

By donating at least $50, I am MORE than happy to print and disperse flyers or info sheets for your organization!

 

I would highly appreciate any support to help make this amazing organization take this huge step! I certainly can't do it without you! :)

story:
Le texte français suit le texte anglais.

Who we are

The McGill Racing Team is a team of undergraduate students from McGill University in Montreal, Canada. Every year we design a formula-style prototype race car to compete in the prestigious Formula SAE competitions throughout the summer.

Formula SAE/Student is an engineering design competition targeted towards university students studying engineering, with the goal to provide students with a hands-on project to apply the skills and knowledge they are taught in their courses. Students are required to take on all aspects of the project, including: Design, Manufacturing, Testing and Maintenance, Finance and Sponsorship, and of course Project Management. "The concept behind Formula SAE is that a fictional manufacturing company has contracted a design team to develop a small Formula-style race car. The prototype race car is to be evaluated for its potential as a production item. The target marketing group for the race car is the non-professional weekend autocross racer. Each student team designs, builds and tests a prototype based on a series of rules whose purpose is both to ensure onsite event operations and promote clever problem solving" (sae.org).

This past year, the McGill Racing Team had one of the most successful seasons in its history, finishing as the best Canadian team at FSAE Lincoln by winning skidpad and achieving a 7th place finish in the Design event. At Formula North, the team was able to take 3rd in Design and 11th Overall. The McGill Racing Team also went overseas for the first time in its history, competing at the world’s most competitive and professional competition, Formula Student Germany, and took home 4th in Design and 14th Overall.

What we need

In order to sustain our success at the highest level, we constantly need to innovate and improve our vehicle. This year, reducing weight is the most significant way we can enhance our car's performance.

For the past 15 years, our vehicles have been designed around steel space-frame chassis. Despite being a proven method, the fact that they are made with steel means they are, inevitably, quite heavy. This year we are taking a big step in developing a carbon fibre monocoque to replace the steel frame. The new chassis will be stronger and stiffer than the steel alternative, while weighing significantly less.

Needless to say, designing and manufacturing a carbon fibre chassis is not an easy task. The design process begins on the computer, where the shape is modeled and the areas requiring stiffness and strength are determined. Once the design has been finalized, the manufacturing phase begins by constructing two moulds, one for each half of the chassis, machined from a special type of composites tooling board. It is within these moulds that one then begins the lay-up procedure, where layers of epoxy pre-impregnated carbon fibre and honeycomb core are placed in precisely determined locations. Finally, these moulds, along with the finished lay-up are placed in a special high-pressure oven known as an autoclave. This last step ensures that all the layers are well bonded using the epoxy resin contained within the carbon fibre pre-preg.

Unfortunately, the manufacturing process for a large composite part like our chassis is still a fairly expensive endeavour, as our cost break-down shows. Thankfully, the labour of a team of university students is free, but we need your help to ensure we can cover the external costs that cannot be covered through direct sponsorship. Be a part of our team's success and donate today!

Also, check out our perks and get specialized McGill Racing Team rewards!

Impact

This project is an excellent learning experience for young university students today, and will help ensure there will be highly talented people entering the workforce of tomorrow. Likewise, composites are quickly becoming the engineering materials of choice and it is crucial that the engineers of the future have an excellent understanding of their unique properties and how they can be employed to build more efficient structures and vehicles.

Other Ways You Can Help

Our team is always looking to get involved in the community. Feel free to get in touch with us through Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, or our web page. Tell your friends about us and help us create a lighter, faster, and more efficient vehicle.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Qui sommes-nous?

Le McGill Racing Team est une équipe constituée d’étudiants au baccalauréat de l’Université McGill à Montréal (Canada). Chaque année, nous créons un véhicule de course prototype, inspiré de la formule 1, avec lequel nous participons à de prestigieuses compétitions de Formule SAE durant l’été.

La Formule SAE/Student est une compétition d’ingénierie visant les étudiants de génie voulant s’engager dans un projet de conception dans lequel ils peuvent appliquer concrètement ce qu’ils apprennent en classe. Les étudiants doivent se charger de tous les aspects du projet: de l’élaboration du modèle, à la manufacture des pièces, des tests et analyses sur piste à l’entretien, du financement à la gestion du projet dans son ensemble. En fait, la Formule SAE est basée sur le concept d’une compagnie fictive voulant engager une équipe de conception pour mettre au point une petite voiture de course inspirée de la Formule 1. Le prototype de l’équipe voit donc son potentiel pour la chaîne de production se faire évaluer en détail. Le groupe d’acheteurs potentiels ciblé consiste de chauffeurs d’autocross récréatif. Chaque équipe participant à la compétition doit concevoir, construire et tester un prototype automobile correspondant à une série de règlements visant à assurer le bon déroulement de la course et à encourager l’ingéniosité dans la résolution de problèmes (sae.org).

L’année dernière, la McGill Racing Team a connu une des ses saisons les plus fructueuses de son histoire en remportant le titre de la meilleure équipe canadienne à la compétition FSAE Lincoln: l’équipe est arrivée première au classement pour le skidpad et septième pour l’épreuve évaluant la conception. À la compétition Formula North, l’équipe est parvenue à obtenir la troisième position pour la conception lui assurant donc une onzième place au cumulatif. La McGill Racing Team s’est aussi aventurée de l’autre côté de l’océan Atlantique pour la première fois afin de participer à la course de Formula SAE la plus compétitive et professionnelle au monde, l’évènement Formula Student Germany (Allemagne). L’équipe est revenue au Canada avec une quatrième position en conception et une impressionnante quatorzième place au classement général!

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Afin de conserver notre niveau de succès à son maximum, nous devons constamment innover pour améliorer notre véhicule. Cette année, nous visons la réduction du poids de notre voiture, un élément très significatif pour la performance du véhicule.

Pendant les quinze dernières années, nos véhicules ont été conçus avec un châssis d’acier. Bien que cette technique se soit montrée efficace, la composante d’acier rendait inévitablement les voitures plutôt lourdes. Cette année, nous faisons un grand pas en introduisant un monocoque en fibres de carbone pour remplacer le squelette en acier. Par conséquent, le nouveau châssis sera plus fort et résistant en plus d’être beaucoup plus léger.

Évidemment, la conception et la manufacture d’un châssis en fibres de carbone est loin d’être une tâche facile. La conception débute sur un ordinateur alors que la forme est modelée et que la rigidité des différentes sections est déterminée. Une fois cette étape achevée, la manufacture commence: deux moules, un pour chaque moitié du châssis, sont construits en utilisant un type spécial de panneau pour matériaux composites. Les moules sont ensuite recouverts, couche après couche, de fibres de carbone imprégnées de colle époxy et de matériau à structure alvéolaire à des endroits précis. Finalement, on place les moules dans des fours spéciaux pressurisés appelés autoclaves. Cette dernière étape assure que les différentes couches ont bien adhéré les unes aux autres grâce à la résine d’époxy. 

Malheureusement, la manufacture d’une grosse pièce telle que notre châssis est dispendieuse, comme le montre notre budget. Bien que le travail des étudiants universitaires soit volontaire et non-rémunéré, nous avons tout de même besoin de vos dons pour régler les coûts externes ne pouvant être pris en charge par nos commanditaires directs. Contribuez au succès de notre équipe en donnant aujourd’hui!

Cliquez sur nos Perks et recevez un cadeau McGill Racing Team en échange de votre contribution!

Votre impact

Ce projet représente une expérience d’apprentissage incroyable pour les jeunes étudiants universitaires en plus d’assurer que les ingénieurs de demain seront hautement qualifiés et talentueux. En plus, les matériaux composites sont de plus en plus utilisés en raison de leurs propriétés uniques et il est crucial que les futurs ingénieurs en aient une connaissance excellente pour construire de meilleures structures et véhicules.

D’autres façons de nous aider

McGill Racing Team tente constamment de s’impliquer davantage dans la communauté. Libre à vous de nous contacter via nos comptes Facebook, Twitter et YouTube, ou via notre site web. Parlez de nous à votre entourage et aidez-nous à créer une voiture de course plus légère, plus puissante, et plus rapide!

It is within these moulds that one then begins the lay-up procedure, where layers of epoxy pre-impregnated carbon fibre and honeycomb core are placed in precisely determined locations. Finally, these moulds, along with the finished lay-up are placed in a special high-pressure oven known as an autoclave. This last step ensures that all the layers are well bonded using the epoxy resin contained within the carbon fibre pre-preg.
Unfortunately, the manufacturing process for a large composite part like our chassis is still a fairly expensive endeavour, as our cost break-down shows. Thankfully, the labour of a team of university students is free, but we need your help to ensure we can cover the external costs that cannot be covered through direct sponsorship. Be a part of our team's success and donate today!
Also, check out our perks and get specialized McGill Racing Team
rewards!
Impact

This project is an excellent learning experience for young university students today, and will help ensure there will be highly talented people entering the workforce of tomorrow. Likewise, composites are quickly becoming the engineering materials of choice and it is crucial that the engineers of the future have an excellent understanding of their unique properties and how they can be employed to build more efficient structures and vehicles.

Other
Ways You Can Help

Our team is always looking to get involved in the
community. Feel free to get in touch with us through Facebook, Twitter, YouTube,
or our web page. Tell your friends about us and help us create a lighter,
faster, and more efficient vehicle.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Qui sommes-nous?
Le McGill Racing Team est une équipe constituée
d’étudiants au baccalauréat de l’Université McGill à Montréal (Canada). Chaque
année, nous créons un véhicule de course prototype, inspiré de la formule 1,
avec lequel nous participons à de prestigieuses compétitions de Formule SAE
durant l’été. 
La Formule SAE/Student est une compétition d’ingénierie
visant les étudiants de génie voulant s’engager dans un projet de conception
dans lequel ils peuvent appliquer concrètement ce qu’ils apprennent en classe.
Les étudiants doivent se charger de tous les aspects du projet: de
l’élaboration du modèle, à la manufacture des pièces, des tests et analyses sur
piste à l’entretien, du financement à la gestion du projet dans son ensemble.
En fait, la Formule SAE est basée sur le concept d’une compagnie fictive
voulant engager une équipe de conception pour mettre au point une petite
voiture de course inspirée de la Formule 1. Le prototype de l’équipe voit donc
son potentiel pour la chaîne de production se faire évaluer en détail. Le
groupe d’acheteurs potentiels ciblé consiste de chauffeurs d’autocross récréatif.
Chaque équipe participant à la compétition doit concevoir, construire et tester
un prototype automobile correspondant à une série de règlements visant à
assurer le bon déroulement de la course et à encourager l’ingéniosité dans la
résolution de problèmes (sae.org).
L’année dernière, la McGill Racing Team a connu une des
ses saisons les plus fructueuses de son histoire en remportant le titre de la
meilleure équipe canadienne à la compétition FSAE Lincoln: l’équipe est arrivée
première au classement pour le skidpad et septième pour l’épreuve évaluant la
conception. À la compétition Formula North, l’équipe est parvenue à obtenir la
troisième position pour la conception lui assurant donc une onzième place au cumulatif.
La McGill Racing Team s’est aussi aventurée de l’autre côté de l’océan Atlantique
pour la première fois afin de participer à la course de Formula SAE la plus
compétitive et professionnelle au monde, l’évènement Formula Student Germany
(Allemagne). L’équipe est revenue au Canada avec une quatrième position en
conception et une impressionnante quatorzième place au classement général!
Ce dont nous
avons besoin
Afin de conserver notre niveau de succès à son maximum,
nous devons constamment innover pour améliorer notre véhicule. Cette année,
nous visons la réduction du poids de notre voiture, un élément très
significatif pour la performance du véhicule. 
Pendant les quinze dernières années, nos véhicules ont
été conçus avec un châssis d’acier. Bien que cette technique se soit montrée efficace,
la composante d’acier rendait inévitablement les voitures plutôt lourdes. Cette
année, nous faisons un grand pas en introduisant un monocoque en fibres de
carbone pour remplacer le squelette en acier. Par conséquent, le nouveau châssis
sera plus fort et résistant en plus d’être beaucoup plus léger.
Évidemment, la conception et la manufacture d’un châssis
en fibres de carbone est loin d’être une tâche facile. La conception débute sur
un ordinateur alors que la forme est modelée et que la rigidité des différentes
sections est déterminée. Une fois cette étape achevée, la manufacture commence:
deux moules, un pour chaque moitié du châssis, sont construits en utilisant un
type spécial de panneau pour matériaux composites. Les moules sont ensuite
recouverts, couche après couche, de fibres de carbone imprégnées de colle époxy
et de matériau à structure alvéolaire à des endroits précis. Finalement, on
place les moules dans des fours spéciaux pressurisés appelés autoclaves. Cette
dernière étape assure que les différentes couches ont bien adhéré les unes aux
autres grâce à la résine d’époxy.  
Malheureusement, la manufacture d’une grosse pièce telle
que notre châssis est dispendieuse, comme le montre notre budget. Bien que le
travail des étudiants universitaires soit volontaire et non-rémunéré, nous
avons tout de même besoin de vos dons pour régler les coûts externes ne pouvant
être pris en charge par nos commanditaires directs. Contribuez au succès de
notre équipe en donnant aujourd’hui!
Cliquez sur nos Perks et recevez un cadeau McGill Racing
Team en échange de votre contribution!
Votre impact
Ce projet représente une expérience d’apprentissage
incroyable pour les jeunes étudiants universitaires en plus d’assurer que les
ingénieurs de demain seront hautement qualifiés et talentueux. En plus, les
matériaux composites sont de plus en plus utilisés en raison de leurs propriétés
uniques et il est crucial que les futurs ingénieurs en aient une connaissance
excellente pour construire de meilleures structures et véhicules. 
D’autres façons
de nous aider
McGill Racing Team tente constamment de s’impliquer
davantage dans la communauté. Libre à vous de nous contacter via nos comptes
Facebook, Twitter et YouTube, ou via notre site web. Parlez de nous à votre
entourage et aidez-nous à créer une voiture de course plus légère, plus
puissante, et plus rapide!

story:
My name is Kenneth Compton. I am asking for help to get to India this summer for a 28 day process called the Deepening at the Oneness University near Chennai. This process will greatly enhance my ability to help others.

I am a Oneness Trainer in a growing spiritual community in NYC where I hold weekly events to share the gift of Kundalini Awakening which initiates a powerful process of purification and healing. I also hold bi-monthly courses to initiate Deeksha (blessing) givers (see onenessuniversity.org or onenessnyc.com) in the effort to help others experience the flow of grace in their lives.
 
I have booked my airfare and will be able to cover my expenses here while I'm away (rent and bills) but I do not have enough funds to cover my accomodations while in India. Accomodations for this process are around $2,915. This does not include any other expenses such as travel so I am asking for $3,000 to cover only my accomodations while at the Oneness University. Please help me to reach my goal! If I don't reach my $3,000 goal I will still receive whatever donation you make so please contribute.

For any donation over $25 I will take your photo or photo of a loved one with me to place on the altar in the main meditation hall at the Oneness University for the full time I'm there. Just send your JPEG as an attachment to onenessnyc@mail.com

Thank you for your help!

Kenneth

story:
Short Summary

I am Courtney Snelling, a recently-barred attorney with a particular interest in international taxation and developing countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. On July 24th, I learned that I was chosen to participate with 58 other young attorneys from around the world in an educational program of the Paris Bar that will take place in Paris from October through November of this year. This experience will increase my understanding of French law, enhance my ability to work with governments of Francophone countries on their tax policy, and link me with dozens of international lawyers who work in Africa. 

Unfortunately, the Paris Bar only funds the courses in French law that are part of the program and not the trip to Paris or housing and room and board. The Paris Bar suggests that participants seek funding from the French Embassy in their home country. I have contacted the French Embassy in the U.S. and was told that there are not funds for this program.  So, I am attempting to raise funds from family and friends to support my stay in Paris during this two-month period.

What We Need & What You Get

The round-trip plane tickets for the trip are going to cost from $1,500 to $2,000. I am looking for friends and associates to stay with in Paris to reduce the cost of housing to an estimated $1,500 per month ($3,000). I will need an additional $1,500 for food, the daily commute to the educational facilities, and other living expenses during this time. I am raising funds with $6,500 as the goal, but I am also attempting to reduce the costs of the trip in all ways that I can. All support and advice is appreciated.

I am willing to provide valuable tax and French translation services for free to those who are able to contribute. 

The Impact

This program of the Paris Bar - Stage International 2013 - is a very unique program that brings together young attorneys from all over the world to increase understanding of French law. Past participants have noted that this is an invaluable career opportunity and particularly for those interested in working with the governments of francophone countries. To learn more about the program visit: http://www.avocatparis.org/le-stage-et-echange.html

Other Ways You Can Help

Any and all help is appreciated. If anyone has contacts in Paris who might be willing to provide housing, please contact me. Please let others know about this campaign. Thank you!

story:
Can you believe that Downtown Raleigh and it's surrounding area has no play-based child care centers or preschools? For us, as early childhood educators, this is mind-blowing! And through our extensive work and play with families in our community, we feel drawn to and motivated to build this exact type of program. Because we know, when play is valued first, learning naturally follows!

As Little by Little, we want to create an inspired and engaged community by giving families creative opportunities to learn and play together! We have developed a program which provides a unique option for high quality childcare as well as opportunities for playful grown up and child experiences.

As owners, we are a team of innovative childcare experts who value play and individuality in the highest regard. We've both spent over a decade doing what we love most: researching, developing and delivering age-appropriate programming for kids ages zero to ten with a focus on exploration of creative and individualized education.

For us, Little by Little embodies our relationship with children, families and our community and we believe that, little by little, we can all grow together.

Check us out! www.littlebylittleraleigh.com

@littlebylittleraleigh

story:
What is Amal ou Salam?

Project Amal ou Salam, meaning Project Hope and Peace in Arabic, is a non-political grassroots organization that works with Syrian refugee children in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon as well as children in Syria to empower the future leaders of Syria through education, intervention and trauma-based care. 

We developed an innovative educational approach that seeks to empower the future leaders of Syria. The core tenets of the approach include working to ensure that every child has the right to an education, a childhood free from trauma and violence, and the hope of a peaceful tomorrow. Project Amal ou Salam has a successful track record of delivering this approach in week-long workshops in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan with volunteers from around the world, in the school that it funds in Jordan and in its community center in Syria.

Our Origins

While visiting an IDP camp in Syria in 2013, Co-Founders Nousha Kabawat and Aziz Abu Sarah were struck by the bored children mirroring the anger, violence and sectarianism around them and began to imagine a grassroots effort to feed the children’s self-esteem and character. With a background in conflict resolution and peacebuilding in post-war societies, Nousha worked to turn her dream of a multicultural, interfaith community into a reality called Project Amal ou Salam.

Free from politics and sectarian dogma, Project Amal ou Salam operates across Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria – few NGOs for Syrian refugee children founded in the past few years are working across borders. 

According to the UNHCR, to date there are over 3 million registered Syrian refugees, of which more than half are under the age of 17. Since the revolution began in 2011, these children have been forced from their homes and country and have been unable to access basic needs or education. In 2016, children who are five years old - or entering school - have always had a life of war and conflict. 

Our Impact

Through our workshops, school and community center, Project Amal ou Salam has supported over 6,000 children in four different countries, aided by more than 100 volunteers from around the world.

Project Amal ou Salam Workshops – Jordan and Lebanon

Project Amal ou Salam’s workshops provide open dialogue, giving the kids a safe space to tackle the issues that they face and develop their own ideas and visions for the future of Syria. With activities not present in the refugee camps, our workshops for Syrian refugee children arm them with the tools and confidence to rebuild Syria through art, health, photography, sports and music.

Project Amal ou Salam School – Jarash, Jordan

In Jordan, we have an Amal ou Salam school that plays an important role by filling a gap in the education system: Syrian children are not allowed to enroll in Jordanian schools until they are able to pass tests at their appropriate grade level.

Before the war, nearly all Syrian children were enrolled in school. Today most Syrian children who are living as refugees in Jordan have been out of school for several years and need significant catch-up time and individualized attention to make up for the hundreds of hours of class time they have missed out on. The Amal ou Salam school prepares students to pass tests that will allow them to enter the Jordanian school system and ensures that they can perform as well as their Jordanian peers in their new classrooms.


Beit Amal ou Salam – Aleppo, Syria

Opened January 1, 2016, our new underground kids community center "The Project Amal ou Salam House" hosts approximately 60 kids every week to learn writing, reading, and math; enjoy lots of arts and music; watch movies and just have a ton of fun! 

The center was built underground to create a safe environment as far away from the war happening above ground as possible. To ensure that the atmosphere is also fun and inviting for children, there are disco lights, a music system, a large screen for showing movies, and stuffed animals in every corner and angle in the room.

Other Activities

In addition to activities run by Project Amal ou Salam, we have provided material donations (e.g., coloring books, games, sports equipment) and monetary support to schools both within and outside of Syria (Turkey and Lebanon). Additionally, we have supported activities in Idlib, Syria; sent school and art supplies to a refugee camp in Ersal, Lebanon; hosted a football tournament for hundreds of Syrian kids as well as hosted a Ramadan meal for 60 Syrian children and their families in Jordan; and hosted Eid celebrations in Suroui, Turkey for Kurdish refugees who had recently arrived from Kobani, Syria.

Spreading the Word

We are always honored when Project Amal ou Salam is featured in the media because it is a great opportunity for more people to learn about the work that we do. Here are some of our favorite features:

  • BBC, Syria’s Next Generation, http://goo.gl/SvIGA0
  • Elle Magazine, Young, Syrian, Female: This Is How you Fight ISIS's Values http://goo.gl/SFeJth
  • Huffington Post, 6 Organizations Helping Syrian Refugees That You Might Not Have Heard Of, http://goo.gl/Cn1Mwe
  • National Geographic, Life Through the Lens of Syria’s Uprooted Teens, http://goo.gl/lWktpO

When speaking on a panel at the UN's Global Forum on Youth, Peace and Security, Nousha summarized the issue well when she said: "Syria has become a complex issue but please don't think it is only about violence and killing. Think about the children who need love, attention and caring from everyone around the world so that they become the future generation, not a lost generation."

Impact – Why Your Support is Critical

Providing a safe space for the psycho-social development of Syria’s children is both crucial for the rebuilding and reconciliation processes and the future of Syrian society, and is more sustainable than direct aid. When PTSD and depression are not treated in children, they result in flashbacks, emotional instability, violent and aggressive behavior, nightmares, isolation and poor academic achievement. Helping the next generation cope with the trauma and tragedy of war will aid them in becoming strong, capable, and productive members of society ready to rebuild their country!

Your donation will go directly towards expanding, building and developing the implementation of Project Amal ou Salam. More specifically, your donation will fund:

  1. The volunteer-run workshops in March 2016 in Jordan for more than 1000 children, aided by 30 volunteers from all around the world
  2. The Amal ou Salam School in Jarash, Jordan
  3. Beit Amal ou Salam, the newly launched community center in Aleppo, Syria

If you are in the U.S. and would like to make a tax-deductible donation, please make your check out to GreaterGood.org and write “Project Amal ou Salam #65981″ in the memo line. Mail checks to 6262 N Swan Road, Suite 150, Tucson, AZ 85718. You can also make a tax-deductible donation online.

Thank you for your donation!

Keep Spreading the Love <3

story:
Thanks for dropping by the Students For High-Impact Charity (SHIC) Indigogo campaign! We want you to make an impact investment in order to help achieve our ultimate goal:

 

Building a global network of students with the technical ability to thrive in the real world and the vision to make it a better place.

 

 

We do this by providing any student, anywhere in the world a global network of classes and extracurricular clubs dedicated to achieving the most substantial prosocial impact.

Our program pays special attention to how science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) all play a crucial role in the future of international development. We envision a new class of socially conscious leaders with a lifelong commitment to doing the most good possible.

                                                                                                                                                     

We need your help to complete the first round of program launches for the new school year through December 2016. We would otherwise not be able to deliver programs beyond August to students around the world who can't wait to start learning how best to make a difference. Every little bit nudges us toward our vision!

                                                                                                                                                    

You can spark a force multiplier for impact.

Part-in-parcel with shaping long-term personal development is inspiring students to truly feel themselves making an impact in the here and now. SHIC supporters not only nudge students towards a healthier future, but your initial gift sets off a chain reaction in real dollars as more and more SHIC students plan quarterly fundraising activities for their favorite high-impact charities. 100% of these student-raised proceeds go directly to charity, not to us.

Why only do a single good deed when you can initiate cascading positive impact? 

Here’s how it works:

(click here or on the image for a closer look)

 

We see your contribution as an impact investment because concern for others is truly a compounding phenomenon. Students who value charity are far more likely to make it an integral part of their lives later on. To break it down even further, a student persuaded by our program to donate just 1% of their income for an entire lifetime could result in tens of thousands of dollars donated to worthwhile causes.

Catherine’s Class - New Zealand

Catherine is an educator in New Zealand and also one of our most dedicated volunteers. She found SHIC materials so appealing that she integrated them into her year 13 core curriculum. After finishing our 6-week pilot, her class raised $675 NZD for high-impact charities!


Half of the class elected to run a Cool Earth peer-to-peer fundraiser, and the other half a vegan sausage sizzle and video screening for our top-ranked animal welfare charities. On top of that, her students will also run a Giving Game assembly for over 100 students to help promote high-impact giving!

“I now realise even more that it is everyone's, including mine, responsibility to help the world in whatever most effective way we can. I'll remember the things I have learnt in this course and it may influence what I choose to study and what career I head into in the future.”

- Kimberley, student participant, New Zealand

What we’re really about: personal growth in rethinking charity

Our ultimate goal is to ignite the ambition of young altruists and extend a refined skill set into all areas of their personal development. Rethinking charity is the vehicle through which students hone valuable meta-skills for personal development. Our novel curriculum complements the latest approaches to doing good with concepts of logic, epistemology, and metacognition, which carry practical applications in everyday life.

For example, what is a cognitive bias? How do they keep us from helping others most effectively? How can we keep these biases from affecting our own personal decisions? We extend these concepts to how we think about charity as well. What do clever marketing campaigns have to tell us about the integrity and effectiveness of a given charity? Should decisions about how best to help others be purely emotional?

With our curriculum, students divide their time between guided discussions, interactive online quizzes and videos, lateral thinking, design challenges, group problem-solving, career exploration, and they round out each semester by taking action on behalf of their favorite effective charities.

SHIC provides innovative services to participating schools and students in three primary ways:

  1. Seeding local clubs. SHIC is committed to building and nourishing an organic network of organizers and member students. We guide our “ambassadors” (member students, teachers and faculty members leading SHIC clubs) in setting up local clubs, and provide attentive guidance and support throughout the entire process.  
  2. Innovative Curriculum. Available on our website free of charge, our curriculum has been developed and refined by veteran teachers from around the world, who know firsthand what works in the classroom.
  3. Attentive Guidance and Support. We will always be available to assist ambassadors and participants with anything they might need. The typical turnaround time for all inquiries is less than 24 hours.

Impact - Inspiring a new generation of altruists

We invest heavily in programs that guide prosocial personal development. While your initial gift is amplified through student fundraising in dollars, our program prioritizes for individual fulfillment and cultivating a lifelong commitment for the least fortunate.

Here’s how we go about doing this:

Mutual reinforcement for enhanced STEM education. In light of the undeniable demand for a new generation of students fluent in STEM concepts, and the acknowledgment of that demand by educators around the world, a program that reinforces already existing curricula is critical. Students come to learn about revolutionizing charity and ultimately leave with an enhanced skill set in preparation for university and beyond.

Activities that research suggests can shape long-term giving potential. Day 1 begins with a Giving Game. According to research conducted by The Life You Can Save, Giving Games carry tremendous potential for influencing future giving behavior.

The calculated value of student clubs supporting high-impact charities. By inspiring students to make a practical and significant difference, a typical club could bring in $60,000 - $100,000 to high-impact charities.

Tangible Benefits

SHIC offers students and schools an opportunity to signal their progress and accomplishments in the real world. Rather than students simply listing themselves as a standard volunteer, SHIC ambassadors can point to leadership, project management, and STEM skills gained from being, for example, a SHIC club Ambassador. These invaluable accomplishments will be on display within our website, which will contain a comprehensive directory of all SHIC Ambassadors and participating schools, including periodic features on particularly impressive achievements of ambassadors and top-rankings of schools according to various metrics.

Why SHIC? Why Now?

For students that truly do care, little else beyond intuition and word-of-mouth guides them towards volunteer opportunities. Search results can leave students both without a starting point and the overwhelming impression that charity-as-usual is not enough, considering the magnitude of today’s social problems. Any action feels like a drop in the bucket, which means an entire generation could be absent a guide to make effective choices about charity, despite living in the information age. How, then, can we expect the next graduating class to play a vital role at the forefront of world development and global ethics?

For young do-gooders living in a world where information is cheap, nothing is more valuable than a roadmap on how best to achieve impact. Our novel curriculum and extracurricular clubs provide a crucial channel for students to discover the latest in global development, embrace the global transition toward applying scientific principles to charity, and above all, embark on the most effective ways to take action. Active students in our program will strengthen the tools that they need to become effective changemakers.

Highly Skilled Altruists - The Gap in Human Capital

Global development entities of all stripes have roundly acknowledged the importance of mathematical and scientific literacy in combatting the most pressing problems of our time. What this means for the next generation is that general demand for STEM skills will be pervasive, and even regarding charity, the head is of equal importance to the heart.

In addition to the general global demand for STEM skill fluency, top policy-makers now understand that feeling good about giving is no longer the same as actually achieving a better world. Providing evidence and proving effectiveness in helping others is the new gold standard. With this firmly affixed as the ethos of SHIC, valuable technical skills are reflected in the curriculum by learning about what works in helping the least fortunate and what does not.

What is High-Impact Charity?

Our chosen high-impact charities have been selected and/or highlighted by charity evaluators GiveWell, Giving What We Can, The Life You Can Save, or Animal Charity Evaluators as having made demonstrable strides in doing the most good with the money they’re given when compared to other charitable organizations. Throughout the course of our program, students will be introduced to different cause areas and the leading charities working in each field.   

The charities we currently support:


 

Operations Direction

SHIC enjoys several advantages relative to typical startups. Most notably, your impact investments will be tax deductible in the US and Canada since we've launched as an independent .impact initiative under the foundational umbrella of Charity Science. Moving forward, we know that our supporters care about being a part of a sustainable initiative. SHIC plans to pivot to a social venture model by generating revenue in various ways. We’ve projected that support via school donations and school accreditation will constitute a sizeable share of our operating budget, allowing serious altruists like yourself to pursue other worthwhile projects.

You can find our full funding proposal here

Other Ways to Contribute

- To make donations without the 5% platform fees of Indiegogo, please click here for our Generosity.com campaign

- For Tax-deductible donations in the US and Canada, please visit our website or contact Tee at tee@highimpacstudents.org

What you Get

We made it a top priority of ours to offer perks that mirror our mission and further foster a sense of connectedness with our supporters. We take pride in demonstrating how every dollar will go directly towards strengthening our global network of students making significant strides in their personal development and taking action on behalf of high-impact charities.

Our impact investors will have a direct line to our team and the latest news coming out of the SHIC program, including a standing invitation to join our Slack community (an instant messaging platform) to see the inner workings of SHIC, and access to our Facebook group our monthly newsletter dedicated exclusively to informing our supporters about the progress we’ve made together. More involved impact investors also receive t-shirts, so you can kick off a conversation anywhere you go about the importance of guiding the next generation of altruists.

What people are saying

“I can't thank you enough Tee and Baxter. The organized, reproducible lesson plans and the SHIC brand are exactly what [] student groups need.

- Aahan Rashid, student coordinator, Indiana, USA

"My experience with the first few levels was overwhelmingly positive...Another great thing about the topics of these lessons is that they immediately capture the attention and interest of the students. The topics come across as both unusual in a school context and extremely relevant and contemporary."

- Roland Reichart, student coordinator, Austria, Vienna

 

“The majority of the students seemed interested in the talk and I could see that the discussions were lively.”

- Radim, student coordinator, Brno, Czech Republic

 

“I know Tee and Baxter well - we’ve worked out of the same Vancouver EA office for a long time - and unreservedly recommend them as a team...I’m very excited to throw the support of .impact behind this project.”
- Tom Ash, .impact Executive Director, Vancouver, Canada

Current Supporters

  • Potentially thousands of dollars in in-kind administrative and technical support from .impact
  • The Life You Can Save - $5000 (in-kind funding for Giving Games)
  • Anonymous donor - $4,500
  • Tee Barnett - $3,750 (at launch)
  • Baxter Bullock - $3,750 (at launch)
  • Ravi Patel and Lucia Coulter - $683.76 (£500)
  • Tracy Patel - $273.50 (£200)
  • Tom Ash - $200
  • Ollie Base - $145 (£100)

 

Total : $5,801.50*
*Subject to currency rates. Figure does not include bootstrap funding by Baxter and Tee at launch

SHIC Organizational Structure

SHIC relies on an expansive and dedicated network of volunteers that is instrumental to our operations. The “internal team” consists of those involved with the program at their home institution in some capacity. SHIC “ambassadors” are students who lead the program at their respective schools, while “officers” are students that take an active leadership role in the program after it is introduced by the local ambassador. Proponents of the program who are either teachers or administrators typically initiate the program with the intention of eventually handing it off to an ambassador, or else they have elected to use our curriculum as a core component of their own classes.

 

The “external team” is composed of SHIC “coordinators” that identify promising potential ambassadors and lobby for clubs to be established. Coordinators will similarly deliver pilots (often at secondary schools) with the intention of inspiring local students to take the program on themselves. The core “central team” is likewise almost entirely composed of volunteers, including the Executive Director, Founding Advisor, Volunteer Programs Manager and volunteer communications and outreach team. The Chief Operations Officer is the only paid full-time staff member of the entire organization, which allows for a supremely lean operating budget.

The Team

With nearly a decade of international teaching experience between them, co-founders Baxter Bullock and Tee Barnett combine educational experience and insight with their technical knowledge of world development.

In the fall of 2015, Baxter and Tee were brought onboard Charity Science to stand in for the senior-level staff, who were to leave for India in January to launch Charity Entrepreneurs. Under the guidance and oversight of co-founder Joey Savoie in India and Operations Director David Moss in the UK, Baxter and Tee received a crash course in running a nonprofit by together handling all of the day-to-day operations of Charity Science. In January, the pair decided to pursue SHIC as a side project with the help of Ravi Patel, eventually teaming up with .impact and Charity Science to launch the project in early March.

Founders

Executive Director

Baxter Bullock currently serves as the Programs Director for Charity Science, a foundation focused on researching and implementing the most effective fundraising methods for the most effective charities. Before moving to Vancouver in October 2015, Baxter interned with the Centre for Effective Altruism in Oxford, UK. This served as his transition into the nonprofit sector after over five years as an educator (high school math and ESL). During this time, he was the head of his school’s community service program, among other positions.

Chief Operations Officer

Tee Barnett recently served as the Communications Manager at Charity Science and is excited to take on SHIC as his primary project. He earned his M.A. specializing in International Development from National Chengchi University (政治大學) in Taipei. While living in Taiwan for three and a half years, he founded The People’s English, a nonprofit community group that gave away free English classes in exchange for donations to charity.

Founding Advisor

Ravi Patel is currently studying Clinical Medicine at Jesus College, University of Cambridge, having graduated in Natural Sciences in 2015. Ravi founded and directed the ‘Take the Pledge’ annual New Year’s campaign in 2014, which reached university students around the world to encourage them to consider taking the Giving What We Can pledge: a pledge to give 10% of future income to high impact charities. He also founded the Jesus College Effective Altruism Society in 2016 whilst in the role of Strategy & External Projects Director for Giving What We Can Cambridge. He began collaborating on plans for SHIC as a side project in January 2015, joining forces with Baxter and Tee to bring the idea to life.

Key Contributors

Camille Ancessi is a Volunteer Communications Officer for SHIC, and a full time student at Langara College, where she is studying Peace and Conflict.

Tom Ash is a the Executive Director of .impact Focus Projects and serves as secretary treasurer for SHIC. Tom also serves as a close advisor on organizational development.

Ollie Base is a second year Philosophy with Psychology student at Warwick in the UK and and has previously helped out Charity Science with research on fundraising.

Matt and Ben Clifford have generously advised on big-picture and fundraising strategies.

Ajeya Cotra is a research analyst for GiveWell and actively assists in the content generation process.

Michael Dello-Iacovo co-founded an effective altruism chapter in Adelaide, and currently serves as a curriculum advisor.

Edward Higson is the former president of the Oxford Giving What We Can Chapter and has since become the president of GWWC Cambridge. Edward has helped immensely with outreach coordination.

Oliver Hornung also previously volunteered for Charity Science, by conducting research on fundraising. Olly has been integral to our curriculum generation process.

Catherine Low is a seasoned Charity Science volunteer and New Zealand educator who’s provided invaluable feedback, as well as initiating some of the first SHIC pilots.

Georgie Mallett has provided technical support as part of the .impact Focus Projects team.

Brenton Mayer is a co-founder of EA Australia and co-creator of Run To Better Days and advises SHIC on outreach techniques.

David Moss is the Director of Operations of Charity Science. David consistently advises on operations, outreach strategy, curriculum development, and survey design.

Jacy Reese is a researcher and former Chair of the Board at Animal Charity Evaluators. Jacy currently serves as a curriculum advisor.

Duncan Sabien is a middle school teacher and curriculum advisor at the Center for Applied Rationality who has allowed us to use some of the fantastic material from his rationality-based summer camp Inflection Point.

Joey and Katherine Savoie are co-founders of the Charity Science Foundation of Canada and Charity Entrepreneurship, and have graciously allowed Students For High-Impact Charity to launch under the foundational umbrella. SHIC eventually plans to pivot into a social venture intent on generating revenue to remain sustainable. Joey and Katherine serve as close advisors on organizational development.

 

Tough Questions

 

Is there demand out there for a program like this? Do students really need it?

More than our intuitive senses suggest that students around the world want this project to exist. We interpret coordinator and ambassador demand as a proxy for general student demand, and after launching officially in mid-March, this demand has already outstripped our expectations. We originally expected to have half a dozen pilot commitments by mid-May; we’re on course to double that. In addition, we’ve made projections regarding program appeal and potential impact with teachers experienced in delivering similar content, all of which are very encouraging even at conservative estimates. The ease with which SHIC pilot material can be imported and tested around the world ensures that we will have plenty of opportunities to pivot our curriculum and gauge demand. Relative to other organizations, the Charity Science Foundation enjoys a healthy reputation of being incredibly meticulous in evaluating programs, and SHIC expects to import the same level of rigor and self-auditing techniques into our operation.

 

As for whether students need this club, this certainly constitutes a more prescriptive answer. Global development entities of all stripes, including the United Nations, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the Open Philanthropy Project, have roundly acknowledged the importance of mathematical and scientific literacy in combatting the most pressing problems of our time. What this means for the next generation of givers is that, even regarding charity, the head is equally as important as the heart. Feeling good about giving is no longer the same as actually achieving a better world.

 

This need for STEM literacy in making real progress is reflected back at our member students during every session and made palpable through learning about what works in helping the least fortunate and what does not. Equipped with the inspiration and know-how to make a substantial prosocial impact, we want to see an entire global network of students with the technical ability to thrive in the real world and the vision to make it a better place for others.

 

What if students simply don’t like your curriculum? Would that paralyze the entire program?

 

Absolutely not. We expect the pilot process to expose weaknesses in our content that we can then rework to make it stronger. In fact, that is the primary goal of distributing these six-week pilots to as many schools as we can – tightening the feedback loop and putting out an even better version of our product than the last will only allow us to go from strength to strength.

 

Can we really expect immediate impact to effective charities through high school students?

 

Without a doubt, but we don’t want to overstate the immediate impact SHIC will have, especially regarding students at such a formative age who are so far from having a regular income. What we will expect to see from every SHIC club is a fundraising effort for their favorite effective charity as the pilot draws to a close, and quarterly fundraising efforts are built into the program for each club thereafter. Those efforts are the bare minimum we’re likely to see in immediate impact and do not include potential spillover effects, including fundraisers taken on independently as well as altered giving habits of parents.

 

What is your primary value added?

 

Our core message is ultimately what will attract students and schools to SHIC. Everything else, including the attentive staff support, fundraising guidance, online network for students, and school accreditation, revolves around our message. We deliver our vision of making the biggest prosocial difference possible through our carefully crafted curriculum. Every single Level Guide is forged with at least 15 work hours, compiled initially by experts in international development and shaped by teachers with decades of combined classroom experience.

 

How can the organization remain sustainable despite giving away SHIC’s primary value added?

 

The trending model for achieving a foothold in the psyche of a potential customer or end user is to give away a fully functional version of a product. In the first year, SHIC does that by allowing full access to our highest quality content, allowing our brand and our message to grow with the students. When the club becomes an integral part of a student’s extracurricular repertoire and an important part of their lives, or teachers similar to our early adopters in Vancouver and New Zealand want to build our curriculum into their actual courses, we will then have made a product of measurable value. After a year of this sort of growth, SHIC will introduce a paywall for premium content, and a small fee for schools interested in integrating our level guides as part of the wider curriculum. This is the point where SHIC turns from a public service, courtesy of our donors, into a social service. SHIC will then be sustained by schools and teachers with the potential to generate additional revenue to be reinvested for the purposes of enhancing SHIC programs.

 

SHIC has only budgeted for one full-time staff member. How can SHIC produce a substantial enough impact with a single person?


We’ve calculated that SHIC can oversee well over 100 clubs at any given time before resources become strained with help from a well-organized volunteer core. Currently, about 15 volunteers actively assist operations directly in curriculum design, development, web design and general administration. For example, each level guide requires roughly 20 hours of manpower, including input from EA teachers that have decades of combined experience. When added to the number of SHIC coordinators and ambassadors, by the start of the new school year SHIC will have built a network of over 50 committed volunteers. The drive and dedication of our EA volunteer core is absolutely crucial to our organizational effectiveness.

Thank you to our special partners

SHIC was fortunate enough to have several operational costs covered and also received technical and financial expertise from .impact, a movement-building organization that also operates under the umbrella of the Charity Science Foundation.

Because the SHIC co-founders are fronting the funds for the initial launch, and thanks to the incredibly active and collaborative effective altruism network, SHIC has made considerable strides in bringing our program to students around the world. The success of Charity Science in ushering other non-profits away from ineffective fundraising practices has translated into considerable support from like-minded charitable organizations. For example, SHIC received $5,000 USD of in-kind funding from The Life You Can Save to conduct Giving Games–an activity that give students a decision-making framework for choosing which charity to support with real money.

Thanks for dropping by the Students For High-Impact Charity (SHIC) Indigogo campaign! We want you to make an impact investment in order to help achieve our ultimate goal: Building a global network of students with the technical ability to thrive in the real world and the vision to make it a better place.  We do this by providing any student, anywhere in the world a global network of classes and extracurricular clubs dedicated to achieving the most substantial prosocial impact.Our program pays special attention to how science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) all play a crucial role in the future of international development. We envision a new class of socially conscious leaders with a lifelong commitment to doing the most good possible.                                                                                                                                                     We need your help to complete the first round of program launches for the new school year through December 2016. We would otherwise not be able to deliver programs beyond August to students around the world who can't wait to start learning how best to make a difference. Every little bit nudges us toward our vision!                                                                                                                                                    You can spark a force multiplier for impact.Part-in-parcel with shaping long-term personal development is inspiring students to truly feel themselves making an impact in the here and now. Coordinators will similarly deliver pilots (often at secondary schools) with the intention of inspiring local students to take the program on themselves.
