The Chief Operations Officer is the only paid full-time staff member of the entire organization, which allows for a supremely lean operating budget.The TeamWith nearly a decade of international teaching experience between them, co-founders Baxter Bullock and Tee Barnett combine educational experience and insight with their technical knowledge of world development.In the fall of 2015, Baxter and Tee were brought onboard Charity Science to stand in for the senior-level staff, who were to leave for India in January to launch Charity Entrepreneurs. Under the guidance and oversight of co-founder Joey Savoie in India and Operations Director David Moss in the UK, Baxter and Tee received a crash course in running a nonprofit by together handling all of the day-to-day operations of Charity Science. In January, the pair decided to pursue SHIC as a side project with the help of Ravi Patel, eventually teaming up with .impact and Charity Science to launch the project in early March.FoundersExecutive DirectorBaxter Bullock currently serves as the Programs Director for Charity Science, a foundation focused on researching and implementing the most effective fundraising methods for the most effective charities. Before moving to Vancouver in October 2015, Baxter interned with the Centre for Effective Altruism in Oxford, UK. This served as his transition into the nonprofit sector after over five years as an educator (high school math and ESL). During this time, he was the head of his school’s community service program, among other positions.Chief Operations OfficerTee Barnett recently served as the Communications Manager at Charity Science and is excited to take on SHIC as his primary project. He earned his M.A. specializing in International Development from National Chengchi University (政治大學) in Taipei. While living in Taiwan for three and a half years, he founded The People’s English, a nonprofit community group that gave away free English classes in exchange for donations to charity.Founding AdvisorRavi Patel is currently studying Clinical Medicine at Jesus College, University of Cambridge, having graduated in Natural Sciences in 2015. Ravi founded and directed the ‘Take the Pledge’ annual New Year’s campaign in 2014, which reached university students around the world to encourage them to consider taking the Giving What We Can pledge: a pledge to give 10% of future income to high impact charities. He also founded the Jesus College Effective Altruism Society in 2016 whilst in the role of Strategy & External Projects Director for Giving What We Can Cambridge. He began collaborating on plans for SHIC as a side project in January 2015, joining forces with Baxter and Tee to bring the idea to life.Key ContributorsCamille Ancessi is a Volunteer Communications Officer for SHIC, and a full time student at Langara College, where she is studying Peace and Conflict.Tom Ash is a the Executive Director of .impact Focus Projects and serves as secretary treasurer for SHIC. Tom also serves as a close advisor on organizational development.Ollie Base is a second year Philosophy with Psychology student at Warwick in the UK and and has previously helped out Charity Science with research on fundraising.Matt and Ben Clifford have generously advised on big-picture and fundraising strategies.Ajeya Cotra is a research analyst for GiveWell and actively assists in the content generation process.Michael Dello-Iacovo co-founded an effective altruism chapter in Adelaide, and currently serves as a curriculum advisor.Edward Higson is the former president of the Oxford Giving What We Can Chapter and has since become the president of GWWC Cambridge. Edward has helped immensely with outreach coordination.Oliver Hornung also previously volunteered for Charity Science, by conducting research on fundraising. Olly has been integral to our curriculum generation process.Catherine Low is a seasoned Charity Science volunteer and New Zealand educator who’s provided invaluable feedback, as well as initiating some of the first SHIC pilots.Georgie Mallett has provided technical support as part of the .impact Focus Projects team.Brenton Mayer is a co-founder of EA Australia and co-creator of Run To Better Days and advises SHIC on outreach techniques.David Moss is the Director of Operations of Charity Science. David consistently advises on operations, outreach strategy, curriculum development, and survey design.Jacy Reese is a researcher and former Chair of the Board at Animal Charity Evaluators. Jacy currently serves as a curriculum advisor.Duncan Sabien is a middle school teacher and curriculum advisor at the Center for Applied Rationality who has allowed us to use some of the fantastic material from his rationality-based summer camp Inflection Point.Joey and Katherine Savoie are co-founders of the Charity Science Foundation of Canada and Charity Entrepreneurship, and have graciously allowed Students For High-Impact Charity to launch under the foundational umbrella. SHIC eventually plans to pivot into a social venture intent on generating revenue to remain sustainable. Joey and Katherine serve as close advisors on organizational development. Tough Questions Is there demand out there for a program like this? Do students really need it?More than our intuitive senses suggest that students around the world want this project to exist. We interpret coordinator and ambassador demand as a proxy for general student demand, and after launching officially in mid-March, this demand has already outstripped our expectations. We originally expected to have half a dozen pilot commitments by mid-May; we’re on course to double that. In addition, we’ve made projections regarding program appeal and potential impact with teachers experienced in delivering similar content, all of which are very encouraging even at conservative estimates. The ease with which SHIC pilot material can be imported and tested around the world ensures that we will have plenty of opportunities to pivot our curriculum and gauge demand. Relative to other organizations, the Charity Science Foundation enjoys a healthy reputation of being incredibly meticulous in evaluating programs, and SHIC expects to import the same level of rigor and self-auditing techniques into our operation. As for whether students need this club, this certainly constitutes a more prescriptive answer. Global development entities of all stripes, including the United Nations, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the Open Philanthropy Project, have roundly acknowledged the importance of mathematical and scientific literacy in combatting the most pressing problems of our time. What this means for the next generation of givers is that, even regarding charity, the head is equally as important as the heart. Feeling good about giving is no longer the same as actually achieving a better world. This need for STEM literacy in making real progress is reflected back at our member students during every session and made palpable through learning about what works in helping the least fortunate and what does not. Equipped with the inspiration and know-how to make a substantial prosocial impact, we want to see an entire global network of students with the technical ability to thrive in the real world and the vision to make it a better place for others. What if students simply don’t like your curriculum? Would that paralyze the entire program?  Absolutely not. We expect the pilot process to expose weaknesses in our content that we can then rework to make it stronger. In fact, that is the primary goal of distributing these six-week pilots to as many schools as we can – tightening the feedback loop and putting out an even better version of our product than the last will only allow us to go from strength to strength. Can we really expect immediate impact to effective charities through high school students?  Without a doubt, but we don’t want to overstate the immediate impact SHIC will have, especially regarding students at such a formative age who are so far from having a regular income. What we will expect to see from every SHIC club is a fundraising effort for their favorite effective charity as the pilot draws to a close, and quarterly fundraising efforts are built into the program for each club thereafter. Those efforts are the bare minimum we’re likely to see in immediate impact and do not include potential spillover effects, including fundraisers taken on independently as well as altered giving habits of parents. What is your primary value added?  Our core message is ultimately what will attract students and schools to SHIC. Everything else, including the attentive staff support, fundraising guidance, online network for students, and school accreditation, revolves around our message. We deliver our vision of making the biggest prosocial difference possible through our carefully crafted curriculum. Every single Level Guide is forged with at least 15 work hours, compiled initially by experts in international development and shaped by teachers with decades of combined classroom experience. How can the organization remain sustainable despite giving away SHIC’s primary value added?  The trending model for achieving a foothold in the psyche of a potential customer or end user is to give away a fully functional version of a product. In the first year, SHIC does that by allowing full access to our highest quality content, allowing our brand and our message to grow with the students. When the club becomes an integral part of a student’s extracurricular repertoire and an important part of their lives, or teachers similar to our early adopters in Vancouver and New Zealand want to build our curriculum into their actual courses, we will then have made a product of measurable value. After a year of this sort of growth, SHIC will introduce a paywall for premium content, and a small fee for schools interested in integrating our level guides as part of the wider curriculum. This is the point where SHIC turns from a public service, courtesy of our donors, into a social service. SHIC will then be sustained by schools and teachers with the potential to generate additional revenue to be reinvested for the purposes of enhancing SHIC programs. SHIC has only budgeted for one full-time staff member. How can SHIC produce a substantial enough impact with a single person? We’ve calculated that SHIC can oversee well over 100 clubs at any given time before resources become strained with help from a well-organized volunteer core. Currently, about 15 volunteers actively assist operations directly in curriculum design, development, web design and general administration. For example, each level guide requires roughly 20 hours of manpower, including input from EA teachers that have decades of combined experience. When added to the number of SHIC coordinators and ambassadors, by the start of the new school year SHIC will have built a network of over 50 committed volunteers. The drive and dedication of our EA volunteer core is absolutely crucial to our organizational effectiveness.Thank you to our special partnersSHIC was fortunate enough to have several operational costs covered and also received technical and financial expertise from .impact, a movement-building organization that also operates under the umbrella of the Charity Science Foundation.Because the SHIC co-founders are fronting the funds for the initial launch, and thanks to the incredibly active and collaborative effective altruism network, SHIC has made considerable strides in bringing our program to students around the world. The success of Charity Science in ushering other non-profits away from ineffective fundraising practices has translated into considerable support from like-minded charitable organizations. For example, SHIC received $5,000 USD of in-kind funding from The Life You Can Save to conduct Giving Games–an activity that give students a decision-making framework for choosing which charity to support with real money.

story:
What's Happening?

Each year, the graduating class of CSULB’s Department of Animation holds an annual industry screening where they invite notable figures in the film industry.  And this year, the graduating class of CSULB’s Department of Animation will hold the industry screening at Los Angeles. Double Exposure is our FIRST EVER off-campus screening, and will take place at the Laemmle Theater in Los Angeles on May 21st at 7pm.

 

What is double exposure?

The title Double Exposure refers to our filmmakers debut to the industry. CSULB’s BFA gallery screening “Single Exposure” will be their first debut as filmmakers to their family and friends. Double Exposure is our filmmaker’s second debut, but this time, to the industry. In addition, exposure also refers to an animator’s usage of an exposure sheet that times out character movements.

Process

All showcasing filmmakers have dedicated their heart and soul into creating, storyboarding, designing, and animating their film. After months of hard work, they are finally in the homestretch of completion. Following the screening, all films will be released publicly after finishing their rounds in the film festival circuit.

Budget

In order to fully bring Double Exposure to life and make it a complete experience, we need your help. Your donations will help cover the costs of theater rental, outsourced sound mixers, and DCP compositing. For that end, we are looking to raise $2,000.

 

What's in it for YOU?

BE A PART OF HISTORY! This is CSULB's first ever off-campus screening!

PRIZES! There are various items you can receive when you donate!

 

Risks & Challenges  - student run/effort/need help.first time. exposure/ create foundation for future

Double Exposure is a student-run event. This is the first time that the CSULB industry screening will be appearing in Los Angeles. Full funding for this event will help establish a foundation in which future graduating classes can also participate in a tradition of showing their finished films in Los Angeles.

How Else Can You Support? 

Support is greatly encourage in any form of donation and sharing via social media!

SHARE our Indiegogo!

FOLLOW our accounts

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/csulbdbex

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/csulb_dbex

story:
How the 10th Annual Black365 Knowledge Bowl Came to Be...

Growing up I thought that African Americans were destined to be one, or all of the following: athletes, drug dealers, gang members or entertainers.  

At the age of 14 I underwent heart surgery, which ended my dreams of ever becoming a basketball star. With more time on my hands, because I was no longer practicing, I began to pick up books on Black history. For the first time, I saw myself reflected on the pages of world history. I discovered that Black people were more than just athletes, drug dealers, gang members, and entertainers - but architects, engineers, astronauts and more.

Inspired by this information, I became my high school's first-ever African American valedictorian, was accepted to eight universities and received approximately $50,000 in scholarships!

The Black365 Knowledge Bowl was created with the intention of being the SPARK that sparks the mind of tomorrow's great leaders! During the Black365 Knowledge Bowl teams of young people challenge one another, and themselves, as they answer 101 questions in world history. This is a jeopardy-style quiz competition, that is fast-paced and rewarding for both the young people and the audience...with a positive lasting impact for everyone involved.


What We Need

Every participant walks away with scholarship money and prizes:

First place: $250 (for all four team members) = $1,000

Second place: $150 (for all four team members) = $600

Third place: $75 (for all four team members) = $300

Fourth place: $25 (for all four team members) = 100

 

The above scholarship amounts also come with:

Certificates of Participation

Books to continue their studies

Inspirational posters and other works of art

 

There you have it, $2,750 in the hands of the deserving college-bound high school students.

 

What Do You Get?

For your contributions, you will receive the satisfaction of knowing you assisted in the ascension of a young person’s life academically and socially! 

Also, depending on the level of support, you will have your name, or your organization’s name recognized in the official program booklet. 

You will receive a photograph of the 2020 Participants and an autographed Black365 Calendar, which is the basis for the Black365 Knowledge Bowl.

 

You can attend the 9th Annual Black365 Knowledge Bowl and promote your business with banners, decorations, give-a-ways, goodie bags... and more. An event program will be mailed to you.

 

Premiere recognition in press releases and publicity material

 

The Impact

Contributing to the 9th Annual Knowledge Bowl lets young people know there are people who exist in the world that care about them and their future. From the eight previous Knowledge Bowls, more than 100 participants are now in college and credit their Knowledge Bowl experience for having a significant impact on their lives.

 

The average G.P.A. of a Knowledge Bowl participant is 3.25

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out and make some noise about the 2016 Black365 Knowledge Bowl!

 

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us grow!

Follow us on Social Media (Instagram, FaceBook and Twitter) 

 

See you there:

February 29, 2020 2:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m.

 

Antelope Valley College's Performing Arts Theatre

3041 West Avenue K

Lancaster, CA 93536

 

This event is FREE

 

Jamaal Brown

Black365 Knowledge Bowl Organizer

story:
BUILD’S MISSION:

Building Understanding through International Learning and Development (BUILD) is an interdisciplinary student-led program of the Institute for Global Leadership at Tufts University. BUILD seeks to educate and immerse students in the theory and practice of sustainable development by partnering with rural communities in the developing world to research and implement sustainable initiatives for human, social, and economic development.

ABOUT BUILD:

BUILD is a student-led sustainable development program guided by the four pillars of education, action, solidarity, and leadership, each serving a crucial and complementary role as we work directly with rural communities in the developing world for the general improvement of their economic, social, and infrastructural condition. BUILD conducts powerful and innovative development work that operates in four stages: research, planning, execution, and analysis.

BUILD’s community partnerships are highly independent, long-term, and comprehensive, transforming the student learning experience from the purely analytical to the fully participatory. As one student said, "We impact real peoples’ lives; the stakes are too high for failure." Statements such as this have prompted BUILD to assure full community participation and deep human investment in all of our projects. The research, planning, execution, and analysis are shared activities, linking and blending the motivations and goals of the Program’s students and the members of our partner communities, for the their mutual benefit.

PROGRAM PILLARS:

Education: BUILD educates students about sustainable development, which we define as a process combining economics, anthropology, political science, and principles of social and environmental justice. Students involved in the program attend weekly meetings to discuss competing theories of economic development as well as the various political, social, and economic issues our partner communities may face given their history, geography, culture, and economy.

Action: BUILD fosters direct interaction between Tufts students and those living in developing communities in order to give students the opportunity to act in the sustainable development process with the ultimate goal of collaboratively implementing sustainable solutions to expressed needs. As interaction depends, BUILD is able to form a Community Development Plan (CDP) written conjointly by BUILD students and community leaders.

Solidarity: Direct interaction and collaboration with partner communities produces a crucial sense of solidarity between students and communities. BUILD students spend substantial time with families and youth conducting personal interviews in order to assess local needs on an individual basis. The sense of solidarity cultivated during all stages of the projects is fundamental to BUILD’s effectiveness and to ensuring the longevity of our community partnerships.

Leadership: Research and project management enable BUILD students to develop their leadership abilities in a context similar to that of a small development NGO. Grant writing, logistical planning, fundraising, budget formation, and outreach to local NGOs are just a few of the responsibilities of BUILD students, and this practical experience equips students with valuable skills while at the same time providing tangible, innovative development solutions to our partner communities.

PAST PARTNERSHIPS AND PROJECTS:

In Guatemala, BUILD partnered with the community, Santa Anita la Unión, an organic coffee cooperative located in the fertile Quetzaltenango province. Most of the men of the cooperative, and a number of the women, fought against the government with the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unit (URNG) from the 1970s to 1990s, and in 1996 this group of combatants handed in their weapons in exchange for the then-abandoned farm. BUILD worked with Santa Anita to implement numerous projects in agriculture, technology, and eco-tourism.

In India BUILD partnered with Thottiapatti, a partner village of 70 households in the Perambalur district of rural Tamil Nadu, India, is a community of individuals with a rich cultural and religious heritage. Thottiapatti lacks access to immediate transportation, toilets, consistent power supply, and medical care. Reflecting the national trend, there have been multiple recent suicides within the village that have torn families apart—leaving an overarching feeling of desolation. In Thottiapattia BUILD has worked to implement projects in public health, technology, and energy.

For more information, visit: http://tuftsgloballeadership.org/programs/build

story:
2012 THIRD STREET WALKATHON IS HERE!

The 2012 Walkathon is on Friday, April 27.  This is a great exercise-oriented event that involves students, teachers, parents, and friends and family for one great cause: raising money for Friends of Third Street programs.   The Walkathon culminates the PTA's Health Week and takes place during school hours and allows Third Street kids to have a field day while raising money for Third Street.  

Events include: walking the track, basketball shooting, cup stacking, tug-of-war, and others.  There will be a 2:30 PM assembly after the Walkathon and students and teachers will be receiving great prizes.  This is an assembly you don't want to miss.

Last year, the Walkathon raised nearly $35,000 and we are trying to beat that number this year.  We appreciate your support of Friends of Third and Third Street School.

story:
BeThePeace

EveryOne, Everywhere, Together, Now!

On September 21, 2012, on the International Day of Peace, organizations around the world are joining together to create the largest global meditation in history: BeThePeace.

This Indiegogo Campaign is to raise money for the website, the marketing materials, and the promotional strategy to make this a success!  

Become part of the movement!

BeThePeace was designed collaboratively by the Gaiafield Project, Pathways to Peace/Culture of Peace Initiative, Institute of HeartMath's Global Coherence Initiative, the Shift Network's Summer of Peace Program, and MedMob, it will feature public events in hundreds of cities worldwide with thousands of virtual participants by telecast. The public events start at 6pm in local timezones, creating a profound wave of peace across the planet. 

There will also be three specific times during the day when everyone around the world will connect at the same time. These Global Attunements for Peace will occur via teleconference/audio webcast at 12am, 12noon, and again at 12midnight EDT, creating three deep planetary pulses of peace.

BeThePeace will feature a Global Care Room, in which people around the world will 'see' each other as points of light on a spinning Google Earth map, providing a real-time visual image of the emerging global field.

We will film a video documentary of the event that will be broadcast on PeaceDay TV to thousands of networks on September 23.

BeThePeace welcomes people from every culture, from every spiritual tradition, and from every political perspective to come together as One. The event builds on a thirty year tradition of a Planetary Peace Wave on September 21 as part of the Culture of Peace Initiative. It aims to strengthen a growing global network of 'subtle activists' committed to developing internal peace as a foundation for a global culture of peace.

What We Need

We'll use the money we raise to:

  • pay for a video editor to create our BeThePeace video documentary, to be broadcast on PeaceDay TV on September 23
  • develop resources to help catapult the whole field of global meditation to a new level of cohesion and collaboration.
  • recover our costs for running this event, including the costs of creating the website, flyer, promo video, logo, and other marketing materials.
  • enable us to convene bigger and better events in the future!

What You'll Get

  • the chance to help co-create one of the largest global prayer and meditation events in history
  • a profound experience of global peace
  • an invitation to a private Global Attunement meditation telecast 
  • all the various perks listed to the right

Who We Are

The hosts of BeThePeace are the leaders of two emerging global peace organizations.

Patrick Kronfli is the director and co-founder of MedMob, which convenes monthly public flash meditation gatherings in over 380 cities worldwide.

David Nicol is the director and co-founder of the Gaiafield Project, that aims to co-create a global network of 'subtle activists' for social and global transformation.

Patrick and David are supported by a large design team, including:

  • Gaiafield Council members David Todd, Bonnie Bell, Leslie Meehan, Avon Mattison, Myra Jackson, Claudia Welss, Lynda Terry, and Sean Kelly;  
  • Prayerformance poet and artist Jody Levy
  • Social media maven and subtle activist Catherine Douglas

BeThePeace has been developed in close partnership with:

  • Pathways to Peace and the Culture of Peace Initiative, especially through Pathways to Peace founder Avon Mattison, one of the primary moving forces behind the International Day of Peace
  • The Institute of HeartMath and its Global Coherence Initiative, especially through Brian Kabaker and Claudia Welss
  • The Shift Network's Summer of Peace program, especially through Philip Hellmich.

Global Significance

We're passionate about the power of global meditation and prayer to inspire the collective imagination of humanity about what's possible on this planet when we come together as One. We believe that creating experiences of profound global communion can help to infuse love, compassion, and joy to the planet, helping us to heal our collective wounds and inspiring us to co-create a global wisdom civilization.

This event, co-designed and co-promoted by many leading organizations in the field, aims to be a model for collaborative global meditations, bringing the whole field forward to a new degree of visibility and cooperation.

Can't contribute financially but would like to help out?

  • Help us spread the word! Join our FB event page and invite your friends!
  • Share our Indiegogo campaign with the Indiegogo share tools
story_txt:
BeThePeace
EveryOne, Everywhere, Together, Now!
On September 21, 2012, on the International Day of Peace, organizations around the world are joining together to create the largest global meditation in history: BeThePeace.
This Indiegogo Campaign is to raise money for the website, the marketing materials, and the promotional strategy to make this a success!  
Become part of the movement!
BeThePeace was designed collaboratively by the Gaiafield Project, Pathways to Peace/Culture of Peace Initiative, Institute of HeartMath's Global Coherence Initiative, the Shift Network's Summer of Peace Program, and MedMob, it will feature public events in hundreds of cities worldwide with thousands of virtual participants by telecast. The public events start at 6pm in local timezones, creating a profound wave of peace across the planet. There will also be three specific times during the day when everyone around the world will connect at the same time. These Global Attunements for Peace will occur via teleconference/audio webcast at 12am, 12noon, and again at 12midnight EDT, creating three deep planetary pulses of peace.
BeThePeace will feature a Global Care Room, in which people around the world will 'see' each other as points of light on a spinning Google Earth map, providing a real-time visual image of the emerging global field.
We will film a video documentary of the event that will be broadcast on PeaceDay TV to thousands of networks on September 23.
BeThePeace welcomes people from every culture, from every spiritual tradition, and from every political perspective to come together as One. The event builds on a thirty year tradition of a Planetary Peace Wave on September 21 as part of the Culture of Peace Initiative. It aims to strengthen a growing global network of 'subtle activists' committed to developing internal peace as a foundation for a global culture of peace.


What We Need
We'll use the money we raise to:

pay for a video editor to create our BeThePeace video documentary, to be broadcast on PeaceDay TV on September 23
develop resources to help catapult the whole field of global meditation to a new level of cohesion and collaboration.
recover our costs for running this event, including the costs of creating the website, flyer, promo video, logo, and other marketing materials.
enable us to convene bigger and better events in the future!

What You'll Get

the chance to help co-create one of the largest global prayer and meditation events in history
a profound experience of global peace
an invitation to a private Global Attunement meditation telecast 
all the various perks listed to the right



Who We Are
The hosts of BeThePeace are the leaders of two emerging global peace organizations.

Gaiafield Council members David Todd, Bonnie Bell, Leslie Meehan, Avon Mattison, Myra Jackson, Claudia Welss, Lynda Terry, and Sean Kelly;  
Prayerformance poet and artist Jody Levy
Social media maven and subtle activist Catherine Douglas

BeThePeace has been developed in close partnership with:


Pathways to Peace and the Culture of Peace Initiative, especially through Pathways to Peace founder Avon Mattison, one of the primary moving forces behind the International Day of Peace
The Institute of HeartMath and its Global Coherence Initiative, especially through Brian Kabaker and Claudia Welss

The Shift Network's Summer of Peace program, especially through Philip Hellmich.

Global Significance
We're passionate about the power of global meditation and prayer to inspire the collective imagination of humanity about what's possible on this planet when we come together as One. We believe that creating experiences of profound global communion can help to infuse love, compassion, and joy to the planet, helping us to heal our collective wounds and inspiring us to co-create a global wisdom civilization.
This event, co-designed and co-promoted by many leading organizations in the field, aims to be a model for collaborative global meditations, bringing the whole field forward to a new degree of visibility and cooperation.

story:
Cerebral palsy, which causes mental and physical impairment, occurs in roughly 2.1 out of 1000 live births. Many people with cerebral palsy face immense challenges in carrying out tasks that others can do without a second thought. 


With today's technology we have been able to achieve something invaluable: efficient communication for those with vocal disabilities in developing countries. Through a very easy-to-use Android app, "Roshni" ("Light" in Hindi),  that we created, people with vocal disabilities are now able to access a specialised Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) picture database developed specifically for those with severe speech or language problems, and conveniently construct storyboards and sentences with these symbols.



While volunteering at IICP we noticed that students were using pictorial storyboard print-outs from PCs to help them carry out activities such as shopping or eating out in the wider community. We realised that it would be easy to transfer this system into a mobile device that the student can carry around in order to more efficiently and dynamically interact with the community while on the move. A few years ago, this would have been a very expensive proposition. But with the advent of low-cost Android tablets, we realised that we could place a powerful yet inexpensive communication tool into the hands of the student; a tool that could immensely improve his or her quality of life. 

We converted IICP's picture symbol library into a format compatible with Android applications, and have created a pilot app, which is already being used throughout IICP by its students.

It is now time to expand the use of this tool more widely in IICP. If it succeeds here, there is potential to roll it out across the entire Indian subcontinent over time.

IICP has authorised us to fundraise on its behalf. We are targeting to raise £700 pounds in order to distribute 10 or more low-cost Android tablets loaded with the app, for use by the institute's students.

In India, there are approximately 33 000 people with cerebral palsy. IICP has multiple affiliated schools in the region and therefore your contribution has the potential to touch the lives of literally thousands of afflicted students in an incredibly positive way.

Even if the total goal is not met, we will use the amount raised to purchase and provide as many tablets to IICP as possible.

If you are unable to make a monetary contribution, you can still assist this cause, by spreading word of this campaign, cerebral palsy, and the amazing work being done by IICP.


We thank you immensely for your generosity.

Useful Links

Cerebral Palsy in India: 

http://www.iicpindia.org/PDF/What%20is%20Cerebral%20Palsy.pdf

The Indian Institute of Cerebral Palsy:

http://www.iicpindia.org/

Augmentative and Alternative Communication:

http://www.communicationmatters.org.uk/about-aac

story:
Who we are

Oxford Educational society was established in 1991 at Mahabubabad, Warangal, India. The primary aim of the institution was to provide education for the poor at affordable cost. However things changed after the founders realized that there are several people who cannot afford any money for education in this small town. 

The founders Mr. Sarangapani and Sunitha Devi introduced a system where the Tuition Fee is flexible to a child based on financial situation of child's parents. Families who cannot afford education for their children serve as volunteers in cooking, donating fresh vegetables from their farms and in turn get their children live and study at the society. Soon Oxford Educational Society evolved into a full fledged Residential School for the poor and runs under name "Twinkle Star High School".

However this system doesn't get the children enough of what they need. The basic things like a warm bed and hygienic kitchen are missing at the Residential campus. These children need your help to get some good sleep and hygienic food!!! 

What We Need & What You Get

The children at the society need Beds for proper sleep and if we can stretch the goal we'd like to setup a steam cooking kitchen run with cooking gas instead of Firewood.

  • Each bunk bed sleeps 2 children and costs 100$. For 200 children to sleep in a bed would cost 100 x $100 = $10000
  • The steam cooking equipment includes Steam cooking vessels, Gas Burners, Cutting tables, Potato Peeling machine, Dough mixing Machine which costs around $5000. This would be a stretch goal for us.
  • Your help will be remembered permanently, the children would.
  • Even if we didn't reach the goal, all the funds will be used to buy as many beds as we can.

          



The Impact

We believe Bed and hygienic food are basic needs which every person in the world should easily get. A donation how small it may be will make larger impact in the lives of these children, their families and the help will never be forgotten.

Steam Cooking system



Children @ Twinkle Star High school

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please do spread the word by sharing this campaign on social networking sites.
  • If you're kind enough, you can talk with the children and build their hope that there are others in the world who care for them.
  • If you have time, you're welcome to volunteer as a cook or teacher or anyone which can help these children build their future.

                         

                                                May God Bless you

story:
http://conference.theleadershipcentre.ca/

Our Story

The Leadership Centre of Central Alberta is a not-for-profit leadership training centre based in Red Deer, Alberta.  Since 2000, the Leadership Centre has been offering unique, experiential learning to up-and-coming leaders with a focus on strengthening our community.  

In May 2013, the Leadership Centre hosted the first Leadership Conference, which included live presenters, an interactive gala with an Alberta Sings competition, and live Leadercast feed.  We made the conference accessible to people working in all different sectors, with flexible pricing to accommodate non-profit agencies, and sponsorship for students. Please have a look at the above video to hear from our Executive Director, Linda Wilson!  Reviews from the conference were overwhelmingly positive, which has inspired us to do it again.

This September, the Leadership Conference returns, but we need your help to make it a great success!  We've gained some valuable learning from last year to apply to the 2014 conference to make it even more engaging, fun, and valuable.  However, we do not have access to the same dollars that we did last year, so we are asking you to be a part of this event in any way you can!

Our Challenge

Last year's conference was an eye-opener for us at the Leadership Centre; it takes a lot of work and a lot of funds to present a crowd-pleasing event!  We are working towards making the Conference a sustainability tool for the Leadership Centre, but it takes time to make that happen.  We are working towards making ourselves self-sufficient, and towards making events like these more available in our community.  However, to get to that point, we do need help from the community that we have helped support over the years.  We look forward to self-sufficiency to allow the Centre to fulfill its mission of supporting the community through growing our leaders.  Your assistance is deeply appreciated, and we look forward to seeing you at the conference!

Where Will the Funds Go?

The 2014 Leadership Conference will consist of these main components:

  • Live speakers
  • Evening gala
  • Silent auction raising awareness and volunteer hours for local charities
  • Alberta Sings competition (raising money for other non-profits)
  • Leadercast presenters
  • Presentation of Leadership Networks community project - Suspended Coffees

The funds raised through this campaign will go directly to helping to cover the largest items: speaker fees and facility costs (meals, room rentals, A/V needs, etc.).  When you donate, you will have the opportunity to receive a variety of perks - please check them out for more details!

If we are unable to reach our funding goal, any funds received will still go towards the two main components noted above.

    The Impact

    Your donation will help us deliver two meaningful days of quality presentations and engagement.  Our conference will benefit not only our attendees, but people they interact with as well, and some other non-profit groups who will be able to gain some volunteers.  Here are just some of the ways individuals and our community will benefit:

    • Community - The ability for participants to network with people from different sectors and backgrounds; raising awareness and volunteer hours for local non-profit organizations; offering opportunities for participants to apply their learning in their own lives and workplaces.
    • Individual growth - One of the best examples of individual growth at last year's conference was watching the participants in the Alberta Sings competition - regular people with their coworkers pushing themselves outside of their comfort zone to perform in front of a live audience.  Their motivation was raising funds for a charity close to their hearts, and it showed that they were inspired!
    • Volunteers - Our silent auction is unique in that we are not raising money for items; instead, we are raising volunteer hours!  Each bid consists of the number of volunteer hours the bidder would be willing to put towards being involved with a non-profit that is new to them.  And the items that they are bidding on often are not objects, but experiences!
    • Growth of the Leadership Centre - A successful conference this year means that the Leadership Centre will be able to continue to offer the Leadership Networks program in the community, and to build on the current programs offered!  

    Last year's conference was very well-received, and we got so many positive comments about the value of the event.  Attendees from non-profit groups were so happy to have a discounted rate to make the event more accessible to them.

    Can't Donate?  Please Share!

    If you are unable to donate but still would like to help, please share our conference link!  We want to make the Leadership Centre famous in Central Alberta to help strengthen our community!

    Please share our campaign and invite your friends, family, and co-workers to a great conference in the fall!

story:
Please Help Me Attend the School of Visual Arts Implementing Impact: The Business of Social Design One Week Design Intensive Workshop

Hello and welcome to my fundraising page! My name is Antionette Carroll and I am social impact designer from St. Louis, MO. During the day, I manage the marketing and visual communications of Diversity Awareness Partnership (dapstl.org), a non-profit dedicated to promoting diversity in the St. Louis region around issues of race, religion, disability, sexual orientation and gender identity. At night, I manage my independent social innovation design and communications consultancy, CHAx365 – Challenge. Change. Champion.

I am also a Community Producer of the Nine Network, a leader and student of IDEO.org and +Acumen’s Human Centered Design Course, and the Vice President and Creator & Chair of Diversity Initiatives of the American Institute of Graphic Artists – St. Louis Chapter.

WHY I WOULD LIKE TO ATTEND IMPLEMENTING IMPACT: THE BUSINESS OF SOCIAL DESIGN

To further my initiatives in social impact design and social entrepreneurship, I applied to the School of Visual Arts Implement Impact: The Business of Social Design and I was recently accepted. But, I need your help to get there!

As a designer, I tend to develop projects focused on diversity, women's rights, the United Nations Millennium Development Goals, mental health and eradicating extreme poverty. Also, one of my goals is to diversify the Creative Industries by raising awareness of career opportunities within these fields for lower-income youth and encouraging mentorship and other support systems for practicing minority professionals. 

I plan on using this experience to provide me with the strategic framework to develop high impact designs that will improve communications and communities through my efforts at Diversity Awareness Partnership. Concurrently, I plan on using the lessons developed during Implementing Impact to work on independent projects and exhibitions, such as my upcoming exhibition at the Regional Arts Commission focused on social justice apparel (see perks!). My long term goal is to develop my own non-profit and social enterprise focused on diversifying the arts and commercial design field, while teaching my students leadership and social justice activism skills.

ABOUT IMPLEMENTING IMPACT: THE BUSINESS OF SOCIAL DESIGN

This one-week intensive workshop will focus on the business of social design by exploring critical topics in hands-on modules ranging from analysis, marketing, management and operations to funding models.

While the road to social change is paved with good ideas and good intentions, many projects never reach a final destination. Why is this? For an idea to sustain itself, it needs to be more than a good idea, it needs a sustainable business model to be viable.

The week is built for creative professionals looking to launch their own projects or adapting their practice to be more socially engaged. And, for those interested in working in the field of social design, the program will give participants a number of perspectives and critical factors applicable to any project.

Experienced faculty will introduce participants to the the skills and understanding needed to execute sustainable projects. Daily conversations with a dynamic range of industry leaders will engage students in a dialog around a number of relevant topics. This is a rare opportunity to engage with innovators in the field in an intimate atmosphere. 

What I Need for Program (in other words: Why Am I Fundraising?)

To attend the one week intensive in the School of Visual Arts in New York, I need to raise funds for the following:

Workshop Fee - $1000

One-Week Residence - $500 (minimum)

Air Travel - $350 (average)

I also need funding for ground transportation, food and workshop materials.

All funds will be used to all for me to attend this workshop without added stress of financial needs. If this campaign was to exceed the minimum amount needed of $2800, I will use the excess funding for additional workshop materials including the purchase of a MacBook (which is technically required for the workshop, but I plan on asking for a waiver), as well as to help with the creation of independent projects (including the exhibition mentioned in the perks!). 

Please check out some of my unique perks to the right, including the opportunity to be an early investor/sponsor of my pop-up social justice apparel shop/exhibition at the Regional Arts Commission in 2015. Another special perk includes my willingness to become a reporter of New York attractions for 5 special donors (complete with a commemorative coffee book).

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't support my campaign financially, I would love for you to share this campaign through your social channels! Please help me raise the necessary funds to attend this life-changing educational opportunity. 

Thank you!

(Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!)

Feel free to reach out to me at acarroll@dapstl.org for any questions and/or additional information!

Another special perk includes my willingness to become a reporter of New York attractions for 5 special donors (complete with a commemorative coffee book).Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can't support my campaign financially, I would love for you to share this campaign through your social channels! Please help me raise the necessary funds to attend this life-changing educational opportunity. Thank you!(Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!)Feel free to reach out to me at acarroll@dapstl.org for any questions and/or additional information!

story:
Short Summary

Centre for youth activism KRIK is non-governmental, non-profit organization established by young people, led by young people and it works for and with young people. The translation of the word KRIK is SCREECH/OUTCRY and the inspiration for it came out of the vision of this organization, which is to be the voice of the youth that will be heard and will make changes and contributions in the society. KRIK strives to encourage greater youth participation, youth activism, encourage young people to be more included in the policy making process on local and national level. The target group that KRIK works with are all people (but mainly youth) who want to contribute and make changes in the field of ecology, critical thinking and communicative skills, as well as working for the well-being of the socially excluded groups from the society. 

In the last 2 years the youth workers from KRIK have been working with young people from the National School for deaf young people Partenija Zoografski. Together with the participants we accomplished different activities on local and international level. 

We are croudfunding to renovate and improve the conditions that supports the target group.

- We need this amount of money to continue with the workshops, to renovate the commune space (books, furniture, games for inclusion), and to prepare the festival. We will make one big festival of differences with a focus on social integration of young people with fewer opportunities. At the festival we will include young deaf people, young people that have Dayn syndrome and young people that does not have any mentally or physical problems. At the festival there will be open space where we will raise some really important questions about the integration of these young people in the society. We will include all the relevant stakeholders: the families, the teachers, the ministries… and have nice debate where we can discus all of these issues together and find a way how to improve it. 

So we need you help in order to continue the activities that we are delivering with the young deaf people. We need to fund 7 000 euro in order to accomplish the mention activities above. 

We will raise the money from the business sector and individuals on different ways. We already started with mini caravan with the theater show where the actors are the young deaf people. We are charging symbolic price for the ticket. Also we walk in the city center with donation box, we write mails to some of the companies in Macedonia and the last part is this crowd funding.

In case if we do not get the expected amount of money from this crowdfunding, we will continue with the activities with some cuts wherever is needed :)

In case you can not help us and support us financially, there is still a way for you to be included in the campaign, just get the word out and make some noise about our campaign :) Do not forget to use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Lets make an awesome camp

SKATEDUCATE is a volunteer organization, that aims to give girls the skills and community to become rad skaters and take over skate ramps all over the world.

The SKATEDUCATE-team is working hard and the dream is becoming reality, but to get fully started we need money and equipment for our very first SKATEDUCATE camp.

Camps to encourage

So what is a SKATEDUCATE camp? A SKATEDUCATE camp is a camp for all girls that want to learn how to skate. The camps are moving from city to city, but the first one will be in Aarhus, Denmark. 

We seek to encourage communities across age, cultural and social differences. By making camps in a local community we are making sure, that the girls get to know the best places to skate near their homes, and they get to meet other girls from their area, with whom they can continue to skate with, when the SKATEDUCATE camp is over.

The world needs SKATEDUCATE

SKATEDUCATE challenges the definition of how a woman should act, look and think of herself in societal context. SKATEDUCATE aims to create a safe place for the girls, where they can learn and build community to support them, when they move on in life and in to the male dominated skate scene. Hopefully the girls will bring the skills and competences with them in other aspects of their lives. 

What do you get if you support SKATEDUCATE?

Besides getting a warm and fuzzy feeling inside, you get a generation of young women, who dare to take chances. You get streets filled with girls who are strong and who spend less time taking selfies and more time celebrating the scratches on their knees. But of course we've got perks for you as well! 

Get a brilliant and unique handmade skate deck 

Five amazing artists have lend us their time and talent and made some unique and cool skate decks for this campaign. For 450 USD the deck you like the most can be yours. But be quick, we only have one of each. The wooden skateboard deck is a canvas, that none of the artists have used before, so the boards are truly one of a kind pieces of art!

The Sys A Board

Sys Abrahamsen is a danish artist, who grew up in Greenland. The title for The Sys A board is "Nordlige Hjem" (Northern Homes). The decoration on the board is inspired by the meeting between nature and housing in Greenland, -from old colonial houses to the 1960' concrete buildings. Sys A lives in Aarhus at the moment, but is attending the school of design in Kolding, Denmark. To see more of Sys' work go to sysabrahamsen.com

The A Mile In The Woods Board

A mile in the woods is a visual laboratory, run by illustrator and cand.arch Louise Haugaard Nielsen. It is an all day all night creative platform from where a variety of projects emerges. You never know what´s coming next. A mile in the woods is founded on the great, thorough craft of drawing by hand, combined with a love for experimenting with visual storytelling. To see more of a mile in the woods go to amileinthewoods.dk

The Iris Bakker Board

Iris Bakker is studying communication design. She is interested in interactiondesign, that deals with people and psycology and often tries to change behavior. She is fascinated and inspired by people, language, geography, mail and food. To se more of Iris Bakkers' work go to her blog

The Nic Naar Board

Nic Naar is Born in the southern corner of the planet.  Patagonia and Pacific Ocean.  He is now living on its northern top.  Windy and silent Baltic sea.  He is captivated by us, the people of the world, and our ability to reflect the life around us. To see more of Nic Naar's work go to nicnaar.com

The ToritoMalo Board

ToritoMalo is studying to become a Design Manager in Kolding, Denmark. On the art scene he is best known for his black and white pipe illustrations and for being a blogger on IDOART.dk. Besides drawing pipes he likes to draw characters and to illustrate different sorts of puns. Describing himself ToritoMalo says; I am a bit of a pessimist, but perhaps that is exactly why I seek to create happiness. To see more of ToritoMalo's work go to his Facebook page

More perks:

Get a T-Shirt made by the girls

On the camp the girls will have the opportunity to learn other cool things than skating. We will have a batik-workshop, where the girls will make cool t-shirts for themselves, and maybe one for you?

Get a special SKATEDUCATE bag

We will make special cotton shopping bags with a cool print and the SKATEDUCATE logo for those who would rather have a bag than a t-shirt. 

What about some art and stickers?

Get an original piece of art and some nice SKATEDUCATE stickers. We will send you the original art piece, a description of the artist behind the piece and a handful of SKATEDUCATE stickers. Solvej Asmark, Ban-Mai Mong Phan, Line Patricia Jakobsen and Boyeon Kang have all donated pieces of original art to us, and you will get one of them, if you buy this perk. Line Patricia Jakobsen made this sweet armadillo on a board. 

Don't have coins in your pocket? 

You can donate other stuff like helmets and boards. If you have an idea, would like to join the SKATEDUCATE movement or want to donate something that is not money? Contact us on info@skateducate.com

We love all of our contributors!! 

All donations, big or small, are helping us accomplish our goal. We want to make sure that the girls have to pay as little as possible to be on the camp, and every contribution is a step on the way making this dream come true. THANK YOU GUYS! 

And by the way - everyone who donates to SKATEDUCATE via Indiegogo gets an email with news and thoughts from our firs SKATEDUCATE camp in Aarhus, Denmark. 


Get to know us better - visit our webpage: skateducate.com


Update: 

We've got 2 snowskates, 10 Roces helmets and 10 Roces safety equipment sets from Skatepro! Thank you Skatepro - you guys rock! 

Anne went to Greenland to visit Sisimiut, where we are making a camp in the summer. Watch the cool girls in Sisimiut try snowskates for the very first time!

story:
Who We Are

The Migrant and Refugee Communities Forum was established in 1993 in response to the needs of migrant and refugee communities in North West London. Settled economic migrants as well as newly arrived refugees struggled in their attempts to access health and welfare services, employment and education, legal advice, and housing. They formed community organisations to share their knowledge and skills and to support each other.

We were created as a trusted intermediary for shared infrastructure support that would sustain their on-the-ground work with specific communities. We were conceived and are still governed by representatives of migrant and refugee communities. We continue to proudly serve and advocate for the issues these migrant groups face in London and the UK.

What We Do 

- Community Organising

- Leadership Development 

- Non-formal & Alternative Education

- Mentoring

- Research & Policy

- Advocacy & Campaigning 

The New Beginnings Mentoring Project 

Mentoring is our tool for combating isolation and loneliness. We use it to empower individuals and communities to tackle and overcome the hardships they encounter as migrants and refugees in London. We use it to impart skills and knowledge that will bring migrant communities forward and that improve social and mental wellbeing. We use it to build the capacity of people and groups so that they themselves can become active multipliers of change. 

Besides offering one-on-one mentoring matches between trained individuals and refugees in need, the New Beginnings Project has grown around a core of services and activities that support refugees, migrants and asylum seekers who are isolated or need extra support to build confidence, access services and develop new abilities so that they can build happier lives in London. 

These activities include:

- English and Mathematics classes

- Social theatre workshops

- Knitting and sewing classes

- Digital drop-in classes

- Support groups for women, men and young people

- Cultural Fridays

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to keep creating New Beginnings for our people and their communities! The £5,000 we are raising is going towards our non-formal and alternative education activities budget, especially the Cultural Fridays.

These Cultural Fridays are weekly get-togethers comprising a portfolio of cultural and arts and craft skills workshops that strengthen the mental and physical wellbeing of our beneficiaries, many of which suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. 

We usually have 15 attendees at a time and we run 40 such events yearly, meaning that we have the potential to reach up to 600 individuals alone just through this aspect of our work. Every session costs us £150 and includes craft materials, refreshments, travel expenses and snacks for the attendees. We need to raise a total of £5,500 to be able to continue our Cultural Fridays this year. We have already raised £500 from our supporters and need your help to cover the rest.

In return for your generous support we are offering you the fruits of our work - our refugees will show you their appreciation and respect by sending you the items they have created during these Cultural Fridays.

The Impact

Focusing on the mental wellbeing of refugees and engaging them in holistic activities that stimulate the mind and the body, helping them to be creative and innovative is essential for their integration and participation in society. 

Our New Beginnings Project tackles feelings of loneliness and isolation stemming from post-traumatic stress disorder by offering activities that focus on mental health and wellbeing and that stimulate our beneficiaries to feel included and cared for. 

We want to be able to continue our important work and grow our New Beginnings Project. This is where you can step in and make a difference!

Other Ways You Can Help

Every share, like and shout-out helps spread the word about our campaign and the work that we do. So please, help us reach as many people as possible. Tell your friends, your family, your boss and work colleagues. Tell everyone you know and invite them to tell others.

story:
Short Summary

What is better than educating the next generation of leaders? Educating those who would educate the next generation! This increases impact, maximizes results and is about multiplication not addition. What we do is help institutions organically determine how to become better at that primary role - education. We offer a platform that enables them to grow their skills, collaborate across disciplines and get the results they want.  

What We Need & What You Get

This process is funded completely by donations and funds raised by the trainers themselves. To do what we do effectively we need:

  • To purchase resources - books, material etc to facilitate the training
  • To assist local leaders in their transportation and accommodation costs to attend and help facilitate the training
  • To travel - by road and air to these locations
  •  To help us do all this, we are asking for $ 2000 

The Impact

The impact is hard to measure or quantify, but consider this -  our training... 

  • Is about multiplication not addition - do the math
  • Creates sustainable educational solutions in the form of human capital invested into those who care deeply for their communities
  • Increases the effectiveness of the teaching/learning process thereby creating better "products" - the graduate! 
  • Allows for reproducability  
  • Helps in an industry the government of South Africa has declared their # 1 need! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign on social media
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Share our with your small group
  • Pray for us 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
***Update, Friday, May 9***

We regret to inform the HARO/HA community that the Great Homeschool Conventions (GHC) board has — without any explanation — reneged on the offer for R.L. Stollar, Executive Director of HARO, to speak at the June 2014 GHC convention in Ontario, California. The HARO board has made repeated efforts to communicate with the GHC board and ask them to reconsider this reversal of their original invitation. However, the GHC board has not reconsidered. When they did respond after several days, they failed to give any reasoning for the decision beyond simply stating that they did not approve the application. Please read more here: http://homeschoolersanonymous.wordpress.com/2014/05/09/ghc-retracts-invitation-to-haro/
To everyone who shared and/or donated to our fundraiser: Thank you for the support. It is greatly appreciated. It is a blessing to know that so many people stand behind our vision and mission as much as we do. If you donated to our GHC campaign, please read the above link. We will be reaching out to all of you individually tomorrow to figure out how best to handle the funds currently raised. 
****

This is HARO's first convention opportunity!

Homeschool Alumni Reaching Out (HARO) has a vision: "Renewing and transforming homeschooling from within." We are a non-profit organization dedicated to advocating for the wellbeing of homeschool students and improving homeschooling communities through awareness, peer support, and resource development.

Our hope is to develop partnerships with homeschooling communities and groups to bring awareness to, and empower homeschoolers to address, pressing matters such as child abuse and mental illness. HARO has recently received its first opportunity to present at a homeschool convention — the 2014 Great Homeschool Convention in Ontario, California. 

This is an amazing opportunity for us. R.L. Stollar, Executive Director of HARO, will be speaking on "Facing Our Fears: How the Voices of Homeschool Alumni Can Help Homeschooling." He will also be in the convention exhibitor hall at HARO's booth for the three days of the convention. Before we can do this, however, we need to raise funds.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1250 to present at the GHC convention. While GHC does not charge speakers, they do require that speakers are also exhibitors. Their exhibitor fee is $500. We also need to cover lodging, transportation, and printing costs for the 3 days of the event. Every dollar raised from this fundraiser will go towards HARO's presentation at the convention.

  • Everyone that contributes at least $10 to this fundraiser will receive a free digital download of HARO's convention presentation, "Facing Our Fears: How the Voices of Homeschool Alumni Can Help Homeschooling." The presentation will be available to download no later than one week after the convention.
  • If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will use what we have and seek other sources of funding as well.

The Impact

Speaking at homeschooling conventions like GHC gives HARO the opportunity to expand our audience and bring our message directly to thousands of homeschooling parents and families. Our booth will be open for the three days of the convention and we can spread awareness to the very people we hope to reach in order to create vitally important change. And through our presentation, our voices will be receiving an official platform.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Here are some ways you can help us instead:

  • Ask friends on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and other social media outlets to make some noise about our campaign.
  • Spread the word about responsible homeschool advocacy. Talk to your friends and family about Homeschool Alumni Reaching Out and Homeschoolers Anonymous. Our website is http://hareachingout.org.
  • If you're a homeschooling parent, talk to your homeschooling community about the importance of discussing issues like child abuse, mental illness, self-injury, and LGBT* issues. Speaking up is the first step towards breaking stigmas.

And if you're in Southern California, come see R.L. Stollar and HARO present at GHC! You can find more information about the convention here: https://www.greathomeschoolconventions.com
story_txt:
***Update, Friday, May 9***We regret to inform the HARO/HA community that the Great Homeschool Conventions (GHC) board has — without any explanation — reneged on the offer for R.L. Stollar, Executive Director of HARO, to speak at the June 2014 GHC convention in Ontario, California. The HARO board has made repeated efforts to communicate with the GHC board and ask them to reconsider this reversal of their original invitation. However, the GHC board has not reconsidered. When they did respond after several days, they failed to give any reasoning for the decision beyond simply stating that they did not approve the application. Please read more here: http://homeschoolersanonymous.wordpress.com/2014/05/09/ghc-retracts-invitation-to-haro/
To everyone who shared and/or donated to our fundraiser: Thank you for the support. It is greatly appreciated. It is a blessing to know that so many people stand behind our vision and mission as much as we do. If you donated to our GHC campaign, please read the above link. We will be reaching out to all of you individually tomorrow to figure out how best to handle the funds currently raised. ****This is HARO's first convention opportunity!Homeschool Alumni Reaching Out (HARO) has a vision: "Renewing and transforming homeschooling from within." We are a non-profit organization dedicated to advocating for the wellbeing of homeschool students and improving homeschooling communities through awareness, peer support, and resource development.Our hope is to develop partnerships with homeschooling communities and groups to bring awareness to, and empower homeschoolers to address, pressing matters such as child abuse and mental illness. HARO has recently received its first opportunity to present at a homeschool convention — the 2014 Great Homeschool Convention in Ontario, California. This is an amazing opportunity for us. R.L. Stollar, Executive Director of HARO, will be speaking on "Facing Our Fears: How the Voices of Homeschool Alumni Can Help Homeschooling." He will also be in the convention exhibitor hall at HARO's booth for the three days of the convention. Before we can do this, however, we need to raise funds.What We Need & What You GetWe need to raise $1250 to present at the GHC convention. While GHC does not charge speakers, they do require that speakers are also exhibitors. Their exhibitor fee is $500. We also need to cover lodging, transportation, and printing costs for the 3 days of the event. Every dollar raised from this fundraiser will go towards HARO's presentation at the convention.
Everyone that contributes at least $10 to this fundraiser will receive a free digital download of HARO's convention presentation, "Facing Our Fears: How the Voices of Homeschool Alumni Can Help Homeschooling." The presentation will be available to download no later than one week after the convention.
If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will use what we have and seek other sources of funding as well.
The ImpactSpeaking at homeschooling conventions like GHC gives HARO the opportunity to expand our audience and bring our message directly to thousands of homeschooling parents and families. Our booth will be open for the three days of the convention and we can spread awareness to the very people we hope to reach in order to create vitally important change. And through our presentation, our voices will be receiving an official platform.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Here are some ways you can help us instead:
Ask friends on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and other social media outlets to make some noise about our campaign.
Spread the word about responsible homeschool advocacy. Talk to your friends and family about Homeschool Alumni Reaching Out and Homeschoolers Anonymous. Our website is http://hareachingout.org.

If you're a homeschooling parent, talk to your homeschooling community about the importance of discussing issues like child abuse, mental illness, self-injury, and LGBT* issues. Speaking up is the first step towards breaking stigmas.
And if you're in Southern California, come see R.L. Stollar and HARO present at GHC! You can find more information about the convention here: https://www.greathomeschoolconventions.com
